verses.latin: Et abiit rex et omnes viri qui erant cum eo in Ierusalem, ad Jebusæum habitatorem terræ: dixeruntque ad David Jebusæi: Non ingredieris huc, sed excæcabunt te cæci et claudi, dicentes: non ingredietur David huc.
verses.english: Then the king and all the men who were with him went to Jerusalem, to the Jebusites who inhabited that land. The Jebusites defiantly said to David, 'You will not enter this place! Even the blind and the lame can drive you out,' mockingly asserting, 'David will never enter here!'

verses.latin: Cepit autem David arcem Sion, hæc est civitas David.
verses.english: Nevertheless, David successfully captured the stronghold of Zion. This place became known as the City of David.

verses.latin: Dixit enim David in die illa: Omnis qui percusserit Jebusæum, ascendat per fistulas tecta domus, et tangat cæcos et claudos et odio habentes animam David. Idcirco dicitur in proverbio: Cæcus et claudus non intrabunt in templum.
verses.english: For David had declared on that day: 'Whoever strikes down a Jebusite must ascend through the water shaft and attack these blind and lame ones who are so hated by David's soul.' This is why it is said in a proverb: 'The blind and the lame will not enter the holy place.'

verses.latin: Habitavit itaque David in arce, et vocavit eam civitatem David: et ædificavit David in circuitu a Mello et intrinsecus.
verses.english: So David took up residence in the stronghold, and he named it the City of David. Then David built walls and fortifications all around the city, from the Millo inward.

verses.latin: Et proficiebat David crescens atque magnificabatur, et Dominus Deus exercituum erat cum eo.
verses.english: And David continued to prosper, growing in power and becoming highly esteemed, because the Lord God of hosts—the God of armies—was with him.

verses.latin: Misit quoque Hiram rex Tyri nuntios ad David, et ligna cedrina, et fabros lignorum, et artifices lapidum, et ædificaverunt domum David.
verses.english: Hiram, the king of Tyre, also sent messengers to David, along with cedar timber, carpenters, and stonemasons. And these skilled craftsmen built a royal palace for David.

verses.latin: Et cognovit David quoniam confirmasset eum Dominus regem super Israël, et quoniam exaltasset regnum ejus super populum suum Israël.
verses.english: And David understood that the Lord God had firmly established him as king over all Israel, and that He had greatly exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.

verses.latin: Accepit quoque David adhuc concubinas et uxores de Ierusalem, postquam venerat de Hebron: natique sunt ei filii et filiæ.
verses.english: After he came from Hebron, David also took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem. And more sons and daughters were born to him there.

verses.latin: Et hæc nomina eorum qui nati sunt ei in Ierusalem: Samua et Sobab, et Nathan, et Salomon,
verses.english: These are the names of the children who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon.

verses.latin: et Jebahar, et Elisua, et Nepheg,
verses.english: Ibhar, Elishua, and Nepheg.

verses.latin: et Japhia, et Elisama, et Elioda, et Eliphaleth.
verses.english: Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphalet.

verses.latin: Audierunt autem Philisthiim quod unctus esset David rex super Israël, et ascenderunt omnes Philisthiim ut quærerent David: et audivit David, et descendit in præsidium.
verses.english: Now the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, and all the Philistines came up to seek him out and fight. When David heard this, he went down to his stronghold—a secure place.

verses.latin: Philisthiim autem venientes diffusi sunt in valle Raphaim.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the Philistines had come and spread themselves out in the Valley of Rephaim.

verses.latin: Et consuluit David Dominum, dicens: Ascendam ad Philisthiim? et trades eos in manu mea? Dixit Dominus ad David: Ascende, quia tradens tradam Philisthiim in manu tua.
verses.english: And David consulted the Lord God, saying, 'Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You hand them over into my power?' The Lord God said to David, 'Go up, for I will surely hand the Philistines over into your power.'

verses.latin: Venit ergo David in Baal Pharisim: et percussit eos ibi David, et dixit: Divisit Dominus inimicos meos coram me, sicut dividuntur aquæ: idcirco vocatum est nomen loci illius, Baal Pharisim.
verses.english: So David came to Baal Perazim. There David struck them down and said, 'The Lord God has broken through my enemies before me, just as waters burst forth and divide!' Therefore, the name of that place was called Baal Perazim, meaning 'Lord of Breakthroughs'.

verses.latin: Et dimiserunt ibi sculptilia sua: quæ tulit David et viri ejus.
verses.english: And there the Philistines abandoned their idols. David and his men then carried these idols away.

verses.latin: Et adhuc ascenderunt Philisthiim, et diffusi sunt in valle Raphaim.
verses.english: But the Philistines came up again and spread themselves out once more in the Valley of Rephaim.

verses.latin: Et consuluit David Dominum: qui respondit: Non ascendis, sed circui per tergum eorum, et venies ad eos ex adverso pyrorum.
verses.english: And David again consulted the Lord God. He responded, 'Do not go up directly against them. Instead, circle around behind them, and attack them from the front of the balsam trees.'

verses.latin: Et cum audieris sonitum gradientis in vertice pyrorum, tunc irrues: quia tunc egredietur Dominus ante faciem tuam, ut percutiat castra Philisthiim.
verses.english: And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then you must rush forward, for at that very moment, the Lord God will go out before you to strike down the Philistine army.

verses.latin: Fecit ergo David sicut præceperat ei Dominus, et percussit Philisthiim de Geba, usque dum venias in Gezer.
verses.english: So David did just as the Lord God had commanded him. He struck down the Philistines all the way from Geba to Gezer.

verses.latin: Congregavit ergo David rursum omnes electos ex Israël, triginta millia.
verses.english: So King David gathered together again all the chosen warriors of Israel, thirty thousand of them.

verses.latin: Et surrexit David et abiit, et universus populus cum eo de viris Juda adducere arcam Dei, super quam invocatum est nomen Domini exercituum, sedentes super Cherubim.
verses.english: David himself went up, and all the people with him, from among the men of Judah, to bring the Ark of God back. This Ark is where the very Name of the Lord of all Creation is called upon, the Lord who is enthroned above the Cherubim.

verses.latin: Et imposuerunt arcam Dei super plaustrum novum: et tulerunt eam de domo Abinadab in Gabaa: Oza autem et Ahio filii Abinadab minabant plaustrum novum.
verses.english: They placed the Ark of God upon a new wagon, and they brought it out from the house of Abinadab, which was located on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab's sons, were driving this new wagon.

verses.latin: Cumque tulissent eam de domo Abinadab, qui erat in Gabaa, Ahio præcedebat arcam.
verses.english: As they carried it from Abinadab's house—Abinadab being the man who lived on the hill—Ahio walked ahead of the Ark.

verses.latin: Porro David et omnis Israël ludebant coram Domino in omnibus lignis fabrefactis, et citharis, et lyris, et tympanis, et sistris, et cymbalis.
verses.english: Meanwhile, King David and all Israel were joyfully celebrating before the Lord with all kinds of musical instruments made of fir wood: with harps, lyres, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.

verses.latin: Postquam autem venerunt ad aream Nachon, extendit Oza manum ad arcam Dei, et tenuit eam: quoniam calcitrabant boves, et declinaverant eam.
verses.english: But when they arrived at the threshing floor of Nachon, Uzzah reached out his hand to the Ark of God and took hold of it, because the oxen stumbled and had nearly overturned it.

verses.latin: Iratusque est Dominus contra Ozam, et percussit eum ibi propter temeritatem suam: qui mortuus est ibi juxta arcam Dei.
verses.english: And the Lord became angry with Uzzah, and He struck him down there for his rash irreverence. So Uzzah died there beside the Ark of God.

verses.latin: Contristatusque est David eo quod percussiisset Dominus Ozam: et vocavit locum illum, Percussio Ozæ, usque in præsentem diem.
verses.english: David was saddened because the Lord had struck Uzzah in this way. And he named that place 'The Striking of Uzzah,' a name it holds even to this present day.

verses.latin: Et pertimuit David Dominum in die illa dicens: Quomodo ingredietur arca Domini ad me?
verses.english: David then greatly feared the Lord on that day, saying: "How can the Ark of the Lord possibly come to me now?"

verses.latin: Et noluit transducere ad se arcam Domini in civitatem David: sed divertit eam in domum Obededom Gethæi.
verses.english: And David decided not to bring the Ark of the Lord into the City of David for himself. Instead, he diverted it to the house of Obed-Edom, the Gittite.

verses.latin: Mansit ergo arca Domini in domo Obededom Gethæi tribus mensibus: et benedixit Dominus Obededom, et omnem domum ejus.
verses.english: So the Ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obed-Edom, the Gittite, for three months. And the Lord blessed Obed-Edom and his entire household.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est regi David, dicentibus: Benedixit Dominus Obededom, et omnia ejus, propter arcam Dei. Abiit ergo David, et adduxit arcam Dei de domo Obededom in civitatem David cum gaudio.
verses.english: It was reported to King David, with people saying: "The Lord has blessed Obed-Edom and all that belongs to him because of the Ark of God." So David went, and he brought the Ark of God from the house of Obed-Edom into the City of David with great joy.

verses.latin: Et cum salissent qui portabant arcam Domini sex passus, immolabant bovem et arietem.
verses.english: And when those who were carrying the Ark of the Lord had taken six steps, they sacrificed an ox and a ram as offerings to God.

verses.latin: Et David saltabat totis viribus ante Dominum: porro David erat accinctus ephod lineo.
verses.english: And David was dancing with all his might before the Lord. King David was dressed only in a linen ephod, a priestly garment.

verses.latin: Et David et omnis domus Israël ducebant arcam fœderis Domini in jubilo, et in clangore buccinæ.
verses.english: So David and all the house of Israel brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord into Jerusalem with joyful shouting and the blast of the trumpet.

verses.latin: Cumque intraret arca Domini in civitatem David, Michol filia Saul prospiciens per fenestram, vidit regem David subsilientem atque saltantem coram Domino: et despexit eum in corde suo.
verses.english: And when the Ark of the Lord entered the City of David, Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out through a window. She saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised him in her heart for his undignified behavior.

verses.latin: Et intulerunt arcam Domini, et posuerunt eam in loco suo in medio tabernaculi, quod tetenderat ei David: et obtulit David holocausta coram Domino, et pacifica.
verses.english: They brought the Ark of the Lord inside and placed it in its designated spot, in the middle of the tent that David had pitched for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.

verses.latin: Cumque complesset David offerens holocausta, et pacifica, benedixit populo in nomine Domini exercituum.
verses.english: When David had finished offering the burnt offerings and the peace offerings, he blessed the people in the Name of the Lord of all Creation.

verses.latin: Et divisit universæ multitudini Israël, tam viris quam mulieribus, singulis collyridam panis, et assaturam bubulæ carnis, et frixam oleo: et abiit universus populus unusquisque in domum suam.
verses.english: Then he distributed to all the multitude of Israel, to both men and women, a loaf of bread, a portion of roasted meat, and a cake fried in oil to each person. And all the people departed, each to their own home.

verses.latin: Reversusque est David ut benediceret domui suæ: et egressa Michol filia Saul in occursum David, ait: Quam gloriosus fuit hodie rex Israël, discopertus ante ancillas servorum suorum, et nudatus est quasi si nudetur unus de nugatoribus.
verses.english: Then David returned to bless his own household. And Michal, Saul's daughter, came out to meet David and said: "How glorious the King of Israel made himself today! He exposed himself before the servant girls of his own servants, uncovering himself just as a vulgar fellow might shamelessly uncover himself!"

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Michol: Ante Dominum qui elegit me potius quam patrem tuum, et quam omnem domum ejus, et præcepit mihi ut essem dux super populum Domini in Israël, et ludam et humiliabor coram Domino.
verses.english: And David said to Michal: "I was dancing before the Lord—the One who chose me rather than your father and rather than his entire house, and who commanded me to be a leader over the Lord's people in Israel. I will continue to celebrate and humble myself before the Lord!"

verses.latin: Et humiliabor magis quam antea, et ero humilis in oculis meis: et cum ancillis de quibus locuta es, glorificabor.
verses.english: I will even humble myself more than I did today, and I will be lowly in my own estimation. Yet, I will be held in honor by these very servant girls about whom you have spoken so scornfully.

verses.latin: Igitur Michol filiæ Saul non est natus filius usque in diem mortis suæ.
verses.english: Therefore, Michal, Saul's daughter, had no child until the day of her death.

verses.latin: Congregavit igitur rursum David omnes electos ex Israël triginta millia.
verses.english: David gathered again all the chosen men from Israel—30,000 men in total.

verses.latin: Et surrexit, et abiit David, et omnis populus qui erat cum eo de viris Juda, ut adducerent arcam Dei, super quam invocatum est nomen Domini exercituum, sedentis super Cherubim in ea.
verses.english: And David arose and went with all the people who were with him, from the men of Judah, to bring up the Ark of God from that place. The Ark of God is the sacred object upon which the Most Holy Name of the Lord of armies is invoked, who is enthroned above the Cherubim on it.

verses.latin: Et imposuerunt arcam Dei super plaustrum novum: et tulerunt eam de domo Abinadab, quæ erat in Gabaa: Oza et Ahio filii Abinadab minabant plaustrum novum.
verses.english: And they placed the Ark of God upon a new cart. Then they took it from the house of Abinadab, which was in Gibeah. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, drove the new cart.

verses.latin: Et cum tulissent eam de domo Abinadab, quæ erat in Gabaa, Ahio præcedebat arcam.
verses.english: And when they had taken it from the house of Abinadab, which was in Gibeah, Ahio walked in front of the Ark.

verses.latin: David autem et omnis Israël ludebant coram Domino in omnibus lignis fabrefactis, et citharis, et lyris, et tympanis, et sistris, et cymbalis.
verses.english: But David and all of Israel were celebrating before the Lord with all sorts of instruments made of wood: harps, lyres, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.

verses.latin: Postquam venerunt ad aream Nachon, extendit Oza manum suam ad arcam Dei, et tenuit eam: quoniam calcitrabant boves, et declinaverunt in hanc et in illam partem.
verses.english: After they reached Nachon's threshing floor, the oxen stumbled and turned aside. So Uzzah stretched out his hand to the Ark of God and took hold of it to steady it.

verses.latin: Iratusque est Dominus contra Ozam, et percussit eum super temeritate sua: qui mortuus est ibi juxta arcam Dei.
verses.english: And the Lord was angry against Uzzah, and struck him for his rashness—touching the sacred Ark was forbidden—and he died there beside the Ark of God.

verses.latin: Contristatusque est David eo quod percussisset Dominus Ozam: et vocatum est nomen loci illius, Percussio Ozæ, usque in præsentem diem.
verses.english: And David was saddened because the Lord had struck Uzzah, and the name of that place has been called The Striking of Uzzah until the present day.

verses.latin: Et pertimuit David Dominum in die illa dicens: Quomodo ingredietur arca Domini ad me?
verses.english: And David was filled with reverential fear for the Lord that day, saying, 'How shall the Ark of the Lord come to me?'

verses.latin: Et noluit introferre arcam Domini ad se in civitatem David: sed divertit eam in domum Obededom Gethæi.
verses.english: And he did not want to bring the Ark of the Lord to himself into the City of David, but diverted it to the house of Obededom the Gittite.

verses.latin: Mansit ergo arca Domini in domo Obededom Gethæi tribus mensibus: et benedixit Dominus Obededom, et omnem domum ejus.
verses.english: Therefore, the Ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obededom the Gittite for three months, and the Lord bestowed blessings upon Obededom and all his household.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est regi David, dicentibus ei: Benedixit Dominus Obededom, et omnia ejus, propter arcam Dei. Abiit ergo David, et adduxit arcam Domini de domo Obededom in civitatem David cum gaudio.
verses.english: And it was reported to King David, saying to him, 'The Lord has bestowed blessings upon Obededom and all his possessions because of the Ark of God.' So David went up and brought the Ark of the Lord from the house of Obededom into the City of David with joy.

verses.latin: Et cum spatium sex passuum complessent qui portabant arcam Domini, immolabant bovem et arietem.
verses.english: And when those who carried the Ark of the Lord had completed a space of six steps, they offered a bull and a ram as sacrifices—a ritual of purification and dedication.

verses.latin: Et David saltabat totis viribus ante Dominum: Davidque erat accinctus ephod lineo.
verses.english: And David was dancing with great fervor before the Lord in worship. David was wearing a linen ephod, a priestly garment.

verses.latin: Et universus Israël deducebant arcam fœderis Domini in jubilo, et in clangore buccinae.
verses.english: And all of Israel was bringing up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord with joyful shouts and with the sound of the trumpet.

verses.latin: Cumque intraret arca Domini in civitatem David, Michol filia Saul prospiciens per fenestram, vidit regem David saltabat atque ludebat: et despexit eum in corde suo.
verses.english: And when the Ark of the Lord came into the City of David, Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out through a window. She saw King David dancing and celebrating, and she scorned him in her heart.

verses.latin: Et introduxerunt arcam Domini, et statuerunt eam in loco suo in medio tabernaculi, quod tetenderat ei David: et obtulit David holocausta coram Domino, et pacifica.
verses.english: And they brought in the Ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it. And David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.

verses.latin: Cumque complesset offerens holocausta, et pacifica, benedixit populo in nomine Domini exercituum.
verses.english: And when he had finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he invoked blessings upon the people in the name of the Lord of armies.

verses.latin: Et divisit universæ multitudini Israël, tam viris quam mulieribus, singulis tortam panis, et assaturam bubulæ carnis, et frixam oleo: et abiit omnis populus unusquisque in domum suam.
verses.english: And he distributed to the entire multitude of Israel, to both men and women, to each a loaf of bread, a portion of roasted beef, and a fried cake made with oil. Then all the people went, each to his own house.

verses.latin: Reversusque est David ut benediceret domui suæ: et egressa Michol filia Saul in occursum David, ait: Quam gloriosus fuit hodie rex Israël, denudatus ante ancillas servorum suorum, quasi si denudetur unus de scurris.
verses.english: And David returned to bless his household. Michal, Saul's daughter, came out to meet David and said sarcastically, 'How splendid the king of Israel was today! He uncovered himself before the servant girls of his servants, as a common jester might uncover himself!'

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Michol: Ante Dominum, qui elegit me potius quam patrem tuum, et quam omnem domum ejus, et præcepit mihi ut essem dux super populum Domini in Israël, et ludam et exsultabo et humiliabor ante Dominum.
verses.english: And David said to Michal, 'I was celebrating before the Lord! It was the Lord who chose me instead of your father and all his house. He commanded me to be a leader over the people of the Lord in Israel. Therefore, I will celebrate and rejoice and humble myself before the Lord.'

verses.latin: Et humiliabor magis quam ante, et ero humilis in oculis meis: et cum ancillis de quibus locuta es, glorificabor.
verses.english: 'And I will humble myself even more than before, and I will be humble in my own eyes. And as for the servant girls about whom you spoke, I will be held in honor by them.'

verses.latin: Igitur Michol filiæ Saul non est natus filius usque in diem mortis suæ.
verses.english: Therefore, Michal, Saul's daughter, had no child until the day of her death.

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum sedisset rex in domo sua, et Dominus dedisset ei requiem undique ab universis inimicis suis, qui in circuitu erant:
verses.english: It happened that the king was finally settled in his own home, and the Lord had given him peace and rest from all the enemies surrounding him from every side.

verses.latin: dixit ad Nathan prophetam: Vides quoniam ego habito in domo cedrina, et arca Dei posita est in medio pellium.
verses.english: He said to Nathan the prophet: 'Do you not see that I, David, live in a magnificent palace built with cedar wood, while the Ark of God still resides within mere tent fabrics?'

verses.latin: Et ait Nathan ad regem: Vade, fac omnia quæ sunt in corde tuo: quia Dominus tecum est.
verses.english: Nathan replied to the king, 'Go ahead and do whatever is in your heart, for the Lord God is truly with you.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem in nocte illa, et ecce sermo Domini ad Nathan, dicens:
verses.english: However, that very night, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:

verses.latin: Vade, et loquere ad servum meum David: Hæc dicit Dominus: Numquid tu ædificabis mihi domum ad habitandum?
verses.english: 'Go and say to My servant David: “Thus says the Lord God: Is it truly you who will build a house for Me to dwell in?

verses.latin: quoniam non habitavi in domo ex die qua eduxi filios Israël de terra Ægypti usque in diem hanc, sed ambulavi in tabernaculo, et in tentorio.
verses.english: For I have not lived in a permanent house since the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day. Instead, I have moved around with them, dwelling in a tabernacle and a tent.

verses.latin: Per omnia loca quæ transivi cum omnibus filiis Israël, numquid loquens locutus sum ad unum de tribubus Israël, cui præcepi ut pasceret populum meum Israël, dicens: Quare non ædificastis mihi domum cedrinam?
verses.english: Throughout all the places where I have traveled with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a single word to any of the tribal leaders of Israel—whom I appointed to shepherd My people, Israel—saying, 'Why have you not built Me a house of cedar?'

verses.latin: Et nunc hæc dices servo meo David: Hæc dicit Dominus exercituum: Ego tuli te de pascuis sequentem greges, ut esses dux super populum meum Israël:
verses.english: Therefore, now, you shall say this to My servant David: 'Thus says the Lord, God of all heavenly powers: I Myself took you from the pastures, where you were following the sheep, to be a prince and leader over My people Israel.

verses.latin: et fui tecum in omnibus ubicumque ambulasti, et interfeci universos inimicos tuos a facie tua: et feci tibi nomen grande, juxta nomen magnorum qui sunt in terra.
verses.english: And I have been with you in every place you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. I have made your name great, like the names of the most powerful and famous rulers on the earth.

verses.latin: Et ponam locum populo meo Israël, et plantabo eum, et habitabit sub eo, et non turbabitur ultra: neque addent ultra filii iniquitatis ut affligant eum, sicut a principio,
verses.english: I will also provide a secure place for My people Israel and establish them there, so that they will live in their own land and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people will not oppress them again, as they did from the beginning,

verses.latin: ex die qua constitui judices super populum meum Israël: et requiem dabo tibi ab omnibus inimicis tuis. Prædicitque tibi Dominus, quod domum faciat tibi Dominus.
verses.english: this will be from the time I appointed judges over My people Israel. Furthermore, I will give you rest from all your enemies. And the Lord reveals to you that He Himself will build you a house — a dynasty, a lasting lineage.

verses.latin: Cumque completi fuerint dies tui, et dormieris cum patribus tuis, suscitabo semen tuum post te, quod egredietur de utero tuo, et firmabo regnum ejus.
verses.english: When your life's days are complete, and you go to rest with your ancestors in death, I will raise up your offspring after you—one who will come from your own body—and I will firmly establish his kingdom.

verses.latin: Ipse ædificabit domum nomini meo: et firmabo thronum regni ejus usque in sempiternum.
verses.english: He, your son, is the one who will build a physical house — a Temple — for My name, a place where My presence and glory will be honored. And I will establish the throne of his kingdom, confirming it forever.

verses.latin: Ego ero illi in patrem, et ipse erit mihi in filium: qui si inique aliquid gesserit, arguam eum in virga virorum, et in plagis filiorum hominum.
verses.english: I will be a Father to him, and he will be My son. If he commits any iniquity, I will correct him with the rod and punishment fitting for human beings, to bring him back to righteousness.

verses.latin: Misericordia autem mea non auferetur ab eo, sicut abstuli a Saul, quem amovi a facie mea.
verses.english: But My mercy and steadfast love will not be taken away from him, unlike what happened with Saul, whom I removed from My presence as king.

verses.latin: Et fidelis erit domus tua, et regnum tuum usque in æternum ante faciem meam: et thronus tuus erit stabilis imperpetuum.
verses.english: Your dynastic house and your kingdom will endure before Me eternally, and your royal throne will be firmly established forever and ever.

verses.latin: Juxta omnia verba hæc, et juxta omnem visionem hanc, sic locutus est Nathan ad David.
verses.english: According to all these words and this entire vision, Nathan then spoke to David.

verses.latin: Ingressus est autem rex David, et sedit coram Domino, et dixit: Quis ego sum, Domine Deus, et quæ domus mea, ut ad hunc modum adduxeris me?
verses.english: Then King David went into the Lord’s presence, sat down before Him, and said, 'Who am I, Lord God, and what is my household, that You have brought me to such a high and honorable position?'

verses.latin: Sed et hoc parum visum est in conspectu tuo, Domine Deus, nisi etiam super domum servi tui loquereris in longum: ista est enim lex Adæ, Domine Deus.
verses.english: Yet even this, Lord God, seemed too little in Your sight, for You have also spoken about the future of Your servant’s house for generations to come. This is indeed the profound and lasting destiny You have decreed for mankind, O Lord God.

verses.latin: Quid ergo addere poterit David, ut loquatur ad te? tu enim scis, Domine Deus, servum tuum.
verses.english: What more can David say to You, Lord God, in addition to this? For You, Lord God, know Your servant intimately.

verses.latin: Propter verbum tuum, et juxta cor tuum fecisti omnia magnalia hæc, ita ut notum faceres servo tuo.
verses.english: It is because of Your word and according to Your own heart’s desire that You have done all these magnificent things, and have made them known to Your servant.

verses.latin: Idcirco magnificatus es, Domine Deus, quia non est similis tui, neque est Deus absque te, in omnibus quæ audivimus auribus nostris.
verses.english: For this reason, You are truly great, O Lord God! There is no one like You, and there is no God apart from You, according to all that we have heard with our own ears throughout history.

verses.latin: Quæ est autem alia gens in terra sicut populus tuus Israël, quem abiisti ut redimeres tibi in populum, et poneres tibi nomen, et faceres ei magnalia, et horribilia super terram, a facie gentium tuarum quas redemisti tibi ex Ægypto?
verses.english: And what other nation on earth is like Your people Israel, whom You went out to redeem for Yourself as Your own special people, to make a glorious name for Yourself? You performed magnificent and awe-inspiring deeds for them on the earth, by redeeming Your own people out of Egypt, demonstrating Your power before other nations who witnessed it.

verses.latin: Et firmasti tibi populum tuum Israël in populum æternum: et tu, Domine Deus, factus es eis in Deum.
verses.english: For You have established Your people Israel for Yourself as a people to endure eternally, and You, Lord God, have truly become their God.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, Domine Deus, verbum quod locutus es super servum tuum, et super domum ejus, suscita in sempiternum: et fac sicut locutus es.
verses.english: Now, therefore, Lord God, confirm the word that You have spoken concerning Your servant and concerning his dynastic house, and make it stand firm eternally; indeed, do as You have spoken.

verses.latin: Ut magnificetur nomen tuum usque in sempiternum, dicentium: Dominus exercituum, Deus super Israël. Et domus servi tui David, sit stabilis coram te.
verses.english: So that Your name may be magnified eternally, and people will say, 'The Lord, God of all heavenly powers, is truly God over Israel!' And may the dynastic house of Your servant David remain stable and enduring before You.

verses.latin: Quoniam tu, Domine exercituum, Deus Israël, revelasti aurem servi tui, dicens: Domum ædificabo tibi. Propter hoc invenit servus tuus cor suum ut oraret te oratione hac.
verses.english: For You, Lord God of all heavenly powers, God of Israel, have revealed to Your servant’s hearing, saying, 'I Myself will build you a dynastic house.' Because of this assurance, Your servant has found the confidence in his heart to pray this prayer to You.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, Domine Deus, tu es Deus, et verba tua erunt vera: tu locutus es ad servum tuum bona hæc.
verses.english: And now, Lord God, You are God indeed, and Your words are true and faithful. You Yourself have spoken these good promises to Your servant.

verses.latin: Incipe ergo, et benedic domui servi tui, ut sit in sempiternum coram te: quia tu, Domine Deus, locutus es, et benedictione tua benedicetur domus servi tui in sempiternum.
verses.english: Therefore, now begin and bless the dynastic house of Your servant, so that it may continue eternally before You. For You, Lord God, have spoken it, and with Your blessing, the dynastic house of Your servant will indeed be blessed forever and ever.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum sedisset rex in domo sua, et Dominus dedisset ei requiem undique ab universis inimicis suis, quos adversarios habebat,
verses.english: It happened when King David had settled in his own house, and the Lord had given him rest on every side from all his enemies, those who were his adversaries—

verses.latin: dixit ad Nathan prophetam: Vides quoniam ego habito in domo cedrina, et arca Dei posita est in medio pellium.
verses.english: he said to Nathan the prophet: “You see that I live in a house built of cedar wood, but the Ark of God is placed only in the midst of curtains—meaning, a tent.”

verses.latin: Dixitque Nathan ad regem: Omne quod est in corde tuo, vade et fac: quia Dominus tecum est.
verses.english: And Nathan said to the king: “Everything that is in your heart to do, go and do it, because the Lord is with you.”

verses.latin: Factum est autem in nocte illa, et ecce sermo Domini ad Nathan, dicens:
verses.english: However, on that very night, behold, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:

verses.latin: Vade, et loquere ad servum meum David: Hæc dicit Dominus: Numquid tu ædificabis mihi domum ad habitandum?
verses.english: “Go, and speak to my servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord: Is it you who will build me a house to dwell in?’

verses.latin: Neque enim habitavi in domo ex die qua eduxi filios Israël de terra Ægypti usque in diem hanc: sed ambulavi in tabernaculo, et in tentorio.
verses.english: For I have not dwelt in a fixed house from the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day: instead, I have walked about in a tabernacle, and in a tent.

verses.latin: Per cuncta loca quæ transivi cum omnibus filiis Israël, numquid loquens locutus sum ad unam de tribubus Israël, cui præcepi ut pasceret populum meum Israël, dicens: Quare non ædificastis mihi domum cedrinam?
verses.english: Through all the places I have passed with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak to any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying: ‘Why have you not built me a house of cedar?’

verses.latin: Et nunc hæc dices servo meo David: Hæc dicit Dominus exercituum: Ego tuli te de pascuis, sequentem greges, ut esses dux super populum meum Israël:
verses.english: And now, you shall say these things to my servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord of armies: I took you from the pastures, following the flocks, so that you would be a leader over my people Israel:

verses.latin: et fui tecum in omnibus ubicumque ambulasti, et interfeci universos inimicos tuos a facie tua: fecique tibi nomen grande, juxta nomen magnorum qui sunt in terra.
verses.english: and I have been with you in everything, wherever you have walked, and I have cut off all your enemies from before your face. And I have made for you a great name, like the name of the great ones who are on the earth.

verses.latin: Et ponam locum populo meo Israël, et plantabo eum, et habitabit sub eo, et non turbabitur amplius: nec addent ultra filii iniquitatis affligere eum, sicut a principio,
verses.english: And I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them there, and they will dwell under it, and they will no longer be disturbed. Nor will the children of iniquity continue to afflict them, as from the beginning—

verses.latin: ex die qua constitui judices super populum meum Israël: et requiem dabo tibi ab omnibus inimicis tuis. Prædicitque tibi Dominus quod domum faciat tibi Dominus.
verses.english: from the day I appointed judges over my people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies. Furthermore, the Lord declares to you that the Lord himself will make a house—a dynasty—for you.

verses.latin: Cumque completi fuerint dies tui, et dormieris cum patribus tuis, suscitabo semen tuum post te, quod egredietur de utero tuo, et firmabo regnum ejus.
verses.english: And when your days are completed, and you sleep with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you, who will come forth from your body, and I will establish his kingdom.

verses.latin: Ipse ædificabit domum nomini meo: et firmabo solium regni ejus usque in sempiternum.
verses.english: He himself will build a house—the Temple—for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.

verses.latin: Ego ero ei in patrem, et ipse erit mihi in filium: qui si inique aliquid gesserit, arguam eum in virga virorum, et in plagis filiorum hominum.
verses.english: I will be a father to him, and he will be a son to me. If he does anything wickedly, I will correct him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men.

verses.latin: Misericordiam autem meam non auferam ab eo, sicut abstuli a Saul, quem abstuli a facie mea.
verses.english: But my mercy I will not take away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I took away from before my face.

verses.latin: Et fidelis erit domus tua, et regnum tuum usque in æternum ante faciem tuam: et solium tuum erit firmum jugiter.
verses.english: And your house will be faithful, and your kingdom will endure forever before you, and your throne will be firm perpetually—this promise is fulfilled in your descendant, Christ the Lord.

verses.latin: Juxta omnia verba hæc, et juxta omnem visionem hanc, sic locutus est Nathan ad David.
verses.english: According to all these words, and according to all this vision, thus Nathan spoke to David.

verses.latin: Ingressus est autem rex David, et sedit coram Domino, et dixit: Quis ego sum, Domine Deus, et quæ domus mea, ut ad tantum me adduxeris?
verses.english: Then King David entered and sat before the Lord, and said: “Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house, that you have brought me to such a greatness?

verses.latin: Sed et hoc parvum et conspectu tuo, Domine Deus, nisi etiam locutus sis super domum servi tui in longinquum: ista est enim lex Adæ, Domine Deus.
verses.english: But even this is small in your sight, O Lord God, unless you have also spoken concerning the house of your servant for a long time to come—into eternity. For this is the law of Adam, O Lord God—a universal and enduring decree for humanity.

verses.latin: Quid ergo addere poterit David, ut loquatur ad te? tu enim scis, Domine Deus, servum tuum.
verses.english: What more then can David add, that he should speak to you? For you know your servant, O Lord God.

verses.latin: Propter verbum tuum, et juxta cor tuum fecisti omnia magnalia hæc, ita ut notum faceres servo tuo.
verses.english: Because of your word, and according to your own heart, you have done all these great things, so that you might make them known to your servant.

verses.latin: Propterea magnificatus es, Domine Deus, quia non est similis tui, neque est Deus absque te, in omnibus quæ audivimus auribus nostris.
verses.english: Therefore you are magnified, O Lord God, because there is no one like you, nor is there any God besides you, in all that we have heard with our own ears.

verses.latin: Quæ est autem alia gens in terra sicut populus tuus Israël, quem ivisti redimere tibi in populum, et ponere tibi nomen, facereque illis magnalia et horribilia super terram, a facie gentium tuarum quas redemisti tibi ex Ægypto?
verses.english: And what other nation on earth is like your people Israel, whom you went to redeem for yourself as a people, and to establish for yourself a name, and to do for them great and terrible things on the earth, from before the nations you redeemed for yourself out of Egypt?

verses.latin: Et firmasti tibi populum tuum Israël in populum sempiternum: et tu, Domine Deus, factus es eis in Deum.
verses.english: And you have established for yourself your people Israel as an eternal people, and you, O Lord God, have become their God.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, Domine Deus, verbum quod locutus es super servum tuum, et super domum ejus, suscita in sempiternum: et fac sicut locutus es.
verses.english: Now therefore, O Lord God, the word which you have spoken concerning your servant, and concerning his house, raise it up forever, and do as you have spoken.

verses.latin: Ut magnificetur nomen tuum usque in sempiternum, dicentibus: Dominus exercituum Deus super Israël. Et domus servi tui David erit stabilis coram te.
verses.english: So that your name may be magnified forever, with people saying: 'The Lord of armies is God over Israel.' And the house of your servant David will be stable before you.

verses.latin: Quoniam tu, Domine exercituum Deus Israël, revelasti aure servi tui, dicens: Domum ædificabo tibi: propterea invenit servus tuus cor suum ut oraret te oratione hac.
verses.english: Because you, O Lord of armies, God of Israel, have revealed in the ear of your servant, saying: ‘I will build a house—a dynasty—for you,’ therefore your servant has found it in his heart to pray this prayer to you.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, Domine Deus, tu es Deus, et verba tua erunt vera: tu locutus es ad servum tuum bona hæc.
verses.english: Now therefore, O Lord God, you are God, and your words will be true. You have spoken these good things to your servant.

verses.latin: Incipe ergo, et benedic domui servi tui, ut sit in sempiternum coram te: quia tu, Domine Deus, locutus es, et benedictione tua benedicetur domus servi tui in sempiternum.
verses.english: Begin therefore, and bless the house of your servant, that it may be forever before you. Because you, O Lord God, have spoken, and with your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.

verses.latin: Et factum est post haec, percussit David Philisthaeos, et humiliavit eos: et tulit David frenum tributi de manu Philisthaeorum.
verses.english: After these events, David waged war against the Philistines, defeating them and humbling their power. David seized control over their chief city, making them subject to his rule and compelling them to pay tribute.

verses.latin: Et factum est post haec, percussit David Philisthaeos, et humiliavit eos: et tulit David frenum tributi de manu Geth, et a finibus ejus.
verses.english: After these events, David attacked the Philistines and utterly subdued them. David then took what the Latin calls 'the bridle of tribute' from Gath, meaning he seized control of this principal Philistine city and its surrounding territories, forcing them into submission and tribute.

verses.latin: Et percussit Moab, et mensus est eos funiculo, coæquans eos terræ: et occidit duos funiculos, unum adducens ad vitam: factusque est Moab David serviens sub tributo.
verses.english: David also attacked the Moabites, subjecting them to a severe judgment. He measured them out with a rope, as if laying them flat on the ground for execution. He put two-thirds of them to death, sparing only one-third. Thus, Moab became servants of David, compelled to pay him tribute.

verses.latin: Et percussit David Adarezer filium Rohob regem Soba, cum pergeret ut dominaretur super flumen Euphraten.
verses.english: David also struck Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, who was the king of Zobah. This happened when Hadadezer was on an expedition to extend his dominion all the way to the Euphrates River.

verses.latin: Et captis David ex ejus equitatu mille septingentis equitibus, et viginti millibus peditum, subnervavit omnes equos curruum: et reservavit ex his centum currus.
verses.english: David captured a vast military force from Hadadezer: seventeen hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. As a tactical move to prevent their future use in warfare against him, David then crippled all the horses intended for chariots by cutting their leg tendons, except for those needed for one hundred chariots, which he kept.

verses.latin: Supervenit quoque Syria Damasci, ut auxilium præberet Adarezer regi Soba: et percussit David de Syria viginti duo millia virorum.
verses.english: The Syrians from Damascus also came to help Hadadezer, the king of Zobah. But David defeated them too, striking down twenty-two thousand Syrian soldiers.

verses.latin: Et posuit David præsidium in Syria Damasci: factaque est Syria David serviens sub tributo. Et adjuvit Dominus David in omnibus ad quæcumque profectus est.
verses.english: David then established garrisons throughout the region of Damascus in Syria. As a result, Syria became subject to David, obligated to pay him tribute. The Lord God assisted David in every endeavor he undertook.

verses.latin: Et tulit David arma aurea, quæ habuerant servi Adarezer, et detulit ea in Jerusalem.
verses.english: David also took the golden shields that belonged to Hadadezer’s royal officers, and he brought these valuable spoils of war back to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Et de Bete et de Beroth urbibus Adarezer, tulit rex David æs multum nimis.
verses.english: From Betah and Beroth, which were cities belonging to Hadadezer, King David seized a vast quantity of bronze.

verses.latin: Audivit autem Thoü rex Emath, quod percussisset David omnem exercitum Adarezer.
verses.english: Then Tou, the king of Hamath, heard the news that David had defeated Hadadezer’s entire army.

verses.latin: Et misit Thoü Joram filium suum ad regem David, ut salutaret eum, et congratularetur ei, et gratias ageret: pro eo quod pugnasset contra Adarezer, et percussisset eum. Hostis quippe erat Thoü Adarezer, et in manu ejus erant vasa argentea, et vasa aurea, et vasa ærea.
verses.english: King Tou then sent his son, Joram, to King David. Joram’s mission was to offer a formal greeting, to congratulate David on his victory, and to express gratitude because David had fought against and defeated Hadadezer. This was a significant act, as King Tou was an enemy of Hadadezer. Joram also brought gifts of silver, gold, and bronze vessels for David.

verses.latin: Sed et hæc sanctificavit rex David Domino, cum argento et auro, quæ sacraverat de universis gentibus, quas subegerat:
verses.english: King David consecrated these gifts, along with all the silver and gold he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued, to the Lord. This act of sanctification meant they were set aside for sacred use in the service of God.

verses.latin: De Syria, et Moab, et filiis Ammon, et Philisthiim, et Amalec, et de spoliis Adarezer filii Rohob regis Soba.
verses.english: These consecrated offerings came from the spoils taken from Syria, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and the Amalekites. They also included the spoils from Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah.

verses.latin: Fecit quoque sibi David nomen, cum reverteretur percussa Syria in valle salinarum, duodecim millia.
verses.english: David also gained great renown for himself when he returned from defeating twelve thousand enemies in the Valley of Salt. Although the Latin text says 'Syria,' this victory most likely refers to his conquest of Edom in that southern region, a battle where he struck down twelve thousand.

verses.latin: Et posuit in Idumæa custodes, statimque facta est omnis Idumæa serviens David: et adjuvit Dominus David in omnibus ad quæcumque profectus est.
verses.english: David then established garrisons throughout Idumea, also known as Edom, and as a result, the entire region of Idumea became completely subject to David. And, as before, the Lord God assisted David in every endeavor he undertook.

verses.latin: Et regnavit David super omnem Israël: et faciebat David judicium et justitiam omni populo suo.
verses.english: So David reigned as king over all of Israel, and he administered fair judgment and righteousness to all of his people.

verses.latin: Joab autem filius Sarviæ erat super exercitum: et Josaphat filius Ahilud, cancellarius.
verses.english: Now, Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the commander of David’s army. And Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, served as the royal chronicler, responsible for keeping all official records.

verses.latin: Et Sadoc filius Achitob, et Achimelech filius Abiathar, sacerdotes: et Saraias scriba.
verses.english: Zadok, the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, the son of Abiathar, served as the principal priests. Seraiah was the royal secretary, handling official correspondence and state affairs.

verses.latin: Banaias quoque filius Jojadæ super Cerethi et Phelethi: et filii David erant sacerdotes.
verses.english: Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and Pelethites, who were David’s personal elite guard. And David’s sons themselves held high office as royal ministers, called 'priests' in this context, indicating their sacred and prominent role in the kingdom.

verses.latin: Dixit autem David: Numquid derelictus est aliquis de domo Saul, ut faciam cum eo misericordiam propter Jonathan?
verses.english: Now David said, "Is there anyone left from the royal house of Saul, so that I may show kindness to him—fulfilling my covenant with Jonathan?"

verses.latin: Erat autem de domo Saul servus nomine Siba: quem cum vocasset rex ad se, dixit ei: Tune es Siba? Et ille respondit: Ego servus tuus.
verses.english: Now there was a servant from Saul's household, named Ziba. When the king called him, David asked, "Are you Ziba?" And he replied, "I am your servant."

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Numquid superest quisquam de domo Saul, ut faciam ei misericordiam Dei? Dixitque Siba regi: Superest filius Jonathae, claudus pedibus.
verses.english: And the king asked, "Is there still anyone left from the house of Saul, that I may show him the kindness of God's covenant?" Ziba then said to the king, "Yes, there is still a son of Jonathan alive, but he is lame in both his feet."

verses.latin: Ubi, inquit, est? Et Siba respondit: Ecce in domo Machir filii Ammiel in Lodabar.
verses.english: David then asked, "Where is he?" And Ziba replied, "Behold, he is in the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lo-debar."

verses.latin: Misit ergo rex David, et tulit eum de domo Machir filii Ammiel de Lodabar.
verses.english: So King David sent messengers, and they brought him from the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar.

verses.latin: Cum autem venisset Meribbaal filius Jonathae filii Saul ad David, cecidit in faciem suam, et adoravit. Et dixit David: Meribbaal? Qui respondit: Ecce servus tuus.
verses.english: When Mephibosheth (also known as Meribbaal), the son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul, came to David, he fell on his face and paid homage. And David said, "Mephibosheth?" He replied, "Behold, I am your servant."

verses.latin: Et ait ei David: Ne timeas, quia faciens faciam tecum misericordiam propter Jonathan patrem tuum, et restituam tibi omnes agros Saul patris tui, et tu comedes panem in mensa mea semper.
verses.english: And David said to him, "Do not fear, for I will most certainly show you great kindness for the sake of Jonathan, your father. I will restore to you all the fields that belonged to Saul, your grandfather, and you shall always eat bread at my royal table."

verses.latin: Qui adorans se, ait: Quid est servus tuus, quia respexti ad canem mortuum similem mei?
verses.english: He prostrated himself again and said, "What is your servant, that you would show regard for a dead dog such as I am?"

verses.latin: Vocavit itaque rex Sibam servum Saul, et dixit ei: Omnia quaecumque fuerunt Saul, et omnis domus ejus, dedi filio patris tui.
verses.english: Then the king called Ziba, Saul's servant, and said to him, "Everything that belonged to Saul and his entire household, I have now given to your master's son—Mephibosheth."

verses.latin: Operare igitur ei terram, tu et filii tui et servi tui: et inferes domino tuo cibos, ut alatur: Meribbaal autem filius domini tui, comedet semper panem super mensam meam. Erat autem Sibae quindecim filii et viginti servi.
verses.english: "Therefore, you and your sons and your servants are to work the land for him. You shall bring in the produce so that your master's son may have food to eat and be provided for. Mephibosheth, your master's son, will always eat at my royal table." Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.

verses.latin: Dixitque Siba ad regem: Sicut jussisti domine mi rex, sic servus tuus faciet: et Meribbaal comedet super mensam tuam, quasi unus de filiis regis.
verses.english: Ziba said to the king, "Just as my lord the king has commanded, so your servant will do. Mephibosheth will eat at your table as one of the king's own sons."

verses.latin: Habebat autem Meribbaal filium parvulum nomine Micha: familia autem Sibae, servi erant Meribbaal.
verses.english: Now Mephibosheth had a young son named Micah. And all the household of Ziba became servants to Mephibosheth.

verses.latin: Porro Meribbaal habitabat in Jerusalem: quia de mensa regis jugiter comedebat: et erat claudus utraque pede.
verses.english: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king's table; and he was lame in both feet.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post hæc, ut mortuus esset rex Ammonitarum, et regnaret Hanon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: It happened after these events that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun began to reign in his place.

verses.latin: Dixitque David: Faciam misericordiam cum Hanon filio Naas, sicut fecit pater ejus mecum misericordiam. Misit ergo David consolatores, ut consolarentur eum super patre suo. Cumque venissent servi David in terram Ammonitarum,
verses.english: And David said, 'I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent messengers to console him over the death of his father. When David’s servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites,

verses.latin: dixerunt autem principes Ammon ad Hanon dominum suum: Putasne quod honorificans pater tuus, miserit ad te David consolatores, et non ut exploraret, et investigaret, et subverteret civitatem nostram?
verses.english: the princes of Ammon spoke to their lord Hanun: 'Do you really believe David has sent these comforters to you out of honor for your father? Is it not rather to spy out our city, to investigate its defenses, and to overthrow it?'

verses.latin: Tulit itaque Hanon servos David, et rasit media barba eorum, et præcidit vestimenta eorum usque ad nates in medio, et dimisit eos.
verses.english: So Hanun seized David’s servants, shaved off half of their beards, cut their outer garments off at the middle—up to their buttocks—and then sent them away in disgrace.

verses.latin: Cumque nuntiatum esset David, misit obviam eis (vir enim turpiter vexati erant) et præcepit dicens: Manete in Jericho donec crescat barba vestra, et tunc revertimini.
verses.english: When this news was reported to David, he sent people to meet them, because the men were greatly humiliated. And David commanded them, saying: 'Remain in Jericho until your beards have grown out, and then you may return.'

verses.latin: Videntes autem filii Ammon quod fecerant David, et quod fœtuisset eis, miserunt et conduxerunt de Syria Rohob, et de Syria Sobal viginti millia peditum, et a rege Maacha mille viros, et ab Istob duodecim millia virorum.
verses.english: But when the sons of Ammon realized what they had done to David and that they had made themselves utterly detestable to him, they sent and hired twenty thousand foot soldiers from Aram-Rehob and Aram-Zobah, one thousand men from the king of Maacah, and twelve thousand men from Ish-Tob.

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset David, misit Joab et omnem exercitum fortissimorum.
verses.english: When David heard this, he sent Joab and his entire army, which was made up of his most powerful warriors.

verses.latin: Egredientes ergo filii Ammon, direxerunt aciem ante portam. Syri autem Rohob, et Is Tob, et Maacha, et Sobal, separatim erant in campo.
verses.english: So the sons of Ammon came out and drew up their battle line at the entrance of the city gate. Meanwhile, the men of Aram-Rehob, Ish-Tob, Maacah, and Zobah were arrayed separately in the open field.

verses.latin: Videns igitur Joab quod utraque acies adversum se esset posita, et ante et post terga, elegit de universis electis Israël, et instruxit aciem contra Syros:
verses.english: When Joab saw that the battle lines were set against him both in front and behind, he chose some of the best men of Israel and arrayed them for battle against the Arameans.

verses.latin: reliquam autem partem exercitus dedit Abisai fratri suo, qui instruxit aciem adversum filios Ammon.
verses.english: He gave the rest of the army to his brother Abishai, who arrayed them in a battle line against the sons of Ammon.

verses.latin: Et ait: Si prævaluerint Syri adversum me, auxiliaberis mihi: si autem filii Ammon prævaluerint adversum te, auxiliabor tibi.
verses.english: And Joab said to Abishai: 'If the Arameans prove too strong for me, then you must come to my aid. But if the sons of Ammon prove too strong for you, then I will come to your aid.'

verses.latin: Confortare, et agamus viriliter pro populo nostro, et pro urbibus Dei nostri: Dominus autem faciet quod bonum in conspectu suo est.
verses.english: 'Be strong! Let us act courageously for our people and for the cities of our God. May the Lord do what is good in His sight.'

verses.latin: Accessit itaque Joab et populus qui cum eo erat, in prælium contra Syros: qui statim fugerunt a facie ejus.
verses.english: So Joab and the people with him advanced into battle against the Arameans, who immediately fled from his presence.

verses.latin: Filii autem Ammon videntes quod fugissent Syri, fugerunt et ipsi a facie Abisai, et ingressi sunt in civitatem. Reversusque est Joab a filiis Ammon, et venit Jerusalem.
verses.english: When the sons of Ammon saw that the Arameans had fled, they also fled from the presence of Abishai and retreated into their city. Then Joab returned from fighting the sons of Ammon and came to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Videntes igitur Syri quod cæciderant coram Israël, congregaverunt se in unum.
verses.english: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated before Israel, they gathered themselves together for a fresh assault.

verses.latin: Misitque Adarezer, et eduxit Syros qui erant trans flumen, et adduxit eorum principem Sobach, ducem exercitus Adarezer.
verses.english: Hadadezer then sent for help and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River, and he brought with them Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, to lead them.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est David, et congregans omnem Israël, transivit Jordanem, et venit in Helam: et direxerunt aciem Syri contra David, et pugnaverunt adversum eum.
verses.english: When this was reported to David, he gathered all of Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. The Arameans arrayed their battle lines against David and fought against him.

verses.latin: Fugeruntque Syri a facie Israël, et occidit David de Syris septingenta currus, et quadraginta millia equitum: et Sobach principem militiæ percussit, qui statim mortuus est.
verses.english: The Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand horsemen from among them. He also struck down Shobach, the commander of their army, who immediately died there.

verses.latin: Videntes autem universi reges, qui erant sub Adarezer, quod victi essent ab Israël, fecerunt pacem cum Israël, et servierunt eis: timueruntque Syri ultra juvare filios Ammon.
verses.english: When all the kings who were allies of Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became their servants. After this, the Arameans were afraid to help the sons of Ammon anymore.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post haec, ut moreretur rex filiorum Ammon, et regnaret Hanon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: Now it came to pass after these events, that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanon began to reign in his place.

verses.latin: Dixitque David: Faciam misericordiam cum Hanon filio Naas, sicut fecit pater ejus mecum misericordiam. Misit ergo David nuntios qui consolarentur eum super patre suo. Cumque venissent servi David in terram filiorum Ammon,
verses.english: And David said: 'I will show kindness to Hanon, the son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent messengers to comfort him concerning his father. But when David’s servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites,

verses.latin: dixerunt autem principes filiorum Ammon ad Hanon dominum suum: Putasne, quod propter honorem patris tui miserit David, qui consoletur te, et non ut exploraret, et investigaret, et subverteret civitatem nostram?
verses.english: the counselors of the Ammonites said to Hanon, their lord: 'Do you truly believe that David sent men to comfort you out of honor for your father? Or did he send them to spy out, to thoroughly search, and to overthrow our city?'

verses.latin: Tulit itaque Hanon servos David, rasitque dimidiam partem barbae eorum, et vestes eorum incisas ad nates usque media parte, dimisit.
verses.english: So Hanon took David's servants. He shaved off half of their beards and cut their garments in the middle, down to their buttocks, and then sent them away, inflicting deep shame upon them.

verses.latin: Cumque hoc nuntiatum esset David, misit obviam eis (erant enim viri confusi vehementer) et præcepit dicens: Manete in Jericho, donec crescat barba vestra, et tunc revertimini.
verses.english: And when this humiliating event was reported to David, he sent to meet them, because the men were greatly ashamed. He commanded them, saying: 'Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.'

verses.latin: Intellexerunt ergo filii Ammon quod contempti fuissent a David, et miserunt et conduxerunt de Syria Rohob, et de Syria Sobal, viginti millia peditum, et de rege Maacha mille viros, et de Istob duodecim millia virorum.
verses.english: Therefore, the Ammonites, realizing they had become utterly contemptible in David's eyes after their insult, sent and hired twenty thousand foot soldiers from Aram-Rehob and Aram-Zobah. They also hired a thousand men from the king of Maacah and twelve thousand men from Istob.

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset David, misit Joab, et universum exercitum fortium.
verses.english: When David heard this, he sent Joab and the entire army of his most valiant men.

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo filii Ammon, et instruxerunt aciem juxta introitum portæ: Syrus autem Sobal, et Rohob, et Istob, et Maacha, seorsum erant in campo.
verses.english: So the Ammonites went out and drew up their battle line at the entrance of their city gate. Meanwhile, the Arameans from Zobah, Rehob, Istob, and Maacah were positioned separately in the open field.

verses.latin: Videns igitur Joab quod utraque acies adversum se esset posita, et ante et retro, elegit ex omnibus viris fortissimis Israël, et instruxit aciem contra Syros.
verses.english: Therefore, Joab, seeing that the enemy battle lines were set against him both in front and in the rear, chose from among all of Israel's most valiant men and drew up his own battle line against the Arameans.

verses.latin: Reliquam autem partem populi dedit Abisai fratri suo, qui instruxit aciem adversum filios Ammon.
verses.english: The remaining part of the people, he gave to his brother Abishai, who then drew up their battle line against the Ammonites.

verses.latin: Et ait Joab: Si prævaluerint contra me Syri, auxilii eris mihi: si autem filii Ammon prævaluerint contra te, auxiliabor tibi.
verses.english: And Joab said: 'If the Arameans prove stronger than I, you shall come to my aid. But if the Ammonites prove stronger than you, then I will come to your aid.'

verses.latin: Confortare, et agamus viriliter pro populo nostro, et pro civitatibus Dei nostri: Dominus autem faciet quod bonum in conspectu suo est.
verses.english: 'Be strong, and let us act bravely for our people and for the cities of our God. May the Lord do what is good in His own sight.'

verses.latin: Et inito certamine, fugerunt Syri a facie Joab: et filii Ammon videntes quod fugissent Syri, fugerunt et ipsi a facie Abisai, et ingressi sunt civitatem. Reversusque est Joab a filiis Ammon, et venit Jerusalem.
verses.english: And when the battle began, the Arameans fled before Joab. And the Ammonites, seeing that the Arameans had fled, also fled from Abishai and entered their city. So Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and came back to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Videntes autem Syri quod corruissent coram Israël, congregaverunt se in unum.
verses.english: But when the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they gathered themselves together in one place.

verses.latin: Misit itaque Adarezer, et eduxit Syros qui erant trans flumen, et adduxit eorum exercitum: et Sobach princeps militiæ Adarezer erat super eos.
verses.english: So Hadadezer sent and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River, and he led their army to battle. Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer's army, was over them.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est David: et contraxit omnem Israël, et transivit Jordanem, et venit Helam: et instruxerunt aciem contra Syros, et pugnaverunt adversum eos.
verses.english: And it was reported to David. So he gathered all of Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. There they drew up their battle line against the Arameans and fought against them.

verses.latin: Fugeruntque Syri a facie Israël: et interfecit David de Syris septingentos currus, et quadraginta millia equitum: et Sobach principem militiæ eorum percussit, qui statim mortuus est.
verses.english: And the Arameans fled from before Israel. David killed seven hundred of their charioteers and forty thousand cavalrymen. He also struck Shobach, their army commander, who immediately died there.

verses.latin: Videntes autem universi reges, qui erant sub Adarezer, se victos esse ab Israël, fecerunt pacem cum Israël, et servierunt eis: timueruntque Syri ultra juvare filios Ammon.
verses.english: And all the kings who were under Hadadezer, seeing that they had been defeated by Israel, made peace with Israel and served them. The Arameans were then afraid to help the Ammonites any further.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post haec, ut moreretur rex filiorum Ammon, et regnaret Hanon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: Now it came to pass after these events, that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanon began to reign in his place.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, vertente anno, eo tempore quo solent reges ad bella procedere, misit David Joab et servos suos cum eo, et universum Israël, et vastaverunt filios Ammon, et obsederunt Rabba: David autem remansit in Jerusalem.
verses.english: Now it happened, as the year turned, at the time when kings typically go out to wage war, David sent Joab, along with his servants and all of Israel. They devastated the Ammonites and laid siege to Rabbah. But David himself remained in Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Et factum est vespere, surrexit David de strato suo: et ambulabat super tectum domus regiae: viditque mulierem lavantem se de super tecto, quae erat valde pulchra.
verses.english: And it happened one evening, David rose from his bed and walked upon the roof of the king's house. From there, he saw a woman washing herself. She was very beautiful.

verses.latin: Misit ergo David et interrogavit quae esset mulier. Dixitque ei nuntius: Nonne haec est Bethsabee filia Eliam, uxor Uriae Hethaei?
verses.english: So David sent messengers and inquired who the woman was. And a messenger said to him, 'Is this not Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite?'

verses.latin: Misit ergo David nuntios, et tulit eam: et ingressa est ad illum, dormivitque cum ea: statimque sanctificata est ab immunditia sua.
verses.english: Then David sent messengers and had her brought to him. She came in to him, and he slept with her. She then immediately purified herself from the uncleanness of her menstrual cycle.

verses.latin: Et reversa est in domum suam, concepissetque. Et mittens nuntiavit David, et ait: Concepisse me.
verses.english: And she returned to her house, having conceived a child. And she sent word to David, saying, 'I have conceived.'

verses.latin: Misit autem David ad Joab, dicens: Mitte ad me Uriam Hethaeum. Et misit Joab Uriam ad David.
verses.english: David then sent word to Joab, saying, 'Send Uriah the Hittite to me.' And Joab sent Uriah to David.

verses.latin: Venitque Urias ad David. Interrogavitque David quam prospere ageret Joab, et populus, et bellum.
verses.english: When Uriah came to David, David asked him how Joab was doing, how the people were doing, and how the war was going.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Uriam: Vade in domum tuam, et lava pedes tuos. Et egressus est Urias de domo regis, secutaque est eum convivii regii mensa.
verses.english: And David said to Uriah, 'Go to your house and wash your feet.' And when Uriah left the king's house, a portion from the king's table followed him, sent as a gift.

verses.latin: Dormivitque Urias ante portam domus regiae cum omnibus servis domini sui, et non ivit in domum suam.
verses.english: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the king's house with all the servants of his lord, and he did not go into his own house.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est David a dicentibus: Non ivit Urias in domum suam. Et ait David ad Uriam: Numquid non de via venisti? quare non descendisti in domum tuam?
verses.english: It was reported to David by those who said, 'Uriah did not go into his house.' Then David said to Uriah, 'Have you not just come from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?'

verses.latin: Et ait Urias ad David: Arca Dei et Israël, et Juda, habitant in papilionibus, et dominus meus Joab, et servi domini mei super faciem terrae manent: et ego ingrediar domum meam, ut comedam et bibam, et dormiam cum uxore mea? Per salutem tuam, et per salutem animae tuae, non faciam rem hanc.
verses.english: And Uriah said to David, 'The Ark of God, along with Israel and Judah, dwell in tents. And my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, remain in the open field. How then could I go into my own house to eat and drink and sleep with my wife? By your life, and by the life of your soul, I will not do this thing.'

verses.latin: Dixit ergo David ad Uriam: Mane hic hodie, et cras dimittam te. Mansit ergo Urias in Jerusalem in die illa et altera.
verses.english: Then David said to Uriah, 'Remain here today, and tomorrow I will send you away.' So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.

verses.latin: Et vocavit eum David, et comedit coram eo et bibit, et inebriavit eum: et egressus est vespere, et dormivit in strato suo cum servis domini sui, et in domum suam non descendit.
verses.english: David then called for him and made him eat and drink in his presence, and he made him drunk. But in the evening, Uriah went out and slept on his bed with the servants of his lord, and he did not go down to his own house.

verses.latin: Factum est ergo mane, scripsit David epistolam ad Joab: et misit per manum Uriae.
verses.english: So it happened in the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah.

verses.latin: Scribens autem in epistola, posuit: Ponite Uriam in prima acie, ubi fortissimum est praelium: et recedite ab eo, ut percussus moriatur.
verses.english: In the letter, he wrote this command: 'Place Uriah in the front line of the fiercest battle. Then, withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and die.'

verses.latin: Igitur cum Joab obsideret urbem, posuit Uriam in loco ubi sciebat viros esse fortissimos.
verses.english: Therefore, when Joab besieged the city, he placed Uriah in a spot where he knew there were very strong enemy fighters.

verses.latin: Egressique viri de civitate, pugnaverunt adversum Joab: et ceciderunt de populo servis David, et mortuus est etiam Urias Hethaeus.
verses.english: And the men of the city came out and fought against Joab. Some of the people, David's servants, fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.

verses.latin: Misit ergo Joab et nuntiavit David omnia verba proelii.
verses.english: So Joab sent and reported to David all the words of the battle.

verses.latin: Et praecepit nuntio, dicens: Cum compleveris universa verba proelii ad regem.
verses.english: And he commanded the messenger, saying: 'When you have finished reporting all the details of the battle to the king,

verses.latin: Si quemque de regibus ira commoverit, et dixerit: Quare accessistis ad murum ut pugnaretis? an ignorabatis quia multa desuper ex muro jacere solent?
verses.english: If any of the king's anger is stirred, and he says, 'Why did you approach the wall to fight? Did you not know that many projectiles are usually thrown down from the wall from above?

verses.latin: Quis percussit Abimelech filium Jerobaal? nonne mulier misit super eum fragmen molae de muro, et interfecit eum in Thebes? quare juxta murum accessistis? Dices: Etiam servus tuus Urias Hethaeus mortuus est.
verses.english: Who struck down Abimelech, the son of Jerubaal? Did not a woman throw a piece of a millstone down on him from the wall and kill him at Thebez? Why did you approach so close to the wall?' Then you shall say, 'Your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.'

verses.latin: Abiit ergo nuntius, et venit ad David, et nuntiavit ei omnia quae praeceperat ei Joab.
verses.english: So the messenger went and came to David and reported to him all that Joab had commanded him.

verses.latin: Et dixit nuntius ad David: Praevaluerunt adversum nos viri, et egressi sunt ad nos in campum: et nos persecuti eos, clausimus usque ad portam civitatis.
verses.english: And the messenger said to David: 'The men of the city had the upper hand against us and came out against us in the open field. But we pursued them and drove them back all the way to the gate of the city.

verses.latin: Et jacuerunt sagittarii super servos tuos de muro, et mortui sunt de servis regis: quin etiam servus tuus Urias Hethaeus mortuus est.
verses.english: And archers shot down from the wall upon your servants, and some of the king's servants died. Indeed, your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.'

verses.latin: Et dixit David ad nuntium: Haec dices Joab: Non te frangat ista res: varius enim eventus est belli: et nunc huc, et nunc illuc percusserit gladius: instiga bellatores tuos adversum civitatem, ut destruas eam, et conforta illum.
verses.english: And David said to the messenger, 'Say this to Joab: 'Do not let this matter discourage you, for the outcome of war is unpredictable. The sword strikes now one way, now another. Press your warriors against the city to destroy it, and strengthen their resolve.''

verses.latin: Audivit autem uxor Uriae quod mortuus esset Urias vir suus, et planxit virum suum.
verses.english: Now when Uriah's wife heard that Uriah, her husband, was dead, she mourned for her husband.

verses.latin: Transacto autem luctu, misit David, et introduxit eam in domum suam, et facta est ei uxor, et peperit ei filium. Et displicuit sermoni quod fecerat David coram Domino.
verses.english: After her period of mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her into his house. She became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the Lord.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, vertente anno, eo tempore quo solent reges ad bella procedere, misit David Joab, et servos suos cum eo, et universum Israel, et vastaverunt filios Ammon, et obsederunt Rabba: David autem remansit in Jerusalem.
verses.english: Now it happened when the new year came—the time when kings typically march out to wage war—that King David sent Joab and his own personal guards with him, along with all the army of Israel. They attacked the Ammonites and laid siege to their city, Rabbah, but King David himself remained behind in Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Erat igitur quodam die, declinante jam ad vesperam, surrexit David de strato suo, et ambulabat super tectum domus regiae: viditque mulierem lavantem se de super tectum domus suae: et erat mulier pulchra valde.
verses.english: Then one day, as the evening was approaching, King David rose from his bed and walked upon the roof of the king's palace. From there he saw a woman bathing on the roof of her own house. The woman was exceptionally beautiful.

verses.latin: Misit ergo rex, et requisivit quæ esset mulier. Et nuntiatum est ei quod ipsa esset Bethsabee filia Eliam, uxor Uriæ Hethæi.
verses.english: So the king sent messengers to inquire who the woman was. And it was reported back to him that she was Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.

verses.latin: Misit ergo David nuntios, et tulit eam. Et ingressa est ad illum, et dormivit cum eo: ipsa autem purgata erat de immunditia sua: reversaque est in domum suam.
verses.english: Therefore, King David sent messengers, and they brought her to him. She came in to him and he lay with her. She had just purified herself from her ritual uncleanness, meaning she was fertile. Afterwards, she returned to her house.

verses.latin: Conceptisque mulier, misit, et nuntiavit David, dicens: Concepisse me.
verses.english: And the woman conceived a child. She then sent word to King David, saying: 'I have become pregnant.'

verses.latin: Misit autem David ad Joab, dicens: Mitte ad me Uriam Hethæum. Et misit Joab Uriam ad David.
verses.english: So King David sent word to Joab, saying: 'Send Uriah the Hittite to me.' And Joab sent Uriah to King David.

verses.latin: Venit Urias ad David: interrogavitque David quam ingrederetur Joab, et populus, et qualiter administraretur bellum.
verses.english: When Uriah came to King David, David asked him how Joab was, and how the soldiers were, and how the war was progressing.

verses.latin: Et dixit David ad Uriam: Vade in domum tuam, et lava pedes tuos. Et egressus est Urias de domo regis, secutusque est eum cibus regius.
verses.english: Then King David said to Uriah: 'Go to your house, and wash your feet.' So Uriah departed from the king's house, and the king's servants carried a gift of food after him, as a sign of favor.

verses.latin: Et dormivit Urias ante portam domus regiæ cum omnibus servis domini sui: et non descendit in domum suam.
verses.english: But Uriah slept outside the gate of the king's house, with all the servants of his lord, and did not go down into his own house.

verses.latin: Nuntiaveruntque David, dicentes: Non ivit Urias in domum suam. Et dixit David ad Uriam: Numquid non de via venisti? quare non descendisti in domum tuam?
verses.english: And they reported to King David, saying: 'Uriah did not go down to his house.' King David then said to Uriah: 'Have you not just come from a journey? Why then did you not go down to your house?'

verses.latin: Et ait Urias ad David: Arca Dei, et Israel, et Juda, habitant in papilionibus, et dominus meus Joab, et servi domini mei super faciem terræ pernoctant: et ego ingrediar domum meam, ut comedam, et bibam, et dormiam cum uxore mea? Per salutem tuam, et per salutem animæ tuæ, non faciam hanc rem.
verses.english: Uriah answered King David: 'The Ark of God, and all Israel, and Judah, are living in temporary shelters, and my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are sleeping in the open field. And should I then go into my house to eat and drink and lie with my wife? By your very life, and by the life of your soul, I will not do this thing!'

verses.latin: Dixit ergo David ad Uriam: Mane hic etiam hodie, et cras dimittam te. Mansit ergo Urias in Jerusalem in die illa, et in crastina.
verses.english: Then King David said to Uriah: 'Stay here also today, and tomorrow I will send you back to the army.' So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day, and the next day.

verses.latin: Et vocavit eum David, ut comedat coram se et biberet, et inebriavit eum: et egressus est vespere, et dormivit in strato suo cum servis domini sui, et in domum suam non descendit.
verses.english: And King David invited him to eat and drink in his presence, and made him drunk. But Uriah still went out in the evening and slept on his pallet with the servants of his lord, and did not go down into his own house.

verses.latin: Factum est ergo mane, scripsit David epistolam ad Joab: et misit per manum Uriæ.
verses.english: So it happened in the morning, King David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah himself.

verses.latin: Scribens autem in epistola, posuit: Ponite Uriam in prima acie, ubi fortissimum est prælium: et recedite ab eo, ut percussus moriatur.
