verses.english: The king and all the people following in his footsteps went out, and then they stopped at a distant house.

verses.latin: Omnesque servi ejus pertransibant juxta eum, et omnis Cherethi, et Phelethi, et omnis Getthaeus, sexcenti viri qui secuti eum fuerant de Geth, transibant coram rege.
verses.english: All his servants passed by him, along with all the Cherethites and all the Pelethites—his personal guard. All six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath also passed by before the king.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex ad Ethai Getthaeum: Cur venis nobiscum? Revertere, et mane cum rege: quia peregrinus es, et egressus de loco tuo.
verses.english: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite: "Why are you coming with us? Go back and stay with the new king Absalom, for you are a foreigner, and you are an exile from your own land."

verses.latin: Heri venisti, et hodie cogaris nobiscum egredi? ego autem vadam quo iturus sum: revertere, et reduc tecum fratres tuos, et Dominus faciat tecum misericordiam, et veritatem.
verses.english: "You only arrived yesterday, and today you are forced to leave with us? I am going wherever I must go. Return, and take your countrymen with you. May the Lord show you steadfast love and faithfulness."

verses.latin: Et respondens Ethai, ait regi: Vivit Dominus, et vivit dominus meus rex, quoniam in quocumque loco fueris dominus meus rex, sive ad mortem, sive ad vitam, ibi erit servus tuus.
verses.english: But Ittai replied to the king: "As the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be—whether it leads to death or to life—there your servant will be also."

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Ethai: Veni, et transi. Et transivit Ethai Getthaeus, et omnes viri ejus, et omnis familia cum eo.
verses.english: David then said to Ittai: "Come, cross over with us." So Ittai the Gittite passed over, with all his men and all the families with him.

verses.latin: Omnisque terra flebat voce magna, et universus populus transibat: rex quoque transibat torrentem Cedron, et cunctus populus in viam deserti tendebat.
verses.english: And all the inhabitants of the land wept with a loud voice as the entire populace passed over. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people headed toward the road leading to the wilderness.

verses.latin: Venit autem et Sadoc, et universi Levitae cum eo, portantes arcam foederis Dei: et deposuerunt arcam Dei, et Abiathar ascendit, donec cunctus populus egressus est de civitate.
verses.english: And behold, Zadok also came, and all the Levites with him, carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark of God, and Abiathar went up and offered sacrifices, until all the people had finished leaving the city.

verses.latin: Et dixit rex ad Sadoc: Reporta arcam Dei in urbem: si invenero gratiam in oculis Domini, reducet me, et ostendet mihi eam, et tabernaculum suum.
verses.english: Then the king said to Zadok: "Carry the Ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, He will bring me back and allow me to see it and His dwelling place again."

verses.latin: Sin autem et dixerit mihi: Non places tibi: paratus sum, faciat quod bonum est coram se.
verses.english: "But if He says to me: 'I am not pleased with you,' then I am ready; let Him do to me whatever seems good in His sight."

verses.latin: Et dixit rex ad Sadoc sacerdotem: Vides? revertere in civitatem in pace: et Achimaas filius tuus, et Jonathan filius Abiathar, duo filii vestri sint vobiscum.
verses.english: The king also said to Zadok the priest: "Do you understand? Return to the city in peace. And your son Ahimaaz, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son—your two sons—let them be with you.

verses.latin: Ecce ego abscondar in campestribus deserti, donec veniat sermo a vobis indicans mihi.
verses.english: Look, I will hide myself by the fords in the wilderness, until a message comes from you to inform me of the situation."

verses.latin: Reportaverunt igitur Sadoc et Abiathar arcam Dei in Jerusalem, et manserunt ibi.
verses.english: So Zadok and Abiathar carried the Ark of God back to Jerusalem and remained there.

verses.latin: Porro David ascendebat clivum Olivarum, plorans et nudis pedibus, operto capite: omnisque populus qui erat cum eo, ascendebat capite operto, plorans.
verses.english: Meanwhile, David was ascending the slope of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered, and his feet were bare as a sign of mourning and humiliation. All the people who were with him also ascended with covered heads, weeping.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem David ab Achitophel: Absalom est in conjuratione tua. Et ait David: Infatua, quæso, Domine, consilium Achitophel.
verses.english: Then it was reported to David: "Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom!" And David prayed: "Please, Lord, make Ahithophel's counsel foolish."

verses.latin: Cumque ascendisset David in verticem montis, ubi adorabatur Dominus, ecce obviam ei venit Chusai Arachites scissa veste et asperso capite pulvere.
verses.english: As David reached the summit of the mountain—the place where the Lord was worshipped—there, Hushai the Archite came to meet him, with his tunic torn and dust sprinkled on his head as a sign of distress.

verses.latin: Et dixit ei David: Si venis mecum, eris mihi oneri:
verses.english: And David said to him: "If you come with me, you will be a burden to me:

verses.latin: si autem reverteris in civitatem, et dixeris Absalom: Servus tuus sum, rex; sicut fui servus patris tui, sic ero et servus tuus; dissipabis consilium Achitophel.
verses.english: But if you return to the city and say to Absalom: 'I am your servant, O king; just as I was your father's servant, so now I will be your servant,' then you can thwart Ahithophel's counsel for me."

verses.latin: Habes autem tecum ibi Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotes: et omne verbum quodcumque audieris de domo regis, indicabis Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotibus.
verses.english: Furthermore, Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, are there with you. Every word you hear from the king's household, you must report to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.

verses.latin: Ipsorum enim sunt ibi duo filii, Achimaas Sadoc, et Jonathan Abiathar: et mittetis per eos omne verbum, quodcumque audieritis.
verses.english: For their two sons are there with them: Zadok's son Ahimaaz, and Abiathar's son Jonathan. Through them, you will send me every message that you hear."

verses.latin: Regressus est ergo Chusai amicus David in civitatem. Absalom autem ingrediebatur Jerusalem.
verses.english: So Hushai, David's friend, returned to the city. And Absalom was entering Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Et cum transisset David paululum verticem montis, apparuit ei Siba puer Miphiboseth in occursum veniens, cum paribus asinis duobus, onustis ducentis panibus, et centum uvis passis, et centum ponderibus aestivis, et utre vini.
verses.english: When King David had gone a little way past the summit of the Mount of Olives, Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, appeared before him, coming to meet him. Ziba had with him a pair of donkeys, loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred baskets of summer fruits, and a wineskin filled with wine.

verses.latin: Et ait rex ad Siba: Quid sibi volunt haec? Qui respondit: Asini servorum domini tui, ut sedeant; et panes et aestiva ad vescendum pueris tuis; et vinum ut bibat unusquisque qui defecit in deserto.
verses.english: Then the king asked Ziba, 'What is the purpose of these things you have brought?' Ziba answered, 'The donkeys are for your household servants to ride upon. The bread and summer fruits are for your young men to eat, and the wine is for anyone who grows weary and thirsty in the desert to drink.'

verses.latin: Et dixit rex: Ubi est filius domini tui? Et respondit Siba regi: Mansit in Jerusalem, dicens: Hodie restituet mihi domus Israel regnum patris mei.
verses.english: The king then asked, 'Where is your master's son, Mephibosheth?' And Ziba answered the king, 'He has remained in Jerusalem, saying, 'Today the house of Israel will restore the kingdom of my father to me.'

verses.latin: Et ait rex Sibae: Tua sint omnia quae fuerunt Miphiboseth. Dixitque Siba: Procidens oro, ut inveniam gratiam coram te, domine mi rex.
verses.english: Then the king said to Ziba, 'Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.' Ziba replied, 'I bow low and plead that I may find favor in your sight, my lord, O King.'

verses.latin: Venit itaque rex David usque Bahurim: et ecce egrediebatur inde vir de cognatione domus Saul, nomine Semei, filius Gera: procedebat, et maledicebat.
verses.english: So King David came to Bahurim. And behold, a man from the kindred of the house of Saul came out from there, whose name was Shimei, the son of Gera. He came forward, cursing as he approached.

verses.latin: Et mittebat lapides contra David, et contra universos servos regis David: omnisque populus, et universi viri fortissimi a dextris ejus, et a sinistris incedebant.
verses.english: He began throwing stones at David and at all the servants of King David. And all the people, and all the strongest warriors, were walking on his right and on his left side.

verses.latin: Sic autem loquebatur Semei cum malediceret regi: Egredere, egredere, vir sanguinum, et vir Belial.
verses.english: And this is what Shimei said as he cursed the king: 'Get out! Get out, you man of bloodshed, and you worthless man!'

verses.latin: Reddidit tibi Dominus omnem sanguinem domus Saul: quoniam invasisti regnum ejus: et dedit Dominus regnum in manu Absalom filii tui: et ecce premunt te mala tua, quoniam vir sanguinum es.
verses.english: The Lord has brought back upon you all the bloodshed of the house of Saul, because you seized his kingdom. And the Lord has now given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. And behold, your own evil deeds are pressing down upon you, because you are a man of bloodshed.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Abisai filius Sarviae regi: Quare maledicit canis hic mortuus domino meo regi? vadam, et amputabo caput ejus.
verses.english: Then Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, said to the king, 'Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over now and cut off his head!'

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Quid mihi et vobis est, filii Sarviae? Dimittite eum ut maledicat: Dominus enim praecepit ei ut malediceret David: et quis est qui audeat dicere: Quare hoc fecisti?
verses.english: But the king said, 'What business is it of mine or yours, O sons of Zeruiah? Let him curse. For the Lord himself has commanded him to curse David, and who is there who dares to say, 'Why have you done this?'

verses.latin: Et dixit David Abisai, et universis servis suis: Ecce filius meus qui egressus est de utero meo, quaerit animam meam: quanto magis nunc filius Jemini? Dimittite eum ut maledicat, juxta praeceptum Domini.
verses.english: And David said to Abishai and to all his servants, 'Behold, my own son, who came out from my body, seeks my life. How much more so should this Benjaminite be allowed to curse? Let him curse, according to the Lord's command.

verses.latin: Forsitan aspiciat Dominus afflictionem meam, et reddat mihi Dominus bonum pro maledictione hac hodierna.
verses.english: Perhaps the Lord will look upon my affliction and repay me with good for this cursing I endure today.

verses.latin: Incedebat itaque David, et socii ejus per viam: Semei autem per juga montis ex latere, maledicens incedebat, et mittens lapides contra eum, terramque spargens.
verses.english: So David and his companions went on their way. But Shimei walked on the side of the mountain ridge, cursing as he went, and throwing stones at David and scattering dust.

verses.latin: Et venit rex, et universus populus cum eo lassus, et refecit se ibi.
verses.english: And the king and all the people with him arrived, weary, and refreshed themselves there.

verses.latin: Absalom autem et omnis populus Israel cum eo, ingressi sunt Jerusalem, et Achitophel cum eo.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Absalom and all the people of Israel with him entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.

verses.latin: Cum autem venisset Chusai Arachites amicus David ad Absalom, locutus est ad eum dicens: Ave rex, ave rex.
verses.english: But when Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, he spoke to him, saying, 'Long live the king! Long live the king!'

verses.latin: Et ait Absalom ad Chusai: Hanc est gratia tua ad amicum tuum? quare non ivisti cum amico tuo?
verses.english: And Absalom said to Hushai, 'Is this how you show loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend David?'

verses.latin: Et respondit Chusai ad Absalom: Nequaquam: sed quem elegit Dominus, et hic populus, et omnis Israel, illius ego ero, et cum illo manebo.
verses.english: Hushai answered Absalom, 'No, that is not the case. But instead, the one whom the Lord has chosen, and this people, and all of Israel, I will be his servant, and I will remain with him.'

verses.latin: Sed et hoc secundo: Cujus sum ego? nonne servi domini tui? Sicut fui coram patre tuo, sic ero coram te.
verses.english: And furthermore, whose servant am I? Am I not the servant of your father? Just as I served before your father, so I will serve before you.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Absalom ad Achitophel: Inite consilium quid agere debeamus.
verses.english: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, 'Give your counsel now: what should we do?'

verses.latin: Et ait Achitophel ad Absalom: Ingredere ad concubinas patris tui, quas dimisit ad custodiendam domum: ut cum audierit omnis Israel quod foedus feceris patri tuo, roborentur manus omnium qui tecum sunt.
verses.english: And Ahithophel said to Absalom, 'Go in to your father's concubines, whom he left behind to guard the house. For when all Israel hears that you have made yourself utterly detestable to your father, the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.'

verses.latin: Tetenderunt igitur Absalom tabernaculum in solario, et ingressus est ad concubinas patris sui coram omni Israel.
verses.english: So Absalom had a tent pitched on the roof of the palace, and he went in to his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.

verses.latin: Consilium autem Achitophel quod dabat in diebus illis, quasi verbum Dei oraculum consulebatur: sic erant omnia consilia Achitophel, et cum David, et cum Absalom.
verses.english: Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave in those days was considered as if it were an oracle from the word of God. Such was all the counsel of Ahithophel, both when he was with David and now when he was with Absalom.

verses.latin: Cumque David transisset paululum verticem, apparuit ei Siba puer Miphiboseth in occursum veniens, cum paribus asinis duobus onustis ducentis panibus, et centum uvis passis, et centum aestivis pomis, et utre vini.
verses.english: As King David had gone a little way past the top of the mountain (specifically, the Mount of Olives), Mephibosheth's servant, Ziba, appeared to meet him. Ziba was bringing two saddled donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred bunches of raisins, one hundred summer fruits, and a wineskin full of wine.

verses.latin: Et ait rex Sibae: Quid sibi volunt haec? Responditque Siba: Asini servi tui, ut sedeat rex, et domus ejus; et panes et poma ad vescendum pueris tuis; et vinum ut bibat, si quis defecerit in deserto.
verses.english: Then the king asked Ziba, "What are these things for?" Ziba replied, "The donkeys are for the king and his household to ride on. The bread and fruit are for your young men to eat, and the wine is for anyone who grows faint in the wilderness to drink."

verses.latin: Et dixit rex: Ubi est filius domini tui? Responditque Siba regi: Remansit in Jerusalem, dicens: Hodie reddet mihi domus Israel regnum patris mei.
verses.english: And the king asked, "Where is your master's son, Mephibosheth?" Ziba answered the king, "He has stayed behind in Jerusalem, saying, 'Today the house of Israel will restore my father's kingdom to me.'"

verses.latin: Et ait rex Sibae: Tua sint omnia quae fuerunt Miphiboseth. Dixitque Siba: Pronus oro; inveniam gratiam coram te, domine mi rex.
verses.english: Then the king said to Ziba, "Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours." Ziba replied, "I bow down to you, my lord the king; I pray that I may always find favor in your sight."

verses.latin: Venit ergo rex David usque Bahurim: et ecce egrediebatur inde vir de cognatione domus Saul, nomine Semei, filius Gera, procedens et maledicens in obvium.
verses.english: So King David arrived at Bahurim, and behold, a man from the clan of Saul's family, named Shimei, the son of Gera, came out from there. He was walking along and cursing David as he came.

verses.latin: Et mittebat lapides contra David, et contra universos servos regis David: omnisque populus, et universi fortes, a dextris et a sinistris regis incedebant.
verses.english: And Shimei threw stones at King David and at all of King David's servants. All the people and all the mighty warriors were walking on the king's right and on his left side.

verses.latin: Sic autem loquebatur Semei cum malediceret regi: Egredere, egredere, vir sanguinum, et vir Belial.
verses.english: This is what Shimei said as he cursed the king: "Get out! Get out, you man of blood, you worthless man!"

verses.latin: Reddidit tibi Dominus omne sanguinem domus Saul, quoniam invasisti regnum ejus: et dedit Dominus regnum in manu Absalom filii tui: et ecce premunt te mala tua, quoniam vir sanguinum es.
verses.english: The Lord has made you pay back for all the bloodshed of Saul's house, because you seized his kingdom. Now the Lord has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. Look, your own evil deeds have caught up with you, because you are a man of blood.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Abisai filius Sarviae regi: Quare maledicit canis hic mortuus domino meo regi? vadam, et amputabo caput ejus.
verses.english: Then Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, said to the king, "Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!"

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Quid mihi et vobis est, filii Sarviae? Dimittite eum ut maledicat: Dominus enim praecepit ei ut malediceret David: et quis est qui audeat dicere: Quare ita fecisti?
verses.english: But the king said, "What concern is this of yours and mine, you sons of Zeruiah? Let him curse. For the Lord Himself has commanded him to curse David; and who would dare to say, 'Why have you done this?'"

verses.latin: Et dixit David Abisai, et universis servis suis: Ecce filius meus, qui egressus est de utero meo, quaerit animam meam: quanto magis nunc filius Jemini? Dimittite eum ut maledicat juxta praeceptum Domini.
verses.english: And David said to Abishai and to all his servants, "Look, my own son, who came from my own body, is trying to take my life! How much more, then, should this Benjaminite be allowed to curse? Let him curse, for the Lord has commanded it."

verses.latin: Forsitan aspiciet Dominus afflictionem meam, et reddet mihi Dominus bonum pro maledictione hac hodierna.
verses.english: Perhaps the Lord will look upon my affliction, and the Lord will repay me with good instead of this cursing I receive today.

verses.latin: Ambulabat itaque David et socii ejus per viam: et Semei per jugum montis ex latere cohaerens, maledicebat in obvium, et spargebat lapides contra eum, et humum identidem injiciebat.
verses.english: So David and his companions continued on their way. Shimei kept walking along the side of the mountain ridge opposite them, cursing as he went, and throwing stones at King David, and continuously kicking up dust toward him.

verses.latin: Venit ergo rex et universus populus cum eo lassus ad Jordanem, et refocillatus est ibi.
verses.english: Thus the king and all the people with him, being tired, arrived at the Jordan River, and they rested there to refresh themselves.

verses.latin: Absalom autem, et omnis populus Israel cum eo, ingressi sunt Jerusalem, et Achitophel cum eo.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Absalom and all the people of Israel with him had entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum venisset Husai Arachites amicus David ad Absalom, locutus est ad eum: Ave rex, ave rex.
verses.english: Now when Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, he said to him, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"

verses.latin: Et ait Absalom: Iste est sermo tuus ad amicum tuum? Quare non isti cum amico tuo?
verses.english: And Absalom said to Hushai, "Is this the loyalty you show your friend? Why did you not go with your friend, King David?"

verses.latin: Et respondit Husai ad Absalom: Nequaquam: sed quemcumque elegit Dominus, et hic populus, et omnis Israel, illius ego ero, et cum eo manebo.
verses.english: And Hushai answered Absalom, "By no means! Rather, whomever the Lord, and this people, and all of Israel have chosen, I will be with him, and I will remain with him."

verses.latin: Sed et hoc, secundo cui ego serviam? nonne filio? Sicut servivi patri tuo, sic et tibi serviam.
verses.english: Furthermore, whom should I serve next? Should it not be his son? Just as I served your father, so I will serve you.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Absalom ad Achitophel: Inite consilium quid agere debeamus.
verses.english: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, "Give us your counsel; what should we do?"

verses.latin: Et ait Achitophel ad Absalom: Ingredere ad concubinas patris tui, quas dimisit ad custodiendam domum: ut audiat omnis Israel quod foetere feceris patrem tuum, et roborentur manus omnium qui tecum sunt.
verses.english: And Ahithophel said to Absalom, "Go in to your father's concubines, whom he left behind to guard the house. Then all of Israel will hear that you have made yourself detestable to your father, and the resolve of all who are with you will be strengthened." (This act symbolically and literally cut off any reconciliation with David and asserted Absalom's claim to the throne).

verses.latin: Tetenderunt igitur Absalom tabernaculum in solario, et ingressus est ad concubinas patris sui coram omni Israel.
verses.english: So Absalom had a tent pitched on the roof of the palace, and he went in to his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.

verses.latin: Consilium autem Achitophel, quod dabat in diebus illis, quasi oraculum Dei, sic habebatur: sic omnia consilia Achitophel, et cum esset cum David, et cum esset cum Absalom.
verses.english: Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave in those days was as if one consulted the oracle of God. Such was all of Ahithophel's counsel, both when he was with David and when he was with Absalom. (This highlights Ahithophel's reputation for wisdom and the gravity of his advice).

verses.latin: Dixit autem Achitophel ad Absalom: Eligam mihi duodecim millia virorum, et consurgens persequar David hac nocte.
verses.english: Achitophel then presented his strategy to Absalom: "Let me select twelve thousand men for myself. I will set out this very night and pursue David."

verses.latin: Et irruens super eum, dum fatigatus est, et languidus, percutiam illum: consternaboque cunctum populum qui est cum eo, et solum regem interficiam.
verses.english: "I will attack him while he is weary and exhausted. I will strike him down and scatter all the people who are with him. I will kill only the king."

verses.latin: Et reducam universam turbam ad te, sicut revertitur sponsa ad virum suum: tu enim unius viri animam quaeris, et omnis populus iste erit pacificus.
verses.english: "Then I will bring all of the people back to you, just as a bride returns to her husband. For you are seeking only the life of this one man, and afterward, all the rest of the people will be at peace."

verses.latin: Placuitque sermo ejus Absalom, et cunctis senioribus Israël.
verses.english: This speech pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Absalom: Vocate et Chusai Arachitem, et audiamus quid et ipse dicat.
verses.english: But Absalom said: "Also call Hushai the Archite, and let us hear what he too has to say."

verses.latin: Cumque venisset Chusai ad Absalom, ait Absalom ad eum, dicens: Hujuscemodi locutus est Achitophel: nunquid facere debemus quod locutus est? an censeas non esse faciendum?
verses.english: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him: "This is what Achitophel has proposed. Should we do what he has suggested, or do you advise against it?"

verses.latin: Et dixit Chusai ad Absalom: Non est bonum consilium quod dedit Achitophel hac vice.
verses.english: Hushai answered Absalom: "Achitophel’s counsel this time is not good."

verses.latin: Addiditque Chusai: Tu nosti patrem tuum, et viros qui cum eo sunt, quia fortissimi sunt, et amaro animo, sicut ursa raptis catulis in silva, et pater tuus vir bellator est, nec morabitur cum populo.
verses.english: Hushai added: "You know your father and the men with him, that they are mighty warriors and fiercely determined. They are like a bear robbed of her cubs in the wilderness. And your father is a man of war; he will not stay with the main army."

verses.latin: Forte nunc latitat in aliqua fovea, aut in uno de locis his: et cum irruerit unusquisque in primis, audiet, et dicent, Cecidit plaga in populum qui sequitur Absalom.
verses.english: "Perhaps he is now hiding in some cave or in one of these secret places. And when he first strikes, everyone who hears of it will say, 'A great slaughter has fallen upon the people following Absalom!'"

verses.latin: Et ipse, qui fortissimus est, forti simus corde, tabescet metu: si audierit, inquit, quod infracti sint, qui cum eo sunt. Sed et omnis Israël scit quod fortis est pater tuus, et robusti omnes qui cum eo sunt.
verses.english: "And even the bravest, strongest-hearted man will be filled with fear if he hears that those who are with David are broken. Moreover, all Israel knows that your father is a powerful warrior, and all who are with him are mighty."

verses.latin: Sed hoc potius consilium do: Congregari ad te universum Israël, a Dan usque Bersabee, quasi arenam maris in multitudine: et tu ipse in medio eorum eris.
verses.english: "Instead, this is the counsel I give: Let all Israel gather to you, from Dan even to Beersheba—a multitude like the sand by the sea. And you yourself will lead them in the middle of them all."

verses.latin: Et irruemus super eum in quocumque loco fuerit inventus, et operiemus eum sicut cadere solet ros super terram: et non remanebit de viris qui cum eo sunt, ne unus quidem.
verses.english: "Then we will fall upon him wherever he may be found, and we will cover him as the dew falls upon the earth—so that not even one man who is with him will remain alive."

verses.latin: Quod si in civitatem aliquam fuerit fugerit, circumdabitur a cuncto Israël urbs illa, et trahemus eam funibus, usque dum ne una quidem lapidis particula inveniatur ibi.
verses.english: "If he has fled into some city, then all of Israel will surround that city. And we will drag it away with ropes until not even one small stone is found remaining there."

verses.latin: Et dixit Absalom, et omnes viri Israël: Melius est consilium Chusai Arachitae, consilio Achitophel. Dominus autem jusserat irritum fieri consilium Achitophel utile, ut induceret Dominus super Absalom malum.
verses.english: Absalom and all the men of Israel said: "The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Achitophel." For the Lord had commanded that Achitophel's useful counsel be made void, so that the Lord might bring disaster upon Absalom.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Chusai Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotibus: Hujuscemodi consilium dedit Achitophel Absalom, et senioribus Israël: et hujuscemodi consilium dedi ego.
verses.english: Hushai then said to Zadok and Abiathar the priests: "This is the counsel Achitophel gave to Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is the counsel I myself gave."

verses.latin: Nunc ergo cito mittite, et nuntiate David, dicentes: Ne moreris nocte hac in solitudine plani campi, sed absque dilatione transgredere, ne forte deglutiatur rex, et omnis populus qui est cum eo.
verses.english: "Now therefore, quickly send word and tell David: 'Do not stay this night in the desert of the plain. But without delay, cross over the Jordan, lest perhaps the king and all the people with him be swallowed up.'"

verses.latin: Jonathan autem et Achimaas stabant juxta fontem Rogel. Abiitque ancilla, et nuntiavit eis, et illi profecti sunt, ut referrent nuntium David regi: non enim poterant videri, nec introire civitatem.
verses.english: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting by the Rogel Spring. A female servant went and told them the message. And they then set out to carry the message to King David, for they could not be seen entering the city.

verses.latin: Vidit autem eos puer, et nuntiavit Absalom. Illi vero festinantes, properaverunt, et ingressi sunt domum viri in Bahurim, qui habebat puteum in vestibulo suo, et descenderunt in eum.
verses.english: However, a young man saw them and reported it to Absalom. But the messengers, hurrying quickly, rushed away and entered the house of a man in Bahurim who had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it to hide.

verses.latin: Tulit autem mulier, et expandit velamen super orificium putei, sicut siccare pannos solent, et nihil omnino cognitum est.
verses.english: The woman then took a covering and spread it over the mouth of the well, as people usually do to dry grain, so that nothing at all was known of their hiding place.

verses.latin: Cumque venissent servi Absalom ad mulierem in domum ejus, dixerunt: Ubi est Achimaas et Jonathan? Et respondit mulier eis: Transierunt festinantes rivulum aquarum. Et cum quaesissent, et non invenissent, reversi sunt in Jerusalem.
verses.english: When Absalom's servants came to the woman at her house, they asked: "Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?" And the woman answered them: "They hurried across the stream of water." And after they searched and did not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Cumque illi abissent, ascenderunt de puteo, et profecti sunt nuntiaverunt regi David, dixeruntque: Consurgite, et transite cito fluvium: quoniam hujuscemodi dedit consilium Achitophel adversum vos.
verses.english: When those pursuers had left, the two men came up out of the well. They went and informed King David, saying: "Get up, and quickly cross the river! For Achitophel has given this kind of counsel against you."

verses.latin: Surrexit ergo David, et omnis populus qui cum eo erat, et transierunt Jordanem, donec dilucesceret: et ne unus quidem superfuit, qui non transisset fluvium.
verses.english: So David rose up, and all the people who were with him, and they crossed the Jordan River before daybreak. Not even one person was left who had not crossed the river.

verses.latin: Achitophel autem videns quia non fuerat secutum consilium suum, strinxit frænum asini sui, et surrexit, et abiit in domum suam, et in civitatem suam: et composita domo sua, suspendio periit, et sepultus est in sepulchro patris sui.
verses.english: But Achitophel, seeing that his counsel had not been followed, saddled his donkey. He rose and went to his own house and to his own city. After he set his household in order, he hanged himself and died, and he was buried in his father’s tomb.

verses.latin: David autem venit in Mahanaim: Absalom vero transiit Jordanem, et omnis vir Israël cum eo.
verses.english: Meanwhile, David arrived at Mahanaim. Absalom, however, crossed the Jordan River, and every man of Israel was with him.

verses.latin: Amasa vero Absalom constituit pro Joab super exercitum: Amasa autem filius erat viri, qui vocabatur Jethra de Israël, qui ingressus est ad Abigail filiam Naas, sororem Sarvi, quæ mater Joab fuerat.
verses.english: Absalom then appointed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. Amasa was the son of a man named Jethra the Israelite, who had gone in to Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah, who had been Joab's mother.

verses.latin: Castrametatus est autem Israël cum Absalom in terra Galaad.
verses.english: And Israel, with Absalom, camped in the land of Gilead.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset David in Mahanaim, Sobi filius Naas de Rabba filiorum Ammon, et Machir filius Ammiel de Lodabar, et Berzellai Galaadites de Rogelim,
verses.english: When David came to Mahanaim, three men arrived to support him: Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim.

verses.latin: attulerunt culcitras, et tapetes, et vasa fictilia, frumentum, et hordeum, et farinam, et polentam, et fabas, et lentem,
verses.english: They brought bedding and rugs and earthenware vessels. They also brought food supplies: wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, and lentils.

verses.latin: et mel, et butyrum, et oves, et caseum bubulum in usum David, et populi qui cum eo erat: suspicati enim sunt, ne forte populus esuriret et deficeret in solitudine.
verses.english: They also brought honey, butter, sheep, and cheese from cattle for David’s use and for the people who were with him. For they had supposed that the people might become hungry and exhausted in the desert.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Achitophel ad Absalom: Eligam mihi duodecim millia virorum, et consurgens persequar David hac nocte.
verses.english: Achitophel then spoke to Absalom: 'Let me choose twelve thousand men for myself, and I will rise up and pursue David this very night.'

verses.latin: Et irruens super eum cum defatigatus fuerit et lassus, percutiam eum: consternabitur omnis populus qui est cum eo, et ego percutiam regem solum.
verses.english: 'I will rush upon him while he is exhausted and weary, and I will strike him down. All the people who are with him will be scattered in terror, and I will strike the king alone.'

verses.latin: Et reducam universum populum ad te, sicut revertitur sponsa ad virum suum: Tu enim animam viri unius quæris, et omnis populus erit pacificus.
verses.english: 'I will bring all the people back to you as a bride returns to her husband. For it is only the life of one man that you seek, and then all the people will be at peace.'

verses.latin: Placuitque sermo ejus Absalom, et cunctis senioribus Israël.
verses.english: This plan pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Absalom: Vocate Husai Arachiten etiam, et audiamus quid et ipse dicat.
verses.english: Absalom then said: 'Call Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear what he too has to say.'

verses.latin: Cumque venisset Husai ad Absalom, ait Absalom, loquens: Hujuscemodi locutus est Achitophel: faciemus verbum ejus, an non? tu consule.
verses.english: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said, speaking to him: 'Achitophel has spoken in this manner. Should we follow his advice or not? You advise us.'

verses.latin: Et ait Husai ad Absalom: Non est bonus sermo quem locutus est Achitophel hac vice.
verses.english: And Hushai said to Absalom: 'The advice that Achitophel has given this time is not good.'

verses.latin: Et adjecit Husai: Tu scis patrem tuum, et viros qui cum eo sunt, quod fortissimi sint, et amaro animo, velut ursa raptis catulis in silva: et pater tuus vir bellator est, nec morabitur cum populo.
verses.english: Hushai added: 'You know your father and the men who are with him, that they are very mighty and fierce in spirit, like a bear whose cubs have been taken from her in the wild. And your father is a warrior, and he will not spend the night with the people.'

verses.latin: Forsitan nunc latitat in aliqua fovea, vel in altero loco: et cum ceciderit unus quilibet in principio, audiet et dicet populus: Facta est plaga in populo qui sequitur Absalom.
verses.english: 'Perhaps right now he is hiding in some pit or in another secret place. And if even one of your men falls at the very beginning of the battle, the people will hear of it and say, 'There has been a great slaughter among the people who follow Absalom!''

verses.latin: Et fortissimus quoque cujus cor est quasi leonis, confterritur: siquidem scit omnis Israël fortissimum esse patrem tuum, et robustos omnes qui cum eo sunt.
verses.english: 'Then even the most courageous man, whose heart is like a lion, will be utterly terrified. For all of Israel knows that your father is a mighty warrior, and that all those who are with him are strong.'

verses.latin: Sed hoc suadeo consilium: Congregari ad te universum Israël a Dan usque Bersabee, quasi arenam maris innumerabilem, et tuum esse in medio eorum præliabitur facies tua.
verses.english: 'Instead, I advise this plan: Let all Israel gather to you, from Dan all the way to Beersheba, as countless as the sand of the sea. And you, personally, with your army, should go into battle at the head of them.'

verses.latin: Et veniemus ad eum in quocumque loco fuerit, et irruemus super eum sicut cadit ros super terram: et non relinquemus de viris qui sunt cum eo, ne unum quidem.
verses.english: 'Then we will come upon him wherever he may be, and we will fall upon him as the dew falls upon the ground. And we will not leave even one of the men who are with him alive.'

verses.latin: Si autem in aliqua civitate fuerit ingressus, circumdabimus civitatem illam universus Israël, et trahemus ad torrentem lapides omnes, donec ne unus quidem lapillus inveniatur ibi.
verses.english: 'But if he has entered into some city, then all of Israel will surround that city, and we will drag all of its stones into the river, until not even one small stone can be found there.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem, ut Absalom et omnes viri Israël dicerent: Melius est consilium Husai Arachitæ consilio Achitophel. Domini autem nutu dissipatum est consilium Achitophel utile, ut inferret Dominus super Absalom malum.
verses.english: And it came to pass that Absalom and all the men of Israel said: 'The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Achitophel.' But it was by the will of the Lord that Achitophel's useful counsel was defeated, so that the Lord might bring evil upon Absalom.

verses.latin: Dixitque Husai Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotibus: Hujuscemodi et hujuscemodi consilium dedit Achitophel Absalom, et senioribus Israël: et hujuscemodi consilium dedi ego.
verses.english: Hushai then said to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: 'Achitophel gave such and such counsel to Absalom and to the elders of Israel. And I gave such and such counsel.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo cito mittite et nuntiate David, dicentes: Noli morari nocte hac in campestribus deserti, sed cito transi, ne forte absorbeatur rex, et omnis populus qui cum eo est.
verses.english: 'Now therefore, quickly send a message and report to David, saying: 'Do not stay this night in the desert plains, but cross over quickly, lest perhaps the king and all the people who are with him be swallowed up.''

verses.latin: Jonathan autem et Achimaas stabant juxta fontem Rogel: ibat quoque puella, et nuntiabat eis, et illi ibant, et nuntiabant regi David: non enim poterant videri, aut introire civitatem.
verses.english: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were standing by the spring of Rogel. A servant girl would go and report to them, and they would then go and report to King David. For they could not be seen entering the city.

verses.latin: Vidit autem eos puer quidam, et indicavit Absalom: illi vero festinarunt, et ingressi sunt domum viri cujusdam Bahurim, qui habebat puteum in vestibulo suo, et descenderunt in eum.
verses.english: However, a certain young man saw them and reported it to Absalom. But Jonathan and Ahimaaz hurried and entered the house of a certain man in Bahurim, who had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it.

verses.latin: Tulitque mulier, et expandit velamen super os putei, quasi siccans pilos: et sic latuit sermo.
verses.english: And the woman took a covering and spread it over the mouth of the well, as if she were drying grain on it. And in this way the message was hidden.

verses.latin: Cumque venissent servi Absalom ad mulierem in domum, dixerunt: Ubi est Achimaas et Jonathan? Et respondit mulier: Transierunt rigulum aquæ. Et cum quæsisset et minime reperisset, reversa est in Jerusalem.
verses.english: When Absalom's servants came to the woman at the house, they said: 'Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?' And the woman replied: 'They have crossed the stream of water.' And when they had searched and found them nowhere, they returned to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Post quorum recessum, ascenderunt de puteo, et abierunt, nuntiaveruntque regi David, et dixerunt: Consurgite, et transite cito aquas: quoniam hujuscemodi initum est consilium contra vos ab Achitophel.
verses.english: After their departure, Jonathan and Ahimaaz came up out of the well and went and reported to King David, and they said: 'Rise up and cross the waters quickly! For Achitophel has begun to devise such and such counsel against you.'

verses.latin: Surrexit ergo David, et omnis populus qui erat cum eo: et transierunt Jordanem, donec dilucesceret: et ne unus quidem superfuit, qui non transisset Jordanem.
verses.english: So David arose, and all the people who were with him. And they crossed the Jordan River until dawn. Not even one person remained who had not crossed the Jordan.

verses.latin: Porro Achitophel videns quoniam non esset secutum consilium suum, strinxit frænum asini sui, et surrexit, et abiit in domum suam, et in civitatem suam: et suspendio semetipsum necavit, et mortuus est, et sepultus in sepulchro patris sui.
verses.english: Now Achitophel, seeing that his counsel had not been followed, saddled his donkey and arose, and went to his house and to his city. And he hanged himself, and so he died, and was buried in the tomb of his father.

verses.latin: David autem venit in Manahaim: porro Absalom transiit Jordanem, et omnis vir Israël cum eo.
verses.english: But David came to Mahanaim. Furthermore, Absalom crossed the Jordan River, and all the men of Israel were with him.

verses.latin: Amasam vero constituit Absalom pro Joab super exercitum: Amasa autem filius viri qui vocabatur Jethra de Israël, qui ingressus est ad Abigal filiam Naas, sororem Sarviæ, quæ fuit mater Joab.
verses.english: Absalom indeed appointed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. Amasa was the son of a man named Jether, from Israel, who had gone in to Abigail, the daughter of Nahash, the sister of Zeruiah, who was Joab's mother.

verses.latin: Et castrametatus est Israël cum Absalom in terra Galaad.
verses.english: And Israel, with Absalom, encamped in the land of Gilead.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset David in Manahaim, Sobi filius Naas de Rabath filiorum Ammon, et Machir filius Ammiel de Lodabar, et Berzellai Galaadites de Rogelim,
verses.english: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash, from Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite, from Rogelim,

verses.latin: obtulerunt ei culcitras, et tapetia, et vasa fictilia, et triticum, et hordeum, et farinam, et polentam, et fabas, et lentem,
verses.english: brought him mattresses, and blankets, and earthenware vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched grain, and beans, and lentils,

verses.latin: Et mel, et butyrum, et oves, et vaccas armenti, dederunt David et populo qui cum eo erat, ut comederent: suspicati enim sunt, quod populus esuriret et defatigatus, et sitiens veniret in desertum.
verses.english: And honey, and butter, and sheep, and cows from the herd. They gave these to David and to the people who were with him, so that they might eat. For they suspected that the people would be hungry, exhausted, and thirsty, having come into the wilderness.

verses.latin: Et recensuit David populum suum, et constituit super eos tribunos, et centuriones.
verses.english: David then reviewed his army and appointed commanders and officers over them.

verses.latin: Et misit David tertiam partem populi sub manu Joab, et tertiam partem sub manu Abisai filii Sarviae fratris Joab, et tertiam partem sub manu Ethai Gethaei: et ait David ad populum: Euntes, egredimini, et vobiscum egrediar.
verses.english: David sent one third of the army under the command of Joab. Another third he sent under the command of Abishai, Joab's brother and son of Zeruiah. And the last third he sent under the command of Ittai the Gittite. David said to the whole army, "I will also march out with you."

verses.latin: Et respondit populus: Non egredieris: si enim fugerimus, non magnopere ad eos pertinebit: sive media pars nostrum ceciderit, non curabunt: nunc enim decem millia sumus, et tu quasi unus es. Melius est igitur ut auxiliere nobis de civitate.
verses.english: But the army replied, "You must not go out with us! For if we have to flee, the enemy will not care about us. And if half of us fall in battle, they will not care. But you, our king, are like ten thousand of us! It is better for you to stay in the city and help us from there."

verses.latin: Et ait ad eos rex: Quod vobis videtur, hoc faciam. Et stetit rex juxta portam: universusque populus egressus est per centurias et per millia.
verses.english: The king said to them, "Whatever seems best to you, this I will do." So the king stood by the city gate. And the entire army marched out in groups of hundreds and thousands.

verses.latin: Et praecepit rex Joab, et Abisai, et Ethai, dicens: Servate mihi puerum Absalom. Audiente omnis populo praecepit rex cunctis ducibus de Absalom.
verses.english: The king commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, "Deal gently, for my sake, with the young man Absalom." And all the people heard the king give this order about Absalom to all the commanders.

verses.latin: Itaque egressus est populus in campum contra Israël, et facta est pugna in saltu Ephraim.
verses.english: So the army went out into the open field against the army of Israel. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.

verses.latin: Et caesus est ibi populus Israël ab exercitu David, stragesque magna facta est in die illa viginti millium virorum.
verses.english: There, the army of Israel was defeated by David's soldiers. A great slaughter happened that day, with twenty thousand men killed.

verses.latin: Factaque est ibi pugna dispersa per omnem faciem terrae: et multo plures quos consumpserat silva, quam quos interfecerat gladius.
verses.english: The battle spread across the entire region, and the dense forest killed more people than the sword.

verses.latin: Accidit autem ut obvius fieret Absalom servis David, sedens mulus: et cum ingressus esset mulus sub spissum quercus rami, adhaesit caput ejus quercui: et pependit inter caelum et terram, mulo, super quem sedebat, translatis.
verses.english: Absalom happened to encounter David's men. Absalom was riding a mule, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a great oak tree, Absalom's head got caught in the oak. He was left hanging between the sky and the earth, while the mule he was riding continued on its way.

verses.latin: Et vidit vir quidam, et nuntiavit Joab, dicens: Vidi Absalom pendere in quercu.
verses.english: A certain man saw this and reported it to Joab, saying, "I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree."

verses.latin: Et ait Joab viro qui nuntiaverat ei: Si vidisti, quare non confodisti eum terra, et ego dedissem tibi decem argenti siclos, et balteum unum?
verses.english: Joab said to the man who reported it to him, "If you saw him, why didn't you strike him to the ground? I would have given you ten silver shekels and a military belt."

verses.latin: Et ait vir ad Joab: Si etiam appendisses mille argenti siclos in manu mea, non extenderem manum meam in filium regis: audientibus enim nobis, praecepit rex tibi, et Abisai, et Ittai, dicens: Custodite, ne quis laedat puerum Absalom.
verses.english: The man replied to Joab, "Even if you had weighed out a thousand silver shekels into my hand, I would not have laid a hand on the king's son. In our hearing, the king commanded you, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, 'Guard the young man Absalom, so that no one harms him.'"

verses.latin: Et si feci insidias contra animam meam, et hoc non poterat regem celari, et tu stetisses ex adverso.
verses.english: "If I had done such a treacherous thing against his life, the king would surely have found out, and you yourself would have stood against me."

verses.latin: Et ait Joab: Non sic sed potius pergam, et coram te faciam. Tulitque tres lanceas in manu sua, et infixit in corde Absalom: cum adhuc palpitaret, et viveret.
verses.english: Joab said, "I will not wait like this. I will deal with him myself, right here in front of you." He took three javelins in his hand and plunged them into Absalom's heart while he was still struggling and alive.

verses.latin: Et circumsteterunt eum decem juvenes armigeri Joab, percusseruntque Absalom, et interfecerunt eum.
verses.english: Then ten young men, Joab's armor-bearers, surrounded Absalom. They struck him and finished killing him.

verses.latin: Caecinit autem Joab buccina, et retinuit populum, ne persequeretur fugientes Israël, quia voluit Joab parcere populo.
verses.english: Joab then blew the trumpet, signaling an end to the pursuit, and held back the army from chasing the fleeing Israelites. Joab wanted to spare the people.

verses.latin: Tuleruntque Absalom, et projecerunt eum in foveam grandem in silva, et complerunt super eum acervum lapidum magnum valde: omnis autem Israël fugit in tabernacula sua.
verses.english: They took Absalom and threw him into a large pit in the forest, and piled a very large heap of stones over him. Then all the remaining soldiers of Israel fled to their tents.

verses.latin: Absalom autem, cum adhuc viveret, erexerat sibi titulum, qui est in valle regis: dixerat enim: Non habeo filium, et hoc est monumentum nominis mei. Vocavitque titulum nomine suo, et appellatur manus Absalom, usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: Now Absalom, during his lifetime, had erected a monument for himself in the King's Valley. He had said, "I have no son to keep my name alive." So he named the monument after himself, and it is called Absalom's Monument to this very day.

verses.latin: Achimaas autem filius Sadoc, ait: Curram, et nuntiabo regi quia judicium fecerit Dominus de inimicis ejus.
verses.english: Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, then said, "I will run and bring the news to the king that the Lord has avenged him against his enemies."

verses.latin: Cui ait Joab: Non es vir nuntii hujus in die hac, sed nuntiabis in alia die: hodie noli nuntiare, quia filius regis mortuus est.
verses.english: Joab said to him, "You are not the right messenger for this news today. You may deliver a message another day, but today do not carry news, because the king's son is dead."

verses.latin: Et ait Joab Cusi: Vade, et nuntia regi quae vidisti. Adoravit Cusi Joab, et cucurrit.
verses.english: Then Joab said to a Cushite, "Go and tell the king what you have seen." The Cushite bowed to Joab and ran off.

verses.latin: Et adhuc addens Achimaas filius Sadoc, ait ad Joab: Quod si curram post Cusi? Cui ait Joab: Quare curris fili mi? non est tibi merces bona nuntii.
verses.english: Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, still insisted and said to Joab, "But what if I run after the Cushite?" Joab replied, "Why do you want to run, my son? You will not be rewarded for this news."

verses.latin: At ille: Quid enim, ait, si cucurrero? Cui ille dixit: Curre. Cucurrit ergo Achimaas per viam compendii, et transivit Cusi.
verses.english: "Regardless," he replied, "I will run!" So Joab said, "Go, run!" Ahimaaz then ran by way of the plain, which was a shortcut, and he overtook the Cushite.

verses.latin: David autem sedebat inter duas portas: et speculatur custos super turris fastigium portae. Et prospiciens vidit hominem currentem solum.
verses.english: Now David was sitting between the two gates of the city. A watchman was positioned on the roof of the gate's tower, and as he looked out, he saw a man running alone.

verses.latin: Et exclamans indicavit regi. Et ait rex: Si solus est, bonum nuntium portat. Properante autem illo, et appropinquante.
verses.english: The watchman cried out and informed the king. The king said, "If he is alone, he brings good news." As the runner quickly approached,

verses.latin: Vidit custos alterum hominem currentem, et clamavit super portam, dicens: Ecce alter homo currit solus. Et ait rex: Et iste bonus est nuntius.
verses.english: The watchman saw another man running and called out to the gatekeeper, "Look, another man is running alone!" The king said, "He also brings good news."

verses.latin: Et ait custos: Gressum primi ego recognosco, incessum Achimaas filii Sadoc. Et ait rex: Bonus vir est, et bonum nuntium portans venit.
verses.english: The watchman said, "I recognize the running style of the first man; it is the stride of Ahimaaz, Zadok's son." The king said, "He is a good man, and he comes with good news."

verses.latin: Clamavit autem Achimaas, et ait ad regem: Omnia bene. Et adorans regem prono in terram vultu, ait: Benedictus Dominus Deus tuus, qui conclusit homines qui levaverunt manus suas contra dominum meum regem.
verses.english: Ahimaaz called out to the king, "All is well!" He bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, "Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who lifted their hands against my lord the king!"

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Estne pax puero Absalom? Et ait Achimaas: Vidi turbam magnam, cum mitteret Joab servum regis tuum, et me servum tuum: nescio aliud.
verses.english: The king asked, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Ahimaaz replied, "I saw a great commotion when Joab sent your servant, the king's servant, and me. But I do not know what it was about."

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Transi, et sta hic. Et cum transisset, et staret.
verses.english: The king said, "Step aside and stand over here." So he stepped aside and stood.

verses.latin: Et ecce Cusi pervenit: et ait Cusi: Audiat dominus meus rex nuntium, quia judicavit Dominus hodie tibi de omnibus qui surrexerunt contra te.
verses.english: Then, the Cushite arrived. The Cushite said, "Let my lord the king hear the news! For the Lord has avenged you today against all who rose up against you!"

verses.latin: Et ait rex ad Cusi: Estne pax puero Absalom? Et respondens Cusi, ait: Fiunt sicut puer, inimici domini mei regis, et universi qui consurgunt adversum te in malum.
verses.english: The king asked the Cushite, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" The Cushite answered, "May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you with evil intent, become like that young man."

verses.latin: Contristatus itaque rex, ascendit coenaculum portae, et flevit. Et sic loquens ambulabat: fili mi Absalom, fili mi, fili mi Absalom: quis mihi tribuat, ut ego moriar pro te, Absalom fili mi, fili mi Absalom?
verses.english: The king was deeply distressed. He went up to the upper room of the gate and wept. As he walked, he kept saying, "My son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!"

verses.latin: Et numeravit David populum, qui secum erat: et constituit super eos tribunos, et centuriones.
verses.english: David then gathered all the men who were with him. He organized them into an army and appointed commanders over thousands of men and captains over hundreds.

verses.latin: Et misit David tertiam partem populi sub manu Joab, et tertiam partem sub manu Abisai filii Sarviae fratris Joab, et tertiam partem sub manu Ethai Gethaei: et dixit rex ad populum: Egrediar et ego vobiscum.
verses.english: David then divided his fighting men into three parts. One third was under the command of Joab. Another third was under the command of Abishai, Joab’s brother, the son of Zeruiah. The final third was under the command of Ittai the Gittite. The king then spoke to the men, saying, 'I will also go out to fight with you, personally leading the charge.'

verses.latin: Et respondit populus: Non egredieris: si enim fugerimus, non multum de nobis curabunt: vel si media pars ceciderit nostrum, non satis ad nos pertinere videbitur: quoniam tu unus instar decem millium es: melius est ergo ut auxilium praestes nobis de civitate.
verses.english: The men replied, 'No, you must not go with us. If we were forced to retreat, the enemy would not care much about us. And if half of us were to fall in battle, it would not be of great concern to them. This is because you, our King, are worth ten thousand of us. Therefore, it is far better that you stay within the city and give us support from there.'

verses.latin: Et ait ad eos rex: Quod vobis videtur, hoc faciam. Et stetit rex juxta portam: et omnis populus egressus est per centurias et per millenas.
verses.english: The king said to them, 'I will do whatever seems best to you.' So the king stood beside the gate of the city. All the men then marched out, organized by their hundreds and by their thousands, ready for battle.

verses.latin: Et praecepit rex Joab, et Abisai, et Ethai, dicens: Servate mihi puerum Absalom. Et omnis populus audivit regem praecipientem cunctis principibus de Absalom.
verses.english: The king then gave an order to Joab, Abishai, and Ittai. He said, 'For my sake, deal gently with the young man Absalom.' All the fighting men heard the king giving this instruction to all his commanders concerning Absalom.

verses.latin: Itaque egressus est populus in campum contra Israel, et factum est praelium in saltu Ephraim.
verses.english: So the men of David went out into the field against the rebel army of Israel. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.

verses.latin: Et caesus est ibi populus Israel a servis David, et facta est ibi plaga magna in die illa viginti millium virorum.
verses.english: There, the army of Israel was defeated by David’s servants. On that day, a great slaughter occurred, with twenty thousand men being killed.

verses.latin: Fuitque ibi prostratum certamen in omni superficie terrae: et multo plures quos gladius devorarat, silva consumpserat in die illa, quam quos inebriarat pugna.
verses.english: The battle spread out across the entire face of the land. More men were killed by the forest itself—by its dangers and confusion—than were consumed by the sword in the fighting that day.

verses.latin: Accidit autem ut irrueret Absalom in servos David, sedens mulam: cumque subisset mula sub concavam quercum magnam, adhaesit caput ejus quercui: et retentus est inter caelum et terram, mula autem, cui insederat, pertransiit.
verses.english: It happened that Absalom came upon David’s servants while riding a mule. The mule went under a large, low-hanging oak tree, and Absalom’s head became entangled in the branches of the oak. He was left suspended there between the sky and the ground, while the mule he had been riding continued on its way.

verses.latin: Vidit autem hoc vir quidam, et nuntiavit Joab, dicens: Vidi Absalom pendere in quercu.
verses.english: A certain man saw this occur and reported it to Joab, saying, 'I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree.'

verses.latin: Et ait Joab: Si vidisti, quare non confodisti eum terrae, et ego dedissem tibi decem argenti siclos, et balteum unum?
verses.english: Joab replied, 'If you saw him, why didn’t you strike him down to the ground right there? I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a military belt as a reward.'

verses.latin: Et respondit vir ad Joab: Si appendisses in manibus meis mille argenti siclos, non extenderem manum meam in filium regis: audientibus enim nobis, praecepit rex tibi, et Abisai, et Ethai, dicens: Custodite, ne quis tangat puerum Absalom.
verses.english: The man answered Joab, 'Even if you were to weigh out a thousand shekels of silver into my hands, I would not lift my hand against the king’s son. For we all heard the king give you, Abishai, and Ittai this command: ‘Be careful that no one harms the young man Absalom.’'

verses.latin: Neque enim pro salute mea auderem contra salutem tuam, et hoc ipsum latere regem non posset: et tu stares ex adverso.
verses.english: Truly, I would not risk my own life by daring to disregard your orders—and the king would surely find out about this. In that case, you yourself would stand against me for disobeying the king.

verses.latin: Et ait Joab: Non sic, sed irruam in conspectu tuo. Et tulit tres lanceas in manu sua, et perfodit cor Absalom cum adhuc viveret, et haereret in quercu.
verses.english: Joab then said, 'That is not how this will end. I will act in your presence!' He took three spears in his hand and thrust them into Absalom’s heart while Absalom was still alive and hanging in the oak tree.

verses.latin: Et circuierunt decem juvenes armigeri Joab, percusseruntque Absalom, et interfecerunt eum.
verses.english: Then ten young men, who were Joab’s armor-bearers, surrounded Absalom. They struck him again and killed him, ensuring his death.

verses.latin: Et cecinit Joab buccina, et retinuit populum, ne persequeretur Israel fugientem: voluit enim Joab parcere populo.
verses.english: Joab then blew the trumpet, signaling an end to the pursuit. He stopped the men from chasing the fleeing Israelites, for Joab wanted to spare the people of Israel from further slaughter.

verses.latin: Et tulerunt Absalom, et projecerunt eum in silva in foveam grandem, et congecerunt super eum acervum lapidum magnum valde: omnis autem Israel fugit in tabernacula sua.
verses.english: Then David’s men took Absalom and threw his body into a large pit in the forest. They piled a very great heap of stones over him, marking his dishonorable grave. Meanwhile, all the remaining men of Israel who had fought for Absalom fled to their homes and tents.

verses.latin: Absalom autem cum adhuc viveret, erexerat sibi titulum, qui est in valle regis: dixerat enim: Non habeo filium, et hoc erit monumentum nominis mei. Vocavitque titulum nomine suo, et appellatur usque in praesentem diem, manus Absalom.
verses.english: Now, while Absalom was still alive, he had erected a pillar for himself in the King’s Valley. He had said, 'I have no son to keep my name alive, so this pillar will be a monument to my name.' He named the pillar after himself, and it is called to this very day, 'Absalom’s Monument.'

verses.latin: Achimaas vero filius Sadoc, ait: Curram, et nuntiabo regi quia judicium fecerit Dominus de manu inimicorum ejus.
verses.english: Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, 'I will run now and bring news to the king—that the Lord has given him victory over his enemies.'

verses.latin: Et ait illi Joab: Non eris nuntius in hac die, sed nuntiabis in alia die: hodie nolo te nuntium facere, quia filius regis mortuus est.
verses.english: But Joab said to him, 'You will not be the messenger today. You may be a messenger on another day, but I do not want you to be the messenger today, because the king’s son is dead, and the news will bring him great sorrow.'

verses.latin: Et ait Joab Chusi: Vade, et nuntia regi quae vidisti. Adoravit Chusi Joab, et cucurrit.
verses.english: Joab then said to a Cushite man, 'Go, tell the king what you have seen.' The Cushite bowed to Joab and quickly ran off.

verses.latin: Adjecit rursum Achimaas filius Sadoc, dicens ad Joab: Quid prohibet si et ego curram post Chusi? Et ait Joab: Quare curris, fili mi? non habes bonum nuntium.
verses.english: Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, again urged Joab, saying, 'What prevents me from running after the Cushite man as well?' Joab replied, 'Why would you run, my son? You will not be bringing good news.'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Quid enim si curram? Et dixit illi: Curre. Cucurrit ergo Achimaas per viam campestrem, et praegressus est Chusi.
verses.english: Ahimaaz answered, 'Even so, what if I simply run?' And Joab said to him, 'Then run!' So Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and outran the Cushite man.

verses.latin: David autem sedebat inter duas portas: et speculator abiit super tectum portae juxta murum, cumque sublevasset oculos suos, et vidisset hominem currentem solum,
verses.english: Now David was sitting between the two inner and outer gates of the city. A lookout man had gone up to the roof of the gate by the wall. When he lifted his eyes and saw a man running alone toward them,

verses.latin: exclamavit, et nuntiavit regi: et ait rex: Si solus est, bonum nuntium portat. Properante autem illo, et accedente propius,
verses.english: he called out and informed the king. The king said, 'If he is alone, then he is bringing good news.' As the man hurried and came closer,

verses.latin: vidit speculator alterum hominem currentem, et clamavit primus speculator ad regem, dicens: Alter homo currit solus. Et ait rex: Et iste bonus est nuntius.
verses.english: the lookout saw another man running. The first lookout called out to the king, saying, 'Look, another man is running alone!' The king replied, 'He, too, is bringing good news.'

verses.latin: Et dixit speculator: Judico cursum prioris, quasi cursum Achimaas filii Sadoc. Et ait rex: Bonus vir est hic, et bonum nuntium portans venit.
verses.english: The lookout then said, 'I recognize the running style of the first man; it is like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.' The king said, 'He is a good man, and he comes bringing good tidings.'

verses.latin: Clamavit autem Achimaas, et ait ad regem: Salve, rex. Et adorans regem prono in terram vultu, ait: Benedictus Dominus Deus tuus, qui conclusit homines, qui levaverunt manus suas contra dominum meum regem.
verses.english: Ahimaaz then called out and said to the king, 'All is well, O king!' He bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, 'Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who raised their hands against my lord the king!'

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Estne pax puero Absalom? Et respondit Achimaas: Vidi tumultum magnum, cum mitteret Joab servum tuum, rex, me minimum tuum: nescio aliud.
verses.english: The king asked, 'Is the young man Absalom safe?' Ahimaaz answered, 'I saw a great commotion when Joab, your servant, was sending me, your humble servant. I do not know what else happened beyond that.'

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Transi, et sta hic. Et transiit, et stetit.
verses.english: The king said, 'Stand aside here.' So Ahimaaz stepped aside and stood still.

verses.latin: Et ecce Chusi venit: et ait: Audiat dominus meus rex, quoniam rex hodie judicavit te de manu omnium qui surrexerunt adversum te.
verses.english: And behold, the Cushite man arrived. He said, 'Let my lord the king hear the news! For the Lord has today granted you justice by delivering you from the hand of all who rose up against you!'

verses.latin: Et ait rex ad Chusi: Estne pax puero Absalom? Et respondit Chusi: Fiunt sicut puer, inimici domini mei regis, et omnes qui consurgunt adversum te in malum.
verses.english: The king asked the Cushite man, 'Is the young man Absalom safe?' The Cushite answered, 'May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you with evil intent, be as that young man is now.'

verses.latin: Conturbatus est itaque rex, et ascendit coenaculum portae, et flevit. Et sic loquens ambulabat: Fili mi Absalom, fili mi, fili mi Absalom: quis mihi tribuat, ut ego moriar pro te, Absalom fili mi, fili mi?
verses.english: The king was deeply shaken and distressed. He went up to the room above the gate and wept. As he walked, he spoke, saying, 'My son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!'

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem Joab quod rex fleret, et lugeret super Absalom.
verses.english: It was reported to Joab that the king was weeping, and openly mourning over Absalom.

verses.latin: Et versum est gaudium in luctum omni populo in die illa: audivit enim populus quod rex contristaretur super filio suo.
verses.english: And so, all the joy of the people on that day turned into deep mourning, for everyone heard that the king was heartbroken over his son.

verses.latin: Et turbabatur populus tacitus ingrediens civitatem in die illa, sicut turbari solet exercitus fugiens, et confusus.
verses.english: The people were unsettled; they entered the city in silence on that day. They were as disquieted as an army that has been defeated, and then flees in shame and confusion.

verses.latin: Clamabat ergo rex magna voce: Fili mi Absalom, Absalom fili mi, fili mi!
verses.english: The king kept crying out in a loud voice: “My son Absalom, Absalom my son, my son!”

verses.latin: Ingressus ergo Joab ad regem in domum ejus, ait: Confusus es hodie vultus omnium servorum tuorum, qui salvam fecerunt hodie animam tuam, et animas filiorum tuorum, et filiarum tuarum, et animas uxorum tuarum, et animas concubinarum tuarum.
verses.english: So Joab entered the king’s house, and said to him: “Today, you have made all of your servants ashamed. These are the men who, on this very day, saved your life, and the lives of your sons, and your daughters, and your wives, and your concubines.

verses.latin: Diligis odientes te, et odio habes diligentes te. Et ostendisti hodie quia non curas de ducibus tuis, et de servis tuis. Et vere cognovi hodie, quia si Absalom viveret, et omnes nos occubuissemus, tunc placeret tibi.
verses.english: You love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. You have shown today that you have no concern for your commanders or for your servants. I truly know this day that if Absalom were alive, and all of us had died, then it would please you.

verses.latin: Et nunc surge, et egredere, et alloquere satisfactionem servis tuis: juro enim tibi per Dominum, quia si non exieris, ne unus quidem manebit tecum nocte hac: et erit hoc pejus tibi quam omnia mala quæ sunt tibi adepta a pueritia tua usque in præsentem diem.
verses.english: Now get up, go out, and speak words of comfort to your servants. For I swear to you by the Lord, if you do not go out, not even one man will remain with you tonight. And this will be worse for you than all the evils that have befallen you from your youth until this present day.”

verses.latin: Surrexit ergo rex, et sedit in porta: et nuntiatum est universo populo quod rex sederet in porta: et venit universus populus coram rege.
verses.english: So the king rose up, and he sat at the city gate. And it was announced to all the people that the king was sitting at the gate. Then all the people came before the king.

verses.latin: Israel autem fugerat unusquisque in tabernacula sua.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the army of Israel had fled, each man to his own tent, their homes.

verses.latin: Omnisque populus certabat in cunctis tribubus Israël, dicens: Rex liberavit nos de manu inimicorum nostrorum, et ipse eruit nos de manu Philisthinorum, et nunc fugerat de terra propter Absalom:
verses.english: And all the people were contending in all the tribes of Israel, saying: “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies. He himself rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. And now he has fled from the land because of Absalom.

verses.latin: Absalom autem, quem unxeramus super nos, mortuus est in prælio. Nunc ergo quare siletis, et non reducitis regem?
verses.english: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us as king, is dead in battle. Now then, why are you silent? Why are you not bringing the king back?”

verses.latin: Rex autem David misit ad Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotes, dicens: Loquimini ad majores natu Judæ, dicentes: Cur sedetis novissimi de reducendum rege in domum suam?
verses.english: But King David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying: “Speak to the elders of Judah, saying: ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house?

verses.latin: Vos fratres mei estis, os meum, et caro mea vos estis: quare novissimi estis reducendi regis?
verses.english: You are my brothers, my very own flesh and blood. Why should you be the last to bring the king back?

verses.latin: Et Amasæ dicite: Nonne tu os meum, et caro mea es? Hæc faciat mihi Deus, et hæc addat, si non fueris princeps militiæ meæ omnibus diebus pro Joab.
verses.english: And to Amasa you shall say: ‘Are you not my very own flesh and blood? May God do such to me, and add more to it, if you are not the commander of my army for all days in place of Joab.’ ”

verses.latin: Et inclinavit cor omnium virorum Judæ quasi viri unius: et miserunt ad regem, dicentes: Revertere tu et omnes servi tui.
verses.english: And David swayed the hearts of all the men of Judah as if they were one man. So they sent word to the king, saying: “Return, you and all your servants.”

verses.latin: Et reversus est rex, venitque usque ad Jordanem: et Juda venerat in Galgala obviam regi, ut transducere eum vellet Jordanem.
verses.english: So the king returned, and came as far as the Jordan River. And Judah had come to Gilgal to meet the king, so that they might escort him across the Jordan.

verses.latin: Festinavit autem Semei filius Gera, filii Jemini, de Bahurim, et descendit cum viris Juda obviam regi David,
verses.english: Then Shimei, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.

verses.latin: et mille viri de Benjamin cum eo: et Siba puer domus Saul, et quindecim filii ejus, et viginti servi ejus cum eo: et irruerunt Jordanem ante regem.
verses.english: There were a thousand men of Benjamin with him. Also, Ziba, the servant of Saul’s house, and his fifteen sons, and his twenty servants were with him. And they rushed into the Jordan ahead of the king.

verses.latin: Et transierunt navigio ut traducerent domum regis, et facerent juxta jussionem ejus. Semei quoque filius Gera prostratus coram rege, cum jam transisset Jordanem,
verses.english: They crossed the river by ferry boat to carry over the king’s household and to do whatever he commanded. Shimei also, the son of Gera, prostrated himself before the king when he had just crossed the Jordan.

verses.latin: dixit ad regem: Ne reputes mihi, domine mi, iniquitatem, neque in memoriam redeat quæ perverse feci servus tuus, in die qua egressus es Domine mi rex de Jerusalem: neque pones rex in corde tuo.
verses.english: He said to the king: “My lord, do not hold my iniquity against me. Let what your servant did perversely on the day my Lord the King departed from Jerusalem not be remembered. Do not take it to heart, O King.

verses.latin: Agnovi enim servus tuus quod peccaverim: et idcirco ecce primus de omni domo Joseph descendri, et occurri tibi Domine mi rex.
verses.english: For your servant knows that I have sinned. And because of this, behold, I am the first of all the house of Joseph —meaning the northern tribes of Israel— to come down and meet you, my Lord the King.”

verses.latin: Respondens autem Abisai filius Sarviæ, dixit: Numquid super his non interficietur Semei, quia maledixit uncto Domini?
verses.english: But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, answered and said: “Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord’s anointed king?”

verses.latin: Et ait David: Quid mihi et vobis filii Sarviæ? Cur adversamini mihi hodie? Numquid hodie interficietur vir in Israël? an ignoratis quia hodie rex in Israël constitutus sum?
verses.english: And David said: “What have I to do with you, sons of Zeruiah? Why do you oppose me today? Shall any man be put to death in Israel today? Do you not know that today I have been established as king over Israel?”

verses.latin: Et ait rex ad Semei: Non morieris. Et juravit ei rex.
verses.english: And the king said to Shimei: “You shall not die.” And the king swore an oath to him.

verses.latin: Miphboseth quoque filius Saul de scendit obviam regi, et pedes laverat, nec toserat barbam, vestesque suas non laverat a die qua egressus fuerat rex fugiens usque ad diem reversionis suæ in pace.
verses.english: Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, also came down to meet the king. He had not washed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes from the day the king had departed in flight until the day he returned in peace.

verses.latin: Cumque salutasset regem, dixit ad eum rex: Quare non venisti mecum Miphboseth?
verses.english: When he had greeted the king, the king said to him: “Why did you not come with me, Mephibosheth?”

verses.latin: Qui respondens ait: Domine mi rex, servus meus contempsit me: dixi ei, Sternere mihi asinum, et ascendens vadam cum rege: claudus enim sum ego.
verses.english: And he answered, saying: “My Lord the king, my servant Ziba deceived me. For I said to him, ‘Saddle an ass for me, so I may ride on it and go with the king,’ for I am lame.

verses.latin: Et ipse mendaciter detraxit de me ad te dominum meum regem: tu autem domine mi rex, sicut angelus Dei es: fac quod placuerit tibi.
verses.english: And he —Ziba— has falsely slandered me to you, my lord the king. But you, my lord the king, are like an angel of God. Do what pleases you.

verses.latin: Neque enim fuit domus patris mei, nisi morti obnoxia domino meo regi: et posuisti me servum tuum inter convivas mensæ tuæ. Quod ergo justam causam habeo ut adhuc clamem ad regem?
verses.english: For indeed, the house of my father —Saul's house— was deserving of nothing but death from my lord the king. Yet you placed your servant among those who eat at your own table. So what just reason do I have to still complain to the king?”

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Quid ultra loqueris? Dixi: tu et Siba dividite possessiones.
verses.english: And the king said: “Why do you speak further? I have said: you and Ziba shall divide the land possessions.”

verses.latin: Dixitque Miphboseth ad regem: Etiam cuncta accipiat, postquam reversus est Dominus meus rex in domum suam in pace.
verses.english: Then Mephibosheth said to the king: “Indeed, let him —Ziba— take everything, now that my Lord the King has returned to his house in peace.”

verses.latin: Berzellai quoque Galaadites descendens de Rogelim, transduxit regem Jordanem, ut duceret eum, et reficeret in transitu suo.
verses.english: Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim, and he crossed the Jordan with the king to escort him and provide for him on his journey.

verses.latin: Erat autem Berzellai senex nimis, id est, annorum octoginta, et ipse præbuerat regi alimenta quando morabatur in castris: homo quippe opulentissimus erat.
verses.english: Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years of age. And he had provided sustenance for the king while he stayed at Mahanaim. For he was a very wealthy man.

verses.latin: Dixit itaque rex ad Berzellai: Veni mecum, ut reficiaris apud me in Jerusalem.
verses.english: So the king said to Barzillai: “Come with me, so that you may be cared for by me in Jerusalem.”

verses.latin: Et respondens Berzellai regi: Quot dierum sunt anni vitæ meæ, ut ascendam cum rege in Jerusalem?
verses.english: And Barzillai answered the king: “How many days are there in the years of my life, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?

verses.latin: Octoginta annorum sum hodie: numquid vivere potest ultra ad discernendum bonum an malum? an delectari potest servus tuus in cibo, aut in potu? an ultra audire potest vocem cantorum, vel cantatricum? quare est gravis servus tuus domino meo regi?
verses.english: I am eighty years old today. Can I still discern what is good or bad? Can your servant still delight in food or drink? Can I still hear the voice of male or female singers? Why should your servant be a burden to my Lord the King?

verses.latin: Pauxillum, ut transducat servus tuus regem Jordanem: non retribuas mihi hanc vicissitudinem.
verses.english: Let your servant just escort the king across the Jordan. Do not repay me with this kindness that I cannot fully appreciate.
