verses.latin: Sed revertatur servus tuus, et moriar in civitate mea, et sepeliar juxta sepulchrum patris mei, et matris meæ. Est autem servus tuus Chamaam: ipse vadat tecum domine mi rex, et fac ei quod tibi placuerit.
verses.english: But let your servant return, and I will die in my own city, and be buried beside the tomb of my father and my mother. However, your servant Chimham is here. Let him go with you, my Lord the King, and do for him whatever pleases you.”

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Mecum vadat Chamaam, et ego faciam ei quicquid tibi placuerit, et omne quod petieris a me, impetrabis.
verses.english: And the king said: “Let Chimham go with me, and I will do for him whatever pleases you. And anything you request of me, you shall obtain.”

verses.latin: Et transduxit omnis populus Jordanem, et rex in medio eorum: reversusque rex, venit in Galgala, et Chamaam cum eo. Omnis autem populus Judæ traduxerat regem, et media pars populi Israël.
verses.english: Then all the people crossed the Jordan, and the king was in their midst. And when the king returned, he came to Gilgal, and Chimham with him. All the people of Judah had escorted the king, and half of the people of Israel.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem Joab quod rex fleret et lugeret super Absalom.
verses.english: And it was reported to Joab that the king was weeping and mourning over Absalom.

verses.latin: Et versum est gaudium omne in luctum omni populo in die illa: audivit enim populus quod rex contristaretur super filio suo.
verses.english: And all the joy of the people turned into mourning on that day, because the people heard that the king was grieving deeply over his son.

verses.latin: Et ingrediebatur populus in die illa furtim in civitatem, sicut ingredi solet furtim populus et confusus, qui fugit de prælio.
verses.english: And the people entered the city in a stealthy manner on that day, just as a people who are ashamed and have fled from battle are accustomed to enter secretly.

verses.latin: Clamabat autem rex vultu velato, et grandi voce: Fili mi Absalom, Absalom fili mi, quis mihi tribuat ut ego moriar pro te, Absalom fili mi.
verses.english: But the king was crying out, with his face covered, and with a loud voice, saying: "My son Absalom, my son Absalom! Oh, that I had died for you, my son Absalom!"

verses.latin: Ingressus ergo Joab ad regem in domum, ait: Confudisti hodie vultus omnium servorum tuorum, qui pugnaverunt hodie pro anima tua, et pro animabus filiorum tuorum et filiarum tuarum, et pro animabus uxorum tuarum, et pro animabus concubinarum tuarum:
verses.english: So Joab came to the king in his house and said: "Today you have shamed the faces of all your servants who have fought today for your life, and for the lives of your sons and your daughters, and for the lives of your wives, and for the lives of your concubines."

verses.latin: diligis odientes te, et odio habes diligentes te. Et ostendisti hodie quia non curas de ducibus tuis et de servis tuis: et vere cognovi modo, quia si Absalom viveret, et omnes nos occubuissemus hodie, tunc placeret tibi.
verses.english: "You love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. And you have shown today that you care nothing for your commanders and your servants. Indeed, I know now that if Absalom were alive, and all of us had died today, then that would have pleased you."

verses.latin: Et nunc igitur surge, et egredere, et alloquere satisfactione servos tuos: juro enim tibi per Dominum, quod si non exieris, ne unus quidem manebit tecum nocte hac: et pejus erit hoc tibi, quam omnia mala quæ evenerunt tibi ab adolescentia tua usque in præsens.
verses.english: "So now, get up and go out, and speak words of comfort to your servants. For I swear to you by the Lord, that if you do not go out, not even one man will remain with you this night. And this will be worse for you than all the evils that have happened to you from your youth until now."

verses.latin: Surrexit itaque rex, et sedit in porta: et nuntiatum est universo populo quod rex sederet in porta: et venit omnis multitudo coram rege.
verses.english: So the king got up and sat in the city gate. And it was announced to all the people that the king was sitting in the gate. Then all the multitude came before the king.

verses.latin: Porro omnis Israel fugerat in tabernacula sua.
verses.english: Meanwhile, all of Israel had fled to their tents.

verses.latin: Omnis quoque populus certabat in cunctis tribubus Israel, dicens: Rex liberavit nos de manu inimicorum nostrorum, et ipse eruit nos de manu Philisthinorum, et nunc fugerat de terra propter Absalom.
verses.english: And all the people were contending throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying: "The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies, and he himself rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. And now he had been forced to flee from the land because of Absalom."

verses.latin: Absalom autem, quem unximus super nos, mortuus est in bello. Nunc ergo quare non facitis et reducetis regem?
verses.english: "But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now then, why do you not take steps to bring the king back?"

verses.latin: Rex autem David misit ad Sadoc et Abiathar sacerdotes, dicens: Loquimini ad majores natu Juda, dicentes: Quare novissimi estis ad reducendum regem in domum suam? sermo autem omnis Israel pervenerat ad regem in domum ejus.
verses.english: Now King David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying: "Speak to the elders of Judah, saying: 'Why are you the very last to bring the king back to his house?'" For the words of all Israel had reached the king in his house.

verses.latin: Et ad Amasa dicite: Numquid non os meum es, et caro mea? Hæc faciat mihi Deus, et hæc addat, si non fueris princeps militiæ meæ coram me omni tempore pro Joab.
verses.english: "And say to Amasa: 'Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me, and more also, if you are not commander of my army before me at all times instead of Joab.'"

verses.latin: Et inclinavit cor omnium virorum Juda quasi viri unius: et miserunt ad regem, dicentes: Revertere tu, et omnes servi tui.
verses.english: And he turned the heart of all the men of Judah as one man. So they sent word to the king, saying: "Return, you and all your servants."

verses.latin: Et reversus est rex, et venit usque ad Jordanem: et Juda venerat in Galgala obviam regi, ut transverteret eum Jordanem.
verses.english: So the king returned and came as far as the Jordan River. And Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king, to escort him across the Jordan.

verses.latin: Festinavit autem Semei filius Gera, filius Jemini de Bahurim, et descendit cum viris Juda obviam regi David,
verses.english: But Shimei, the son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.

verses.latin: et mille viri de Benjamin cum eo: Siba quoque puer domus Saul, et quindecim filii ejus, et viginti servi ejus cum eo: et irrumpentes Jordanem, præcedebant regem.
verses.english: And a thousand men of Benjamin were with him. Also Ziba, the servant of Saul's house, with his fifteen sons and twenty servants, were with him. And they rushed into the Jordan, going ahead of the king.

verses.latin: Et transierunt vada, ut traducerent domum regis, ac facerent juxta jussionem ejus: ipse vero Semei prosternens se coram rege, cum jam transisset Jordanem,
verses.english: And they crossed the ford to help the king's household cross over and to do whatever he commanded. And Shimei himself prostrated himself before the king, after the king had already crossed the Jordan.

verses.latin: dixit regi: Ne reputes mihi, domine mi, iniquitatem, neque hoc recognoscas quod inique gessi in die qua egressus es, domine mi, rex, de Jerusalem, nec in mente habeas, rex, cor tuum.
verses.english: He said to the king: "Do not count against me, my lord, this iniquity, nor remember what I did wickedly on the day when you departed from Jerusalem, my lord the king. Let your heart not bear a grudge, O king."

verses.latin: Quia ego servus tuus fateor peccatum meum: et idcirco en hodie primus de omni domus Joseph descendit, ut occurreret domino meo regi.
verses.english: "For I, your servant, confess my sin. And behold, for this reason, I am the first of all the house of Joseph — meaning the northern tribes of Israel — who has come down today to meet my lord the king."

verses.latin: Respondens autem Abisai filius Sarviæ, dixit: Ergone pro his, non interficietur Semei, qui maledixit uncto Domini?
verses.english: But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, answered and said: "Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord's anointed?"

verses.latin: Et ait David: Quid mihi et vobis, filii Sarviæ, ut sitis mihi hodie in adversarios? an hodie interficietur vir in Israel? an ignoro hodie quod rex constitutus sim super Israel?
verses.english: And David said: "What have I to do with you, sons of Zeruiah, that you should be adversaries to me today? Shall any man be put to death in Israel today? Do I not know today that I am established as king over Israel?"

verses.latin: Et dixit rex Semei: Non morieris. Et juravit ei rex.
verses.english: And the king said to Shimei: "You shall not die." And the king swore an oath to him.

verses.latin: Mefiboseth quoque filius Saul de scendit obviam regi: et erat in sordibus, et incultis pedibus, imbarbatus ex eo die quo egressus fuerat rex, usque ad diem reversionis suæ pacificæ.
verses.english: Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, also came down to meet the king. And he was in mourning, with unwashed feet and an untrimmed beard, from the day the king had departed until the day of his peaceful return.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset Jerusalem obviam regi, ait ei rex: Quare non venisti mecum Mefiboseth?
verses.english: When he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him: "Why did you not come with me, Mephibosheth?"

verses.latin: Qui respondens ait: Domine mi rex, servus meus contempsit me: dixeram illi ego, ut sterneret mihi asinum, et ascenderem et proficiscerer cum rege: nam claudus est servus tuus.
verses.english: He answered and said: "My lord the king, my servant Ziba despised me. For I said to him that he should saddle a donkey for me, so that I might ride upon it and go with the king, because your servant is lame."

verses.latin: Et ipse servus tuus calumniatus est me ad te, domine mi rex: tu autem rex, ut est angelus Dei, fac quod placuerit tibi.
verses.english: "And he himself, your servant Ziba, has slandered me to you, my lord the king. But you, O king, are like an angel of God; do what is pleasing to you."

verses.latin: Nihil enim erat ex omni domo patris mei, nisi tantum mortis reus ante te: et tu posuisti servum tuum inter convivas mensæ tuæ: quid igitur habeo justæ querelæ? aut quid possum ultra clamare ad regem?
verses.english: "For there was nothing from all my father's house but that which was worthy of death before you. Yet you placed your servant among those who eat at your table. What then do I have to complain about justly? Or what more can I cry out to the king?"

verses.latin: Et ait illi rex: Quid ultra loqueris? Ego dixi: Tu et Siba dividite possessiones.
verses.english: And the king said to him: "Why do you speak further? I have decided: You and Ziba divide the land."

verses.latin: Et respondit Mefiboseth regi: Etiam omnia accipiat, quoniam reversus est dominus meus rex in domum suam pacificus.
verses.english: And Mephibosheth answered the king: "Let him even take everything, since my lord the king has returned to his house in peace."

verses.latin: Berzellai quoque Galaadites descendens de Rogelim, traduxit regem Jordanem, ut proficisceretur cum eo trans Jordanem.
verses.english: Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim and accompanied the king across the Jordan, to go with him beyond the Jordan.

verses.latin: Erat autem Berzellai senex nimis, id est, octoginta annorum: et ipse sustentabat regem, cum moraretur in Masana: magnum quippe virum valde.
verses.english: Now Barzillai was very old, that is, eighty years old. And he himself had provided for the king while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very great man.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex ad Berzellai: Veni mecum, ut quiescas apud me in Jerusalem.
verses.english: And the king said to Barzillai: "Come with me, that you may rest with me in Jerusalem."

verses.latin: Et ait Berzellai ad regem: Quot sunt dies annorum vitæ meæ, ut ascendam cum rege in Jerusalem?
verses.english: And Barzillai said to the king: "How many are the days of the years of my life, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?"

verses.latin: Octoginta annorum sum hodie: numquid vivere potest ultra me, ut delectetur et tristetur? numquid videre potest servus tuus cibum et potum? numquid audire vocem cantorum et cantatricum ultra potero? quare provocas servum tuum ad omnia hæc onera?
verses.english: "I am eighty years old today. Can I still discern good from bad? Can your servant taste what I eat or drink? Can I still hear the voice of male and female singers? Why should your servant be a burden to you in all these things?"

verses.latin: Pausabit ad modicum servus tuus trans Jordanem: oro, ut revertar, et moriar in civitate mea, et sepeliar juxta sepulchrum patris mei et matris meæ. Est autem servus tuus Chamaam: ipse vadat tecum, domine mi rex, et fac ei quicquid tibi placuerit.
verses.english: "Your servant will only tarry a little while across the Jordan. I beg you, let me return and die in my own city, and be buried near the tomb of my father and my mother. Behold, your servant Chimham is here; let him go with you, my lord the king, and do for him whatever pleases you."

verses.latin: Et dixit rex: Tecum vadat Chamaam, et ego faciam ei quicquid tibi placuerit, et omne quod petieris a me, impetrabis.
verses.english: And the king said: "Let Chimham go with you, and I will do for him whatever pleases you, and everything you ask of me, you shall obtain."

verses.latin: Cumque transisset omnis populus Jordanem, et rex transiit: osculatus est rex Berzellai, et benedixit ei: et ille reversus est in locum suum.
verses.english: When all the people had crossed the Jordan, and the king also crossed over, the king kissed Barzillai and blessed him. And Barzillai returned to his own place.

verses.latin: Transivit ergo rex in Galgala, et Chamaam cum eo: omnis autem populus Juda traduxerat regem, et media pars populi Israel.
verses.english: So the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham with him. All the people of Judah had escorted the king, and half the people of Israel as well.

verses.latin: Et ecce, omnes viri Israel veniebant ad regem, dicentesque regi: Quare te furati sunt fratres nostri viri Juda, et traduxerunt regem, et domum ejus, et omnes viros David cum eo?
verses.english: And behold, all the men of Israel came to the king, saying to the king: "Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away and brought the king, and his household, and all the men of David with him, across the river?"

verses.latin: Et forte ibi erat vir Belial, nomine Seba filius Bochri, vir Jemini: et cecinit buccina, et ait: Non est nobis pars in David, neque haereditas in filio Isai: revertere unusquisque in tabernacula tua, Israel.
verses.english: And behold, there was a lawless man there, named Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite. This man blew a trumpet, and cried out, saying: "We have no portion with David, nor do we have any inheritance in the son of Jesse—that is, in David's lineage! Every man, return now to your own homes, O Israel!"

verses.latin: Et separatus est omnis Israel a David, et secutus est Seba filium Bochri: viri autem Juda adhaeserunt regi a Jordane usque Jerusalem.
verses.english: So all the other tribes of Israel withdrew their loyalty from David and followed Sheba, the son of Bichri. However, the men of Judah remained completely loyal to their king, from the Jordan River all the way to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset rex in domum suam Jerusalem, tulit rex decem mulieres concubinas suas, quas dereliquerat ad custodiendam domum: et reclusit eas in domos viduarum, praebens eis alimenta, et non ingressus est ad eas. Sed erant clausae usque ad diem mortis suae, viduitatis.
verses.english: When King David arrived at his house in Jerusalem, he took his ten concubine women whom he had left behind to watch over the palace during his flight. Because they had been defiled by Absalom, David placed them in a secluded house, like women in widowhood. He provided them with food and everything they needed, but he never had relations with them again. They remained shut away in this condition until the day they died, living as if they were true widows.

verses.latin: Et ait rex Amasae: Convocato mihi viro Juda in diebus tribus, et tu ipse adesto praesens.
verses.english: Then King David said to Amasa: "Summon all the men of Judah to assemble for me within three days, and make sure that you yourself are present."

verses.latin: Abiit ergo Amasa ut convocaret Judam: et moratus est ultra statutum tempus, quod ei praefinierat rex.
verses.english: So Amasa went out to summon Judah, but he delayed much longer than the time the king had set for him to return.

verses.latin: Dixit itaque David ad Abisai: Nunc magnus nobis erit infortunium a Seba filio Bochri, quam ab Absalom: tolle igitur servos domini tui, et persequere eum, ne forte occupet civitates munitas, et effugiat nos.
verses.english: Therefore, David said to Abishai: "Now Sheba, the son of Bichri, will do us more harm than Absalom ever did. Take therefore your master's servants—that is, my personal guard—and pursue him, lest he seize fortified cities and escape from us."

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo cum eo viri Joab, et Cherethi et Phelethi, et omnes robusti: et egressi sunt de Jerusalem ad persequendum Seba filium Bochri.
verses.english: So Joab's men went out with Abishai, along with the Cherethites, and the Pelethites—that is, David's elite guard—and all the strong warriors. They marched out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, the son of Bichri.

verses.latin: Cumque essent juxta magnum lapidem, qui est in Gabaon, Amasa veniit obviam eis. Porro Joab accinctus erat super veste sua stricto balteo juxta lumbos suos, et pugione incluso in vagina: egressusque pallium, protinus usque ad inferiorem partem succinxerat.
verses.english: As they were near the great stone that is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was girded with his military tunic over his usual garment, and around his waist was a tightly fastened belt with a dagger sheathed in it. As he went forward, the dagger immediately fell out of its sheath and to the lower part of his body—unbeknownst to Amasa, this was a deliberate maneuver.

verses.latin: Dixitque Joab ad Amasam: Salve mi frater. Et tenuit manu dextra mentum Amasae, quasi osculans eum.
verses.english: And Joab said to Amasa: "Greetings, my brother!" Then with his right hand, Joab took hold of Amasa's beard, as if to kiss him.

verses.latin: Porro Amasa non observavit gladium, quem habebat Joab in manu, et percussit eum in latere, et effudit intestina ejus in terram, nec secundum vulnus apposuit: statimque mortuus est. Et Joab, et Abisai frater ejus prosecuti sunt Seba filium Bochri.
verses.english: But Amasa did not notice the sword that Joab held in his left hand. With it, Joab struck him in the side, spilling his intestines out onto the ground. He did not need a second wound; Amasa died immediately. After this, Joab and Abishai, his brother, continued their pursuit of Sheba, the son of Bichri.

verses.latin: Et quidam de servis Joab, stans juxta Amasam, ait: Quis est pro Joab, et quis pro David, sequatur Joab.
verses.english: And one of Joab's servants, standing by Amasa's body, cried out: "Whoever is for Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!"

verses.latin: Amasa autem volutabatur in sanguine in media via. Viditque homo ille, quod omnis turba consisteret: et trahens Amasam de via in agrum, operuit eum vestimento, ne transeuntes cunctarentur propter eum.
verses.english: Now Amasa was writhing in his own blood in the middle of the road. That man saw that all the people were stopping because of the sight. So he dragged Amasa off the road into a field and covered him with a garment, so that passersby would not stop and hinder the pursuit because of him.

verses.latin: Remoto igitur eo de via, transierunt omnes viri sequentes Joab ad persequendum Seba filium Bochri.
verses.english: Once Amasa was removed from the road, all the men who were following Joab continued their march to pursue Sheba, the son of Bichri.

verses.latin: Transivit autem ille per omnes tribus Israel, et in Abelam et Bethmaacha, et omnes Viri: et congregati sunt universi, et ingressi sunt post eum.
verses.english: Sheba, however, passed through all the tribes of Israel, going to Abel of Beth-Maachah, and through all the communities of the Berites. There, all the people gathered and followed him.

verses.latin: Venit itaque Joab, et oppugnavit eum in Abela et in Bethmaacha, et circumdedit materiis, et fossis urbem: steteruntque omnes turbae, quae erant cum Joab, et everterunt muros.
verses.english: So Joab arrived and besieged Sheba in Abel of Beth-Maachah. They built a siege ramp and a trench around the city. Then all the troops who were with Joab took their positions and began to undermine the city walls.

verses.latin: Et clamavit mulier sapiens de civitate: Audite, audite: loquimini ad Joab: Appropinqua huc, et loquar tecum.
verses.english: Then a wise woman from the city called out: "Listen! Listen! Speak to Joab! Tell him to come closer, so I may speak with him."

verses.latin: Cumque appropinquasset, ait: Tu es Joab? Et ille respondit: Ego. Et illa: Audi verba ancillae tuae. Qui ait: Audio.
verses.english: When Joab approached, she asked: "Are you Joab?" He answered: "I am." And she said: "Hear the words of your handmaid." He replied: "I am listening."

verses.latin: Et inquit: Sermo vetus est, et dicitur: Qui interrogat in Abela, et sic completur.
verses.english: Then she spoke: "There is an old saying, and it is spoken: 'Whoever inquires in Abel, that is how the matter is resolved.'"

verses.latin: Ego sum de his quae interrogo et pacem sequor in Israel: et tu quæris subvertere civitatem, et evertere matrem in Israel: quare praecipitas haereditatem Domini?
verses.english: She continued: "I am among those who seek counsel and pursue peace in Israel. Yet you are trying to overthrow a city, and to destroy a mother in Israel—a principal city. Why would you devastate the inheritance of the Lord?"

verses.latin: Respondensque Joab, ait: Absit, absit a me: hoc nunquam erit.
verses.english: And Joab answered, saying: "Far be it, far be it from me! This will never happen!"

verses.latin: Non sic est, sed vir de monte Ephraim, Seba filius Bochri nomine, levavit manum suam contra regem David: tradite illum tantum, et recedamus a civitate. Et dixit mulier ad Joab: Ecce caput ejus mittetur ad te per murum.
verses.english: He continued: "That is not the case at all! Rather, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba, the son of Bichri, has raised his hand in rebellion against King David. Just hand him over, and we will withdraw from the city." And the woman said to Joab: "Behold, his head will be thrown over the wall to you."

verses.latin: Ingressa est itaque mulier ad omnem populum, et locuta est ad eos sapienter: qui abscissum caput Seba filii Bochri projecerunt ad Joab. Qui cecinit buccina, et abierunt universi de civitate, unusquisque in tabernacula sua. Joab autem reversus est Jerusalem ad regem.
verses.english: So the woman went to all the people and spoke to them with wisdom. Then they cut off the head of Sheba, the son of Bichri, and threw it over the wall to Joab. Joab then blew the trumpet, and all the men dispersed from the city, each returning to his own home. Joab, for his part, returned to Jerusalem to the king.

verses.latin: Porro Joab erat super omnem exercitum Israel: Banaia autem filius Jojadae super Cherethaeos et Phelethaeos.
verses.english: Now Joab was in command of all the army of Israel. Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in command over the Cherethites and the Pelethites—David's personal bodyguards.

verses.latin: Aduram vero super tributa: Josaphat autem filius Ahilud praefectus archivis.
verses.english: Adoram was in charge of collecting tribute. Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the recorder of official records.

verses.latin: Siva autem scriba: Sadoc vero et Abiathar sacerdotes.
verses.english: Sheva was the secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.

verses.latin: Ira quoque Jairi, erat sacerdos a latere David.
verses.english: And Ira, the Jairite, was also a priest alongside David, serving as his personal chaplain.

verses.latin: Et contigit ut vir quidam sceleratus, nomine Seba filius Bochri, vir de stirpe Jemini, inveniret buccinam et cecinerit, et dixerit: Non est nobis pars in David, neque haereditas in filio Isai: unusquisque ad tabernacula sua, Israel. Omnisque Israel recessit a David, secutus Seba filium Bochri: viri autem Juda adhaeserunt regi a Jordane usque Jerusalem.
verses.english: It happened then that a wicked man named Sheba, son of Bochri, from the tribe of Benjamin, found a trumpet and blew it, declaring to the people: "We have no portion in David! We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse (meaning King David)! Everyone to your tents, O Israel!" So all the people of Israel turned away from David and followed Sheba, son of Bochri. But the men of Judah remained loyal to their king, accompanying him from the Jordan River all the way to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Et venit David in domum suam Jerusalem: et accipit rex decem mulieres, concubinas quas dereliquerat ad custodiendam domum: et tradidit eas in custodiam, sustentans eas: et ad eas non ingrediebatur, sed erant clausae usque ad diem mortis suae in viduitate viventium.
verses.english: When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, the king took the ten concubines whom he had left behind to guard the household. He placed them under house arrest, providing for their sustenance, but he no longer had marital relations with them. They remained confined, living as widows until the day they died.

verses.latin: Venit autem rex ad domum suam Jerusalem, et accepit rex decem mulieres concubinas, quas dimiserat ad custodiendam domum: et reclusit eas in domo, tradens eas in custodiam: et tribuit eis alimenta: et ad eas non est ingressus, sed erant clausae usque ad diem mortis suae, in viduitate viventes.
verses.english: Indeed, when the king arrived at his house in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubine women whom he had sent away to guard the house. He confined them to a house, placing them under guard, and provided them with food. He did not go in to them, and they remained locked away, living like widows until their death.

verses.latin: Dixit autem rex Amasa: Convoca mihi viros Juda in tertium diem, et tu adesto praesens.
verses.english: Then the king said to Amasa: "Call the men of Judah for me to gather by the third day, and you must be present there yourself."

verses.latin: Abiit ergo Amasa, ut convocaret Judam: et moratus est ultra statutum tempus quod ei rex praefixerat.
verses.english: So Amasa went to summon the men of Judah, but he delayed beyond the appointed time that the king had set for him.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Abisai: Nunc magnopere affliget nos Seba filius Bochri, quam Absalom: tolle igitur servos domini tui, et persequere eum, ne forte inveniat civitates munitas, et aufugiat nos.
verses.english: And David said to Abishai: "Now Sheba, son of Bochri, will do us more harm than Absalom did. Therefore, take your master's soldiers and pursue him, lest he find fortified cities and escape from us."

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo post eum viri Joab, et Cherethi et Phelethi, et omnes robusti: et egressi sunt de Jerusalem, ut persequerentur Seba filium Bochri.
verses.english: So Joab's men went out after Abishai, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty warriors. They left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, son of Bochri.

verses.latin: Cumque illi essent juxta magnum lapidem qui est in Gabaon, Amasa venit obviam eis. Joab autem vestitus erat vestimento militari, et super ipsum accinctus gladio habens juxta lumbos, in vagina, et egressus prosiliit, et cecidit gladius.
verses.english: When they were near the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was dressed in his military uniform, and over it, a sword was belted to his waist, sheathed at his side. As he stepped forward, the sword slipped out of its sheath and fell.

verses.latin: Dixitque Joab ad Amasa: Salve mi frater. Et tenuit Joab manum Amasae barba, quasi osculans eum.
verses.english: And Joab said to Amasa: "Greetings, my brother!" Then Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand, as if to kiss him.

verses.latin: Porro Amasa attendere non curavit ad gladium quem habebat Joab in manu sua, et percussit eum Joab in latere, in inguine, et effudit intestina ejus in terram, nec secundam plagam dedit, et mortuus est. Et Joab et Abisai frater ejus persequuti sunt Seba filium Bochri.
verses.english: But Amasa did not pay attention to the sword that Joab held in his left hand. Joab then stabbed him in the side, piercing his groin, and spilled his intestines onto the ground. He did not need to strike a second blow, and Amasa died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai continued their pursuit of Sheba, son of Bochri.

verses.latin: Interim quidam de Joab pueris, stetit juxta Amasa, et ait: Ecce vir qui pro Joab est, et qui pro David est!
verses.english: Meanwhile, one of Joab's young men (soldiers) stood by Amasa's body and said: "Let anyone who is for Joab, and who is for David, follow us!"

verses.latin: Amasa autem volutabatur in sanguine suo in media via. Viditque vir ille, omnem populum consistere qui pertransiebat, et traxit Amasam de via in agrum, et operuit eum vestimento, ne incedentibus ad populum qui praeteribant, moraretur.
verses.english: Now Amasa lay writhing in his blood in the middle of the road. That soldier saw that all the people who were passing by were stopping to look. So he dragged Amasa from the road into a field and covered him with a garment, so that the sight of him would not delay the people who were passing by.

verses.latin: Remoto ergo illo de via, transierunt omnes viri ad persequendum Seba filium Bochri, Joab, et omnes qui erant cum eo.
verses.english: Therefore, once Amasa's body was removed from the road, all the men continued on to pursue Sheba, son of Bochri, with Joab and all who were with him.

verses.latin: Transivit autem per omnes tribus Israel, et per Abel, et Bethmaacha, et omnes Berym: et congregati sunt, et venerunt post eum.
verses.english: Sheba then traveled through all the tribes of Israel and came to Abel of Beth Maachah and all the Berites. There, many people gathered and followed him.

verses.latin: Veneruntque et obsederunt eum in Abel, et Bethmaacha, et super universos domos, et Berym: et effuderunt aggerem in circuitu civitatis, et stetit in muro: et omnis turba, quae erat cum Joab, suffodiebat murum, ut eum everterent.
verses.english: Joab's forces came and besieged Sheba in Abel of Beth Maachah. They surrounded the city, and against its walls, they built a siege ramp. All the multitude that was with Joab began undermining the wall, attempting to cause it to collapse.

verses.latin: Et clamavit mulier sapiens de civitate: Audite, audite, dicite Joab: Appropinqua huc, et loquar tecum.
verses.english: Then a wise woman cried out from the city: "Listen! Listen! Tell Joab: Come near here, and I will speak with you."

verses.latin: Et cum appropinquasset ad eam, ait mulier: Tu es Joab? Et ille respondit: Ego. Cui ait: Audi verba ancillae tuae. Et ille ait: Audio.
verses.english: When Joab approached her, the woman asked: "Are you Joab?" And he answered: "I am." She said to him: "Hear the words of your servant." And he replied: "I hear."

verses.latin: Et ait illa: Sermo antiquus, dicentium: Postulabant in Abel, et sic perficiebant.
verses.english: And she said: "There is an old saying among the people who would declare: 'When they seek counsel in Abel, they bring matters to completion.'" (This proverb highlights Abel's reputation as a place of wisdom and resolution.)

verses.latin: Ego sum de his quae interrogo, et responsum pacis recipiunt in Israel, et tu quare non vis subvertere civitatem quae est una de civitatibus primis in Israel? et quare praecipitas haereditatem Domini?
verses.english: I am one of those who seek peace and receive a peaceful answer in Israel. So why do you want to destroy a city that is one of the chief cities in Israel? And why do you seek to ruin the inheritance of the Lord (meaning God's people)?

verses.latin: Respondensque Joab, ait: Absit, absit a me, ut subvertam, aut demolior.
verses.english: And Joab answered, saying: "Far be it from me, far be it from me, that I should destroy or demolish anything!"

verses.latin: Non sic est, sed vir de monte Ephraim, Seba filius Bochri nomine, levavit manum suam contra regem David: tradite illum solum, et recedamus a civitate. Et ait mulier ad Joab: Ecce caput ejus mittetur ad te per murum.
verses.english: That is not the case. Instead, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba, son of Bochri, has raised his hand against King David. Hand over him alone, and we will withdraw from the city." And the woman said to Joab: "Behold, his head will be thrown over the wall to you."

verses.latin: Ingressa itaque mulier ad omnem populum, locuta est eis sapienter: et absciderunt caput Seba filii Bochri, et projecerunt illud ad Joab. Qui statim buccinâ cecinit, et recesserunt a civitate, unusquisque in tabernacula sua. Joab autem reversus est Jerusalem ad regem.
verses.english: So the woman went to all the people and spoke to them wisely. And they cut off the head of Sheba, son of Bochri, and threw it to Joab. He immediately blew the trumpet, signaling the end of the siege, and they withdrew from the city, each man returning to his own tents. Joab then returned to Jerusalem to the king.

verses.latin: Igitur Joab super omnem exercitum Israel erat: Banaias vero filius Jojadae super Cherethi et Phelethi:
verses.english: Therefore, Joab remained commander over all the army of Israel. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the Cherethites and the Pelethites (David's elite bodyguard and executioners).

verses.latin: Aduram autem super tributa: Josaphat vero filius Ahilud, a commentariis:
verses.english: Adoram was in charge of the tribute (overseeing forced labor and taxes). Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the recorder (the royal chronicler or secretary of state).

verses.latin: Siva autem scriba: Sadoc vero et Abiathar sacerdotes:
verses.english: Sheva was the scribe (the secretary who managed royal correspondence and records). And Zadok and Abiathar were the priests (the two high priests serving David).

verses.latin: Porro Ira Jairites erat sacerdos David.
verses.english: Moreover, Ira the Jairite was also a priest for David (likely a personal or honorary priestly advisor to the king).

verses.latin: Facta est autem fames in diebus David tribus annis jugiter, et consuluit David oraculum Domini. Et dixit Dominus: Propter Saul, et domum ejus sanguinum, et pro eo quod interfecit Gabaonitas.
verses.english: And a famine came upon the land during the reign of King David, and this famine lasted for three continuous years. King David sought to know the reason, so he consulted the oracle of the Lord for divine instruction. And the Lord revealed: 'This famine is because of Saul, and because of his entire house, which is guilty of shedding innocent blood — a bloodguilt incurred when Saul, in his zeal, massacred the Gibeonites.'

verses.latin: Vocatis itaque Gabaonitis, rex dixit ad eos: (Porro Gabaonitae non erant de filiis Israël, sed de reliquiis Amorrhæi: juraverant autem ei filii Israël, et Saul quærebat interficere eos zelo pro filiis Israël et Juda.)
verses.english: So King David called the Gibeonites to him and spoke with them. (Now, the Gibeonites were not from the Israelite people, but were a remnant of the Amorites. The sons of Israel had sworn an oath to them long ago, but Saul, in his misguided zeal for the sons of Israel and Judah, had sought to kill them all.)

verses.latin: Dixit ergo David ad Gabaonitas: Quid faciam vobis? et quod erit piaculum, ut benedicatis hæreditati Domini?
verses.english: Then David said to the Gibeonites: 'What must I do for you? And what atonement can be made, so that you may bless the inheritance of the Lord — meaning, the people and land of Israel?'

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei Gabaonitae: Non est nobis argenti et auri causa cum Saul, neque cum domo ejus: neque volumus ut interficiatur homo de Israël. Et dixit ad eos: Quodcumque petieritis, faciam vobis.
verses.english: And the Gibeonites answered him: 'It is not a matter of silver or gold for us concerning Saul or his house. Nor do we desire that any specific man of Israel be put to death by our hand.' But they had something else in mind. And David said to them: 'Whatever you ask for, I will do it for you.'

verses.latin: Qui responderunt regi: De viro qui nos attrivit, et depopulatus est nos, et cogitavit ut aboleremur, ne essemus in universis finibus Israël,
verses.english: They responded to the king: 'Concerning the man who crushed us, who utterly destroyed us, and who planned for us to be completely annihilated — so that we would no longer exist within any of the borders of Israel—'

verses.latin: dentur nobis septem viri de filiis ejus, et crucifigamus eos Domino in Gabaa Saul, quondam electi Domini. Et ait rex: Ego dabo.
verses.english: 'Let seven men from his sons be given to us. We will then impale them before the Lord in Gibeah of Saul, the very place where Saul, the Lord's chosen king, once lived.' And the king said: 'I will give them to you.'

verses.latin: Parcebat autem rex Miphiboseth filio Jonathan filii Saul, propter jusjurandum Domini quod fuerat inter David et Jonathan filium Saul.
verses.english: However, the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, who was Saul's son. He did this because of the solemn oath made before the Lord that had existed between David and Jonathan, Saul's son.

verses.latin: Tulit itaque rex duos filios Respha filiæ Aja, quos pepererat Sauli, Armoni et Miphiboseth: et quinque filios Michol filiæ Saul, quos genuerat Hadriel filio Barzellai Molathitae:
verses.english: So King David took two sons of Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, whom she had borne to Saul: Armoni and Mephibosheth. He also took the five sons of Michal, daughter of Saul, whom she had borne to Adriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.

verses.latin: et dedit eos in manu Gabaonitarum: qui crucifixerunt eos in monte coram Domino: et ceciderunt hi septem simul in diebus messis primis, sicut incipiebant triticum metere.
verses.english: And David gave these seven men into the hand of the Gibeonites. They impaled them on the mountain before the Lord. And these seven fell together — they died on the very first days of the harvest, right as the people were beginning to cut the wheat.

verses.latin: Tulit autem Respha filia Aja cilicio super petram a principio messis, donec stillaret aqua super eos de cælo: et non dimisit aves cæli requiescere super eos per diem, neque bestias agri per noctem.
verses.english: But Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, took sackcloth and spread it for herself on a rock from the beginning of the harvest season. She stayed there, watching over the bodies, until rain poured down upon them from the sky — signifying God's acceptance of the atonement. During all this time, she did not allow the birds of the sky to rest upon the bodies by day, nor the wild animals of the field to approach them by night.

verses.latin: Et nuntiatum est David quæ fecerat Respha filia Aja, concubina Saul.
verses.english: And it was reported to King David what Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, Saul's concubine, had done in her faithfulness.

verses.latin: Et abiit David, et tulit ossa Saul, et ossa Jonathan filii ejus de viris Jabes Galaad, qui furati fuerant ea de platea Bethsan, in qua suspenderant eos Philisthæi, quando interfecerunt Saul in Gelboe.
verses.english: Then David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-Gilead. These men had secretly taken them from the public square of Beth-Shan, where the Philistines had hung them after they killed Saul on Mount Gilboa.

verses.latin: Et asportavit inde ossa Saul, et ossa Jonathan filii ejus: et collegit ossa eorum qui confixi fuerant.
verses.english: And from there, David brought the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan. He also gathered the bones of those men who had been impaled.

verses.latin: Et sepelierunt ea cum ossibus Saul, et Jonathan filii ejus in terra Benjamin, in latere, in sepulchro Cis patris ejus: feceruntque omnia quæ præceperat rex, et propitiatus est Deus terræ post hæc.
verses.english: And they buried them — meaning, all the bones — with the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the land of Benjamin, in Zela, in the tomb of Kish, Saul's father. They carried out everything the king had commanded. After these things were done, God was appeased concerning the land, and the famine ended.

verses.latin: Factum est autem rursum proelium Philisthæorum adversus Israël: et descendit David, et servi ejus cum eo, et pugnabant adversum Philisthæos. Et defatigatus est David.
verses.english: Now, it happened again that there was a battle of the Philistines against Israel. David went down, and his servants went with him, and they fought against the Philistines. And during the fighting, David grew weary and exhausted.

verses.latin: Isbibenob autem de genere Arapha gigas, cujus hasta trecentos auri pondo appendebat, et accinctus erat gladio novo, conabatur interficere David.
verses.english: Then Ishbi-Benob, who was one of the descendants of the giant Rapha, whose spear weighed three hundred shekels of bronze — equivalent to a heavy amount of gold — and who was armed with a new sword, tried to kill King David.

verses.latin: Et subvenit ei Abisai filius Sarviæ, et percussum Philisthæum interfecit. Tunc juraverunt viri David, dicentes: Non egredieris nobiscum in proelium, ne forte extinguas lucernam Israël.
verses.english: But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, came to David's rescue. He struck the Philistine and killed him. Then the men of David swore an oath to him, saying: 'You shall not go out with us into battle anymore, lest you extinguish the lamp of Israel' — meaning, the very light and hope of our nation.

verses.latin: Secundum hoc et proelium factum est in Gob contra Philisthæos: tunc percussit Sobochai Husathites Saph de genere Arapha.
verses.english: After this, another battle occurred in Gob against the Philistines. At that time, Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Saph, who was also one of the descendants of the giant Rapha.

verses.latin: Et rursum pugnatum est in Gob contra Philisthæos, in quo percussit Adeodatus faber, cognomento Goliath Gethæum, cujus hastile concupivit vir texens.
verses.english: And again, battle was fought in Gob against the Philistines. In this engagement, Elhanan, the craftsman — whose proper name `Adeodatus faber` means 'God-given artisan' — struck down the Gittite giant, who was surnamed Goliath, and whose spear shaft was so massive it resembled a weaver's beam.

verses.latin: Fuit quoque et aliud bellum in Geth, in quo fuit vir procerus, habens senos digitos, et pedes, id est, viginti quatuor: et erat de genere Arapha.
verses.english: There was also another battle in Gath, in which there was a man of great stature. He had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot — that is, twenty-four digits in total. And he was also one of the descendants of the giant Rapha.

verses.latin: Et blasphemavit Israël: percussitque eum Jonathan filius Samma fratris David.
verses.english: And he — this giant — blasphemed Israel, challenging them. And Jonathan, the son of Shimei, David's brother, struck him down.

verses.latin: Hi quatuor de genere Arapha gigantis in Geth ceciderunt in manu David et servorum ejus.
verses.english: These four — meaning these four giants from the lineage of Rapha who lived in Gath — all fell by the hand of King David and his servants.

verses.latin: Facta est autem fames in diebus David tribus annis jugiter: et consuluit David oraculum Domini. Dixitque Dominus: Propter Saul, et domum ejus sanguinum, et quia interfecit Gabaonitas.
verses.english: During David's reign, a famine that lasted continuously for three years occurred. So David inquired of the Lord, seeking His divine answer. The Lord then said: "This famine is because of Saul and his household's bloodguilt, and because he killed the Gibeonites."

verses.latin: Vocatis ergo Gabaonitis rex, dixit ad eos (Porro Gabaonitae non erant de filiis Israel, sed de reliquiis Amorrhaeorum: filii quippe Israel juraverant eis, et voluit Saul percutere illos zelo pro filiis Israel et Juda):
verses.english: The king then summoned the Gibeonites and spoke with them. (The Gibeonites, by the way, were not descendants of Israel but were among the remaining Amorites. The sons of Israel had once sworn an oath to them, but Saul, in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah, had attempted to wipe them out.)

verses.latin: Dixitque David ad Gabaonitas: Quid vultis ut faciam vobis? et quod sit piaculum, ut benedicatis hereditati Domini?
verses.english: David then asked the Gibeonites: "What do you want me to do for you? What atonement can I make so that you may bless the Lord's inheritance—His people and His land—and the famine will end?"

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei Gabaonitae: Non est nobis argenti et auri sermo contra Saul, et contra domum ejus: neque volumus interfici hominem de Israel. Qui ait: Quid ergo vultis ut faciam vobis?
verses.english: The Gibeonites answered him: "Our claim against Saul and his house is not about silver or gold. Nor do we desire that any ordinary Israelite be put to death." David then pressed them again: "What then *do* you want me to do for you?"

verses.latin: Qui responderunt regi: De viro qui attrivit nos, et persecutus est crudeliter, ut deleremur et non maneremus in universis finibus Israel:
verses.english: They answered the king: "Concerning the man who crushed us and cruelly persecuted us with the intent to wipe us out completely from all the borders of Israel—"

verses.latin: dentur nobis septem viri de filiis ejus, ut crucifigantur Domino in Gabaa Saul, quondam electi Domini. Et ait rex: Ego dabo.
verses.english: "—let seven men of his descendants be given to us, so that they may be impaled before the Lord in Gibeon, Saul's city, who was once the Lord's chosen king." The king replied: "I will give them."

verses.latin: Pepercitque rex Miphiboseth filio Jonathan filii Saul, propter jusjurandum Domini quod fuerat inter David et Jonathan filium Saul.
verses.english: However, the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan (Saul's son), because of the sacred oath sworn before the Lord between David and Jonathan, Saul's son.

verses.latin: Tulit itaque rex duos filios Respha filiae Aja, quos genuerat Saul, Armoni et Miphiboseth: et quinque filios Michol filiae Saul, quos genuerat Hadriel filius Barzillai Molathitae.
verses.english: So the king took the two sons of Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, whom Saul had fathered: Armoni and Mephibosheth. He also took the five sons of Michal, Saul's daughter, whom Hadriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite, had fathered.

verses.latin: Et dedit eos in manu Gabaonitarum: qui crucifixerunt eos in monte coram Domino: et ceciderunt hi septem simul in diebus messis primis, in principio sementis hordei.
verses.english: And he gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites, who then impaled them on the mountain before the Lord. These seven died together during the first days of the harvest, right at the beginning of the barley harvest.

verses.latin: Tulit quoque Respha filia Aja cilicio sibi, et extendit illud super petram de principio messis, donec stillaret aqua super eos de caelo: et non dimisit aves caeli requiescere super eos per diem, neque bestias agri per noctem.
verses.english: Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, also took sackcloth for herself and spread it out upon a rock, making a vigil. She stayed there from the beginning of the harvest until the rains finally poured down on the bodies from the sky. During that entire time, she did not allow the birds of the sky to settle on them by day, nor the wild beasts of the field to approach them by night.

verses.latin: Et nuntiatum est David quae fecisset Respha filia Aja concubina Saul.
verses.english: And it was reported to David what Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, Saul's concubine, had done.

verses.latin: Et abiit David, et tulit ossa Saul, et ossa Jonathan filii ejus a viris Jabes Galaad, qui furati fuerant ea de platea Bethsan, ubi affixerant eos Philisthim, quando interfecerunt Saul in Gelboe.
verses.english: David then went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-Gilead. These men had previously rescued the bodies, stealing them from the public square of Beth-Shan, where the Philistines had displayed them after killing Saul on Mount Gilboa.

verses.latin: Et asportavit inde ossa Saul, et ossa Jonathan filii ejus: ossa quoque eorum, qui fuerant crucifixi, collegit.
verses.english: From there, David brought the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan. He also gathered the bones of those who had been impaled by the Gibeonites.

verses.latin: Et sepelierunt ea cum ossibus Saul, et Jonathan filii ejus, in terra Benjamin in latere, in sepulchro Cis patris ejus: feceruntque omnia quae praeceperat rex, et propitiatus est Deus terrae post haec.
verses.english: And they buried them (the bones of the seven impaled men) along with the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan, in the land of Benjamin, in Zelah, in the tomb of Kish, Saul's father. They carried out everything the king had commanded. After these acts, God was finally appeased for the land of Israel.

verses.latin: Et locutus est David Domino verba carminis hujus, in die qua liberavit eum Dominus de manu omnium inimicorum ejus, et de manu Saul,
verses.english: David spoke this song to the Lord, on the very day the Lord had rescued him from the power of all his enemies, and from the power of Saul.

verses.latin: et dixit: Fortitudo mea, et firmamentum meum, et refugium meum, et salvator meus.
verses.english: And David said: “The Lord is my strength and my fortified place, my refuge and my savior.

verses.latin: Deus meus, meus fortis, sperabo in eum: clypeus meus, et cornu salutis meae: excelsus, et asylium meum: salvator meus, a iniquitate liberabis me.
verses.english: My God is my Rock, in Him I will trust. He is my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my high tower, and my sanctuary. My Savior, you will deliver me from injustice.

verses.latin: Laudans invocabo Dominum: et ab inimicis meis salvus ero.
verses.english: When I call upon the Lord with praise, I will be saved from my enemies.

verses.latin: Quia circumdederunt me fluctus mortis: torrentes iniquitatis conturbaverunt me.
verses.english: For the waves of death had surrounded me; the destructive currents of iniquity terrified me.

verses.latin: Funes inferni circumdederunt me: praeoccupaverunt me laquei mortis.
verses.english: The snares of hell encircled me; the traps of death had seized me.

verses.latin: In tribulatione mea invocabo Dominum, et ad Deum meum clamabo: et exaudiet de templo suo vocem meam, et clamor meus veniet ad aures ejus.
verses.english: In my distress, I called upon the Lord, and cried out to my God. And from His holy temple, He heard my voice, and my cry came to His ears.

verses.latin: Commota est et contremuit terra, fundamenta montium concussa sunt, et complanata sunt, quoniam iratus est illis.
verses.english: Then the earth shook and trembled, the foundations of the mountains were stirred, and they were made low, because the Lord was angry with them.

verses.latin: Ascendit fumus de naribus ejus: et ignis de ore ejus voravit: carbones succensi sunt ab eo.
verses.english: Smoke rose from His nostrils, and fire from His mouth devoured; burning coals were ignited by Him.

verses.latin: Inclinavit caelos, et descendit: et caligo sub pedibus ejus.
verses.english: He bowed the sky and came down, and thick darkness was under His feet.

verses.latin: Et ascendit super Cherubim, et volavit: et lapsus est super pennas ventorum.
verses.english: And He rode upon a Cherub and flew; He glided upon the wings of the winds.

verses.latin: Posuit tenebras in circuitu suo latibulum, in circuitu ejus tabernaculum ejus: tenebrosa aqua, et nubes aeris.
verses.english: He made darkness His hidden place all around Him, His tent was all around Him: dark water and thick clouds of the sky.

verses.latin: De splendore coram ipso, succensi sunt carbones ignis.
verses.english: From the brilliance before Him, coals of fire were kindled.

verses.latin: Tonabit de caelo Dominus: et Excelsus dedit vocem suam.
verses.english: The Lord thundered from the sky, and the Most High gave forth His voice.

verses.latin: Misit sagittas, et dissipavit eos: fulgura, et conturbavit illos.
verses.english: He sent forth arrows and scattered them; He sent lightning and put them to flight.

verses.latin: Et apparuerunt effusiones maris, et revelata sunt fundamenta orbis terrarum ab increpatione Domini, ab inspiratione spiritus furoris ejus.
verses.english: Then the ocean floor became visible, and the foundations of the earth were uncovered at the Lord's rebuke, at the blast of the breath of His fury.

verses.latin: Misit de alto, et assumpsit me, et extraxit me de aquis multis.
verses.english: He reached down from on high and took hold of me; He drew me out of many waters.

verses.latin: Eripuit me de inimicis meis fortissimis, et de his qui oderant me: quoniam confortati sunt super me.
verses.english: He rescued me from my mighty enemies, and from those who hated me, because they were too strong for me.

verses.latin: Praevenerunt me in die afflictionis meae: et factus est Dominus protector meus.
verses.english: They confronted me on the day of my distress, but the Lord became my protector.

verses.latin: Et eduxit me in latitudinem: liberavit me, quia placui ei.
verses.english: And He brought me out into a wide-open place; He delivered me because I was pleasing to Him.

verses.latin: Retribuet mihi Dominus secundum justitiam meam: et secundum munditiam manuum mearum reddet mihi.
verses.english: The Lord will reward me according to my righteousness, and according to the cleanness of my hands, He will repay me.

verses.latin: Quia custodivi vias Domini: et non egi impie a Deo meo.
verses.english: Because I have kept the ways of the Lord, and have not acted wickedly against my God.

verses.latin: Quoniam omnia judicia ejus in conspectu meo sunt: et praecepta ejus non amovi a me.
verses.english: For all His judgments are before my eyes, and I have not turned His commands away from me.

verses.latin: Et ero perfectus cum eo: et custodiam me ab iniquitate mea.
verses.english: I will be blameless before Him, and I will keep myself from my iniquity.

verses.latin: Et reddet mihi Dominus secundum justitiam meam: et secundum munditiam manuum mearum in conspectu oculorum ejus.
verses.english: Therefore the Lord will repay me according to my righteousness, and according to the cleanness of my hands in the sight of His eyes.

verses.latin: Cum sancto sanctus eris: et cum robusto perfectus.
verses.english: With the holy, You will be holy; and with the mighty, You will be perfect.

verses.latin: Cum electo electus eris: et cum perverso perverteris.
verses.english: With the chosen, You will be chosen; and with the perverse, You will be perverse.

verses.latin: Et populum pauperem salvum facies: et oculis superborum humiliabis.
verses.english: And You will save the humble people, but You will humble the eyes of the proud.

verses.latin: Quoniam tu lucerna mea Domine: et tu Domine illuminabis tenebras meas.
verses.english: For You, O Lord, are my lamp; and You, O Lord, will illuminate my darkness.

verses.latin: In te enim curram accinctus: et in Deo meo transiliam murum.
verses.english: For by Your help, I will charge into battle prepared, and by the power of my God, I will leap over any wall.

verses.latin: Deus, perfectam viam meam: eloquium Domini igne examinatum: clypeus omnium sperantium in se.
verses.english: God makes my way perfect; the word of the Lord is proven by fire; He is a shield to all who trust in Him.

verses.latin: Quis est enim Deus praeter Dominum? et quis fortis praeter Deum nostrum?
verses.english: For who is God except the Lord? And who is strong besides our God?

verses.latin: Deus qui accinxit me fortitudine: et statuit perfectam viam meam.
verses.english: God is the one who has girded me with strength and made my path perfect.

verses.latin: Aequans pedes meos cervis: et super excelsa mea statuens me.
verses.english: He made my feet like those of deer, enabling me to stand firm on my high places.

verses.latin: Docens manus meas ad proelium: et aptasti arcum aereum brachiis meis.
verses.english: He trains my hands for battle, so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.

verses.latin: Deditque mihi clypeum salutis tuae: et lenitas tua multiplicavit me.
verses.english: You have also given me the shield of Your salvation, and Your gentleness has made me great.

verses.latin: Dilatabis gressus meos subtus me: et non deficient tali mei.
verses.english: You will make my steps wide beneath me, and my ankles will not falter.

verses.latin: Persequar inimicos meos, et conteram: et non convertar donec consumam eos.
verses.english: I will pursue my enemies and crush them; I will not turn back until I have destroyed them.

verses.latin: Consumam eos, et confringam, ut non consurgant: cadent subtus pedes meos.
verses.english: I will consume them and break them, so that they cannot rise; they will fall beneath my feet.

verses.latin: Accinxisti me fortitudine ad praelium: incurvasti resistentes mihi subtus me.
verses.english: You have girded me with strength for the battle; You have subdued those who rise against me beneath my power.

verses.latin: Hæc sunt verba David novissima. Dixit David filius Isai: Dixit vir, cui constitutum est de Christo Dei Jacob, egregius psaltes Israel:
verses.english: These are the final words of David. David, the son of Jesse, declared them. Thus declared the man who was established by the Anointed One of the God of Jacob, the excellent psalmist of Israel:

verses.latin: Spiritus Domini locutus est per me, et sermo ejus per linguam meam.
verses.english: The Spirit of the Lord has spoken through me, and His word has been on my tongue.

verses.latin: Dixit Deus Israël, mihi locuta est Fortis Israël: Dominator hominum, justus dominator in timore Dei.
verses.english: The God of Israel has spoken, the Strong One of Israel has spoken to me: 'The Ruler over humanity is a just ruler, ruling in the fear of God.'

verses.latin: Sicut lux auroræ, oriente sole, absque nubibus, rutilat, et sicut pluviis germinat de terra herba.
verses.english: His rule will be like the morning light when the sun rises without clouds, shining brightly. It will be like the grass that sprouts from the earth after the rains.

verses.latin: Neque enim tanta est domus mea cum Deo, ut pactum æternum iniret mecum firmum in omnibus atque munitum. Cuncta enim salus mea, et omnis voluntas, et deinceps non germinabit.
verses.english: Indeed, my household is not so great before God, for He has made an eternal covenant with me, firm in all things and secured. For all my salvation and all my desire come from Him, and His covenant will not fail in the future.

verses.latin: Sicut spinæ ardentis, sic sunt omnes filii Belial, quæ nec manu capiuntur.
verses.english: But all the sons of Belial (worthless men) are like burning thorns that cannot be grasped by hand.

verses.latin: Et si quis tangere voluerit eas, armabitur ferro et ligno lanceato, et igne comburentur in eodem loco.
verses.english: And if anyone wishes to touch them, he must be armed with iron and a spear shaft, and they will be utterly consumed by fire in that very place.

verses.latin: Hæc nomina fortium David: Isboseth sedens in cathedra, sapientissimus princeps inter tres, ipse est quasi tenerrimus ligni vermiculus, qui octingentos interfecit impetu uno.
verses.english: These are the names of David’s mighty warriors: Isboseth, who sat on the throne, the wisest prince among the top three warriors. He was like a very tender worm in wood, yet he killed eight hundred men in one attack.

verses.latin: Post hunc Eleazar filius patrui ejus Ahohites inter tres fortes qui erant cum David quando exprobraverunt Philisthiim et congregati sunt illic in prælium.
verses.english: After him was Eleazar, the son of his uncle Ahohite, one of the three mighty men who were with David when they defied the Philistines, who had gathered there for battle.

verses.latin: Cum ascendissent viri Israël, ipse stetit et percussit Philisthiim donec refatigata manus ejus, obriguit cum gladio, et fecit Dominus salutem magnam in die illa: et populus, qui fugerat, reversus est ad cædem spoliandi.
verses.english: When the men of Israel had gone up, he stood firm and struck down the Philistines until his hand was weary and stiff from holding his sword. The Lord brought about a great victory on that day, and the people who had fled returned only to plunder the dead.

verses.latin: Et post hunc Semma filius Agæ de Arari. Et congregati sunt Philisthiim in Lehi: erat quippe ibi ager lente plenus. Cum fugisset populus a facie Philisthiim,
verses.english: And after him was Semma, the son of Age from Arari. The Philistines had gathered at Lehi; there was a field full of lentils there. When the people fled from the Philistines,

verses.latin: Stetit ipse in medio agri, et tuitus est eum, percussitque Philisthiim: et fecit Dominus salutem magnam.
verses.english: He himself stood in the middle of the field and defended it. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.

verses.latin: Tribus ex triginta principibus perrexerunt, et venerunt ad David in messem siliginis in speluncam Odollam: siquidem castra Philisthiim erant posita in valle Raphaim.
verses.english: Three of the thirty chief warriors went down and came to David during the rye harvest, into the cave of Odollam. The Philistine army was encamped in the valley of Raphaim.

verses.latin: Et David erat in præsidio: et statio Philisthiim tunc in Bethlehem.
verses.english: And David was in a stronghold there, while the Philistine outpost was then in Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Desideravit ergo David, et ait: Si quis mihi daret aquam de cisterna Bethlehem, quæ est in porta!
verses.english: David then expressed a longing, saying, 'If only someone would give me water from the cistern of Bethlehem, which is near the gate!'

verses.latin: Irruperunt ergo tres fortes castra Philisthiim, et hauserunt aquam de cisterna Bethlehem, quæ erat in porta, et attulerunt ad David: noluitque David bibere, sed libavit eam Domino, dicens:
verses.english: So the three mighty men broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the cistern of Bethlehem, which was at the gate. They brought it to David, but David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne faciam hoc. Sanguinem hominum istorum, qui ierunt cum animarum periculo, bibam? Et noluit bibere. Hæc tria fecerunt robustissimi.
verses.english: 'May the Lord be merciful to me, that I should not do this. Should I drink the blood of these men who went risking their very lives?' And he refused to drink it. These three mighty deeds were performed by the strongest warriors.

verses.latin: Abisai quoque frater Joab, filius Sarviæ, princeps inter tres, ipse est qui levavit hastam suam contra trecentos, quos interfecit: nominatus in tribus,
verses.english: Abisai also, the brother of Joab, son of Sarvia, was a chief among a group of three. He was the one who lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and he was renowned among this group of three.

verses.latin: Et inter tres potentissimus, et factus est eorum princeps: verumtamen usque ad tres primos non pervenerat.
verses.english: And he was the most powerful among these three, and he became their commander. Nevertheless, he did not reach the status of the first three (the top warriors).

verses.latin: Banaias filius Jojadæ, vir robustissimus, magnorum operum, de Cabseel: ipse percussit duos leones Moab, et ipse descendit et percussit leonem in media cisterna diebus nivis.
verses.english: Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was a very robust man, capable of great deeds, from Cabseel. He struck down two lion-like men of Moab, and he also went down into a cistern and struck down a lion on a snowy day.

verses.latin: Ipse quoque interfecit virum ægyptium, miræ staturæ, habentem in manu hastam: et descendit ad eum cum virga, et rapuit hastam de manu Ægyptii, et interfecit eum hasta sua.
verses.english: He also killed an Egyptian man of extraordinary stature, who had a spear in his hand. Benaiah went down to him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear.

verses.latin: Hæc fecit Banaias filius Jojadæ,
verses.english: These deeds were done by Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada.

verses.latin: Et ipse nominatus inter tres robustos, qui inter triginta nobiliores erant: verumtamen usque ad tres non pervenerat, fecitque eum David sibi a secreto.
verses.english: And he was renowned among the three powerful ones, who themselves were considered more noble than the thirty other warriors; nevertheless, he did not attain the rank of the first three (top warriors). David made him his privy counselor.

verses.latin: Asael frater Joab inter triginta, Eleanan filius patrui ejus de Bethlehem.
verses.english: Asael, Joab's brother, was among the thirty warriors; Eleanan, the son of his uncle, from Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Samma de Harodi, Elica de Harodi,
verses.english: Samma from Harodi, Elica from Harodi.

verses.latin: Heles de Palti, Hira filius Acces de Thecua,
verses.english: Heles from Palti, Hira, the son of Acces, from Thecua.

verses.latin: Abiezer de Anathoth, Mobonnai de Husati,
verses.english: Abiezer from Anathoth, Mobonnai from Husati.

verses.latin: Selmon Ahohites, Maharai Netophathites,
verses.english: Selmon, an Ahohite; Maharai, a Netophathite.

verses.latin: Heled filius Banaa de Netophath, Ithai filius Ribai de Gabaath filiorum Benjamin,
verses.english: Heled, the son of Banaa, from Netophath; Ithai, the son of Ribai, from Gabaath of the children of Benjamin.

verses.latin: Banaias Pharathonites, Hiddai de Nahale Gaas,
verses.english: Benaiah, a Pharathonite; Hiddai from Nahale Gaas.

verses.latin: Abialbon Arbathites, Azmaveth de Beromi,
verses.english: Abialbon, an Arbathite; Azmaveth from Beromi.

verses.latin: Eliaba de Saalboni, filii Jasen, Jonathan,
verses.english: Eliaba from Saalboni, along with the sons of Jasen: Jonathan.

verses.latin: Samma de Arari, Ahiam filius Sarar de Arari,
verses.english: Samma from Arari, Ahiam, the son of Sarar, from Arari.

verses.latin: Eliphelet filius Ahasbai filii Machati, Eliam filius Achitophel Gelonites,
verses.english: Eliphelet, the son of Ahasbai, the son of Machati; Eliam, the son of Achitophel, a Gelonite.

verses.latin: Hesrai de Carmelo, Pharai de Arbi,
verses.english: Hesrai from Carmelo, Pharai from Arbi.

verses.latin: Igaal filius Nathan de Soba, Bonni de Gadi,
verses.english: Igaal, the son of Nathan, from Soba; Bonni from Gadi.

verses.latin: Selec Ammonites, Naharai Berothites armiger Joab filii Sarviæ.
verses.english: Selec, an Ammonite; Naharai, a Berothite, the armor-bearer of Joab, the son of Sarvia.

verses.latin: Ira Jethrites, Gareb Jethrites,
verses.english: Ira, a Jethrite; Gareb, a Jethrite.

verses.latin: Urias Hethæus.
verses.english: Uriah, the Hethite.

verses.latin: Omnes triginta septem.
verses.english: In total, there were thirty-seven.

verses.latin: Hæc sunt verba David novissima. Dixit David filius Isai: Dixit vir, cui constitutum est de Christo Dei Jacob, egregius psaltes Israel:
verses.english: These are David's last words. David, Jesse's son, declared this message: The man who was established by the God of Jacob as His anointed ruler, the renowned psalmist of Israel, spoke this revelation.

verses.latin: Spiritus Domini locutus est per me, et sermo ejus per linguam meam.
verses.english: The Spirit of the Lord spoke through me, and His message was on my tongue.

verses.latin: Dixit Deus Israel mihi, locuta est Fortis Israel, Dominator hominum, justus dominator in timore Dei.
verses.english: The God of Israel spoke to me. The Strong One of Israel declared this truth: The Ruler of all humanity is a just ruler, governing in the reverent fear of God.

verses.latin: Sicut lux aurorae, oriente sole, absque nubibus, rutilat, et sicut pluvia germinat de terra.
verses.english: His rule is like the morning light, shining brightly when the sun rises without clouds. It is like the rain that makes the earth sprout with life.

verses.latin: Neque enim tanta est domus mea apud Deum, ut pactum æternum iniret mecum, firmum in omnibus atque munitum. Cuncta enim salus mea et omnis voluntas, nec est qui germinet.
verses.english: Indeed, my royal house is not so great in God's sight, that He would enter into an eternal covenant with me, steadfast in every way and secured. Yet, this is all my salvation and all my desire; and even if no heir of mine should truly flourish by his own power, God's promise stands.

verses.latin: Sicut spinæ evulsæ omnes, non complentur manu: et si quis tangere voluerit eas, armabitur ferro, et ligno lanceato, et igne comburentur in eodem loco.
verses.english: But the wicked are all like thorns that have been torn out, which cannot be gathered by hand. If anyone desires to handle them, he must arm himself with iron and a spear, for they will surely be consumed by fire right where they are found.

verses.latin: Hæc nomina fortium David. Sedens in cathedra sapientissimus princeps inter tres, ipse est quasi tenerrimus ligni vermis, qui octingentos interfecit impetu uno.
verses.english: These are the names of David's mighty warriors. Josheb-basshebeth, the wisest chief among the three, was the same as Adino the Eznite, who with a single attack killed eight hundred men.

verses.latin: Post hunc fuit Eleazar filius patrui ejus Ahohites inter tres fortes qui erant cum David quando exprobraverunt Philisthiim, et congregati sunt illuc in prælium. Cumque recessissent viri Israel,
verses.english: After him was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite, who was among the three mighty warriors with David. They were with David when they defied the Philistines, who had gathered there for battle. When the men of Israel had retreated,

verses.latin: ipse stetit et percussit Philisthiim donec deficeret manus ejus, et obrigesceret cum gladio. Et fecit Dominus salutem magnam in die illa: et populus, qui fugerat, reversus est ad cædem spoliare interfectos.
verses.english: Eleazar stood firm and fought the Philistines until his hand grew weary and stiff, clenched to his sword. And the Lord brought about a great victory on that day. The people who had fled then returned, but only to plunder the slain.

verses.latin: Et post hunc Semma filius Agæ de Arari. Et congregati sunt Philisthiim in Lechi: erat quippe ibi ager plenus lente. Cumque fugisset populus a facie Philisthiim,
verses.english: After Eleazar was Shammah, son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had gathered in Lehi, where there was a field full of lentils. When the people fled from the Philistines,

verses.latin: stetit ipse in medio agri, et defendit eum, percussitque Philisthiim: et fecit Dominus salutem magnam.
verses.english: Shammah stood his ground in the middle of the field and defended it. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.

verses.latin: Et tres ex triginta qui erant principes descenderunt, et venerunt ad David in messem ad speluncam Odollam: siquidem castra Philisthinorum erant posita in valle Raphaim.
verses.english: Three of the thirty chief warriors went down and came to David during harvest time at the cave of Adullam. At that time, the Philistine camp was set up in the Valley of Rephaim.

verses.latin: Eo igitur tempore David erat in præsidio, et statio Philisthinorum in Bethlehem.
verses.english: At that time, David was in a stronghold, and a Philistine garrison was in Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Desideravit ergo David, et ait: O si quis mihi daret aquam de cisterna Bethlehem, quæ est in porta!
verses.english: So David longed for water and said: 'Oh, if only someone would give me a drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the city gate!'

verses.latin: Irruperunt ergo tres fortes castra Philisthinorum, et hauserunt aquam de cisterna Bethlehem, quæ erat in porta, et asportaverunt ad David: noluitque David bibere, sed libavit illam Domino,
verses.english: So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the well of Bethlehem, which was by the city gate. They brought it to David, but David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord,

verses.latin: dicens: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne faciam hoc. Sanguinem hominum istorum, qui periculum mortis adierunt, bibam? Et idcirco noluit bibere. Hæc fecerunt tres fortes.
verses.english: saying: 'May the Lord forbid that I should do this! Shall I drink the blood of these men who went at the risk of their lives?' And because of this, he would not drink it. These were the deeds of the three mighty warriors.

verses.latin: Abisai quoque frater Joab filius Sarviæ, princeps de tribus: ipse est qui levavit hastam suam contra trecentos, quos interfecit: nominatus in tribus,
verses.english: Abishai, the brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was chief of the three. He was the one who lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them; he became renowned among the three.

verses.latin: et inter tres primus, et multo illustrior quam duo, qui et factus est eorum princeps: verumtamen usque ad tres primos non pervenerat.
verses.english: He was the first among the three, and much more illustrious than the other two, and he became their commander. Nevertheless, he did not reach the level of the first three mighty warriors.

verses.latin: Et Banaias filius Jojadæ vir fortissimus, magnorum operum, de Cabseel: ipse percussit duos leones Moab: et ipse descendit, et percussit leonem in media cisterna diebus nivis.
verses.english: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, a very mighty man who performed great deeds, came from Kabzeel. He killed two of Moab's most powerful warriors. He also went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.

verses.latin: Et ipse percussit virum ægyptium, miræ staturæ, habentem in manu hastam: cumque descendisset ad eum cum virga, extorsit hastam de manu ægyptii, et interfecit eum hasta sua.
verses.english: He also struck down an Egyptian, a man of remarkable stature, who had a spear in his hand. Benaiah went down to him with only a staff, wrestled the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and then killed him with his own spear.

verses.latin: Hæc fecit Banaias filius Jojadæ, et nominatus est inter tres robustos.
verses.english: These were the deeds of Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, and he became renowned among the three mighty warriors.

verses.latin: Et de triginta primus fuit, verumtamen usque ad tres non pervenerat: fecitque eum David sibi a secreto consilii.
verses.english: He was the chief of the thirty, though he did not reach the level of the first three. David appointed him as his chief counselor.

verses.latin: Asahel frater Joab de triginta erat, et Elchanan filius patrui ejus de Bethlehem.
verses.english: Among the thirty were Asahel, Joab's brother, and Elhanan, son of Dodo from Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Semma de Harodi, Elica de Harodi,
verses.english: Also, Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,

verses.latin: Heles de Phalti, Hira filius Acces de Thecua,
verses.english: Helez the Paltite, Ira, son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,

verses.latin: Abiezer de Anathoth, Mobonnai de Husati,
verses.english: Abiezer from Anathoth, Mebunnai the Hushathite,

verses.latin: Selon de Ahohi, Maharai de Netophathi,
verses.english: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,

verses.latin: Heled filius Banæ de Netophathi, Ithai filius Ribai de Gabaath filiorum Benjamin,
verses.english: Heled, son of Baanah from Netophah, Ittai, son of Ribai from Gibeon of the Benjamites,

verses.latin: Banaias de Pharathon, Hodai de Nahale Gaas,
verses.english: Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash,

verses.latin: Abi Albon de Araba, Azmaveth de Baromi,
verses.english: Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Bahurimite,

verses.latin: Eliaba de Saalboni, Jonathas de Bani,
verses.english: Eliaba the Shaalbonite, Jonathan, son of Jashen,

verses.latin: Samma de Arari, Ahiam filius Sarar de Arari,
verses.english: Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam, son of Sharar the Ararite,

verses.latin: Eliphelet filius Aasbai filii Machati, Eliam filius Achitophel Gelonites,
verses.english: Eliphelet, son of Ahasbai from Maacah, Eliam, son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,

verses.latin: Hesrai de Carmelo, Pharai de Arbi,
verses.english: Hezrai the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,

verses.latin: Igaal filius Nathan de Soba, Bonni de Gadi,
verses.english: Igal, son of Nathan from Zobah, Bani the Gadite,

verses.latin: Selec de Ammoni, Naharai de Berothites armiger Joab filii Sarviæ,
verses.english: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, who was the armor-bearer for Joab, son of Zeruiah,

verses.latin: Ira de Jethri, Gareb de Jethri,
verses.english: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,

verses.latin: Urias Hethæus, omnes triginta septem.
verses.english: Uriah the Hittite—in all, thirty-seven warriors.

verses.latin: Et addidit furor Domini irasci contra Israël, commovitque David in eis, dicens: Vade, numera Israël et Iudam.
verses.english: The Lord’s just anger continued to burn against Israel. He stirred up David to act against them, saying, “Go, take a census of the men of Israel and Judah.”

verses.latin: Et dixit rex Ioab principi exercitus sui: Circuite universas tribus Israël, a Dan et Bersabee, et numerate populum, ut sciam numerum eius.
verses.english: So the king told Joab, the commander of his army: “Go throughout all the tribes of Israel, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, and count the people. I want to know their total number.”

verses.latin: Dixitque Ioab regi: Addat Dominus Deus tuus ad populum hunc, centuplum quantum est nunc: et oculi domini mei regis videant. Quare autem dominus meus rex vult rem hanc?
verses.english: But Joab replied to the king: “May the Lord your God increase the number of these people a hundredfold more than they are now! And may my lord the king live to see it with his own eyes. Why, then, does my lord the king want to do this thing?”

verses.latin: Obstinavitque rex sermonem Ioab et principum exercitus: et egressus est Ioab et principes militum a facie regis, ut numerarent populum Israël.
