verses.english: Yet the king insisted on his command to Joab and the army commanders. So Joab and the generals departed from the king’s presence to take a census of the people of Israel.

verses.latin: Et cum pertransissent Iordanem, venerunt in Aroer, et in dexteram urbis, quae est in valle Gad.
verses.english: When they had crossed the Jordan River, they came to Aroer, and to the city that is on the right side of the valley of Gad.

verses.latin: Et per Madiam, et Galaad, et in terram Inferiorem, id est, Odasi, veneruntque in saltus Solis, quae est urbs Sidoniorum.
verses.english: From there, they went through Midian and Gilead, and into the lower land, that is, Hodesh. They came to the forested area of the Sun, which is the city of the Sidonians.

verses.latin: Et transierunt inde contra faciem Tyri, et omnem terram Hevei et Chananei: veneruntque in meridiem Iudae, Bersabee.
verses.english: They then traveled from there, facing Tyre, and through all the land of the Hivites and Canaanites. They finally arrived in the south of Judah, at Beersheba.

verses.latin: Lustraveruntque omnem terram, et venerunt post novem menses et viginti dies in Ierusalem.
verses.english: After surveying all the land, they returned to Jerusalem after nine months and twenty days.

verses.latin: Deditque Ioab numerum descriptionis populi regi: et inventa sunt de Israël octingenta millia virorum fortium, qui educerent gladium: et de Iuda quingenta millia pugnatorum.
verses.english: Joab reported the number of the registered people to the king: In Israel, there were eight hundred thousand valiant men who could wield a sword. In Judah, there were five hundred thousand fighting men.

verses.latin: Percussit autem cor David postquam numerasset populum: et dixit ad Dominum: Peccavi valde in hoc opere: sed precor, Domine, aufer iniquitatem servi tui, quia stulte egi.
verses.english: But David’s conscience troubled him after he had counted the people. So he said to the Lord: “I have sinned greatly in this act. But I beg You, Lord, take away the iniquity of Your servant, for I have acted foolishly.”

verses.latin: Et surrexit David mane, et sermo Domini factus est ad Gad prophetam et videntem David, dicens:
verses.english: When David rose in the morning, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying:

verses.latin: Vade, et loquere ad David: Hæc dicit Dominus: Tres res tibi propono: elige unam quam volueris, ut faciam tibi.
verses.english: “Go, and speak to David: ‘This is what the Lord says: I offer you three choices. Choose one, and I will bring it upon you.’”

verses.latin: Cumque venisset Gad ad David, nuntiavit ei, dicens: Aut septem annis veniet tibi fames in terra tua: aut tribus mensibus fugies adversarios tuos, et illi persequentur te: aut tribus diebus erit pestis in terra tua. Nunc igitur delibera, et vide quid respondeam ei qui misit me.
verses.english: When Gad came to David, he reported to him, saying: “Either seven years of famine will come upon your land, or for three months you will flee from your adversaries as they pursue you, or for three days there will be a plague in your land. Now then, decide, and see what answer I should give to the One who sent me.”

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Gad: Angustiae sunt mihi nimis: sed melius est ut incidam in manu Domini, quia multae sunt miserationes eius, quam in manu hominis.
verses.english: And David said to Gad: “I am in a very distressed situation. But it is better that I fall into the hand of the Lord, for His compassions are great, rather than into the hand of man.”

verses.latin: Immisit ergo Dominus pestem in Israël de mane usque ad tempus statutum, et mortui sunt de populo, a Dan et Bersabee, septuaginta millia virorum.
verses.english: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel from that morning until the appointed time. And from Dan to Beersheba, seventy thousand men among the people died.

verses.latin: Cumque extendisset angelus manum suam super Ierusalem, ut disperderet eam, misertus est Dominus super afflicto, et ait Angelo exterminanti populum: Sufficit, ne extendas ultra manum tuam. Erat autem Angelus Domini juxta aream Areunae Iebusaei.
verses.english: When the angel extended his hand over Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord had pity on the afflicted people. He said to the angel who was destroying the people: “Enough! Do not extend your hand further.” Now the Lord’s angel was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

verses.latin: Dixitque David ad Dominum, cum videret Angelum percutientem populum: Ego sum qui peccavi, ego inique egi: hi qui oves sunt, quid fecerunt? Vertatur obsecro manus tua contra me, et contra domum patris mei.
verses.english: And when David saw the angel striking the people, he said to the Lord: “It is I who have sinned, I have acted wickedly. These people are like sheep; what have they done? I beg You, let Your hand be turned against me and against my father’s house.”

verses.latin: Venit autem Gad ad David in die illa, et ait ei: Ascende, constitue altare Domino in area Areunae Iebusaei.
verses.english: Now Gad came to David on that day and said to him: “Go up and erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”

verses.latin: Et ascendit David juxta sermonem Gad, sicut præceperat Dominus.
verses.english: So David went up, just as Gad had told him, according to the Lord’s command.

verses.latin: Aspiciensque Areuna, et videns regem et servos eius transire ad se, egressus obviam regi, adoravit eum prono in terram vultu.
verses.english: Araunah looked up and saw the king and his servants coming toward him. So he went out to meet the king and prostrated himself before him with his face to the ground, showing his respect.

verses.latin: Et ait Areuna: Quare venit dominus meus rex ad servum suum? Cui respondens David, ait: Ut emam a te aream, et ædificem altare Domino, et cesset interfectionis plaga a populo.
verses.english: And Araunah said: “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David replied to him: “To buy the threshing floor from you, so I can build an altar to the Lord and stop the plague of death from affecting the people.”

verses.latin: Et ait Areuna ad David: Accipiat, et offerat dominus meus rex, sicut ei placet. Habes boves in holocaustum, et plaustrum, et iuga boum in ligna.
verses.english: Araunah said to David: “Let my lord the king take and offer whatever pleases him. You have oxen here for a burnt offering, and the threshing sledges, and the yokes of the oxen for wood.”

verses.latin: Omnia dedit Areuna rex regi: dixitque Areuna ad regem: Dominus Deus tuus propitius sit tibi.
verses.english: Araunah the king gave all these things to the king. And Araunah said to the king: “May the Lord your God be gracious to you.”

verses.latin: Cui respondens rex, ait: Nequaquam ut voluisti, sed emam pretio a te: neque enim offeram Domino Deo meo holocausta gratuita. Emit ergo David aream et boves argento siclis quinquaginta.
verses.english: But the king replied to him: “No, not as you wish. I will certainly buy it from you for a price. For I will not offer burnt offerings to the Lord my God that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty silver shekels.

verses.latin: Et ædificavit ibi David altare Domino, et obtulit holocausta et pacifica: et propitiatus est Dominus terræ, et sublata est plaga ab Israël.
verses.english: And David built an altar there to the Lord, and he offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. And the Lord was moved to mercy for the land, and the plague was lifted from Israel.
